DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Acting Treasurer forthwith advising the House of his reasons for demanding the Prime Minister's immediate resignation, as detailed on page 15 of today's Australian newspaper.

In today's Australian is a revelation of the greatest importance for all Australians. They all happen to be suffering under this Government. But what is alleged in this article goes to the heart of the very nature of government today and to the incompetence of the current Government. Mr Paul Kelly has revealed in today's Australian that, some six weeks ago, the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) called on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and demanded his resignation. We know that that followed more than simply-and I am an authority on car telephone calls-the call that Senator Richardson made on his car telephone to the Grim Reaper, that is, the person in the guise of the Treasurer. This is, however, no laughing matter. The article reveals more than simply a demand for resignation. It reveals hatred; it reveals animosity; it reveals frustration at the highest level of government amongst all the Government's economic Ministers. It reveals that Dawkins is finished with Hawke; that Hawke is finished with Dawkins; that Keating has considered resigning; that Walsh has told colleagues that he is thinking of quitting. Beyond that, it reveals the reasons for the absolute incoherence on living standards, on the direct impact of this Government, on taxes imposed on average Australians today, on the interest rates that they pay, on wage fixation, on the tax file number, on privacy-all of which the Government is unable to handle coherently. It reveals a government which is divided against itself. As Kelly puts it, the only certainty in terms of policy determination is uncertainty.

Let me quote from the article for those honourable members who have not seen it, to help them to understand the reasons for our calling on the Acting Treasurer to indicate to the Australian people why he is demanding the Prime Minister's resignation. He is not merely saying to the Prime Minister, `Lead us to the next election and then resign'; he is saying, `Go, and go now'. Of course, if he does not go, we will have, in the current Prime Minister, a mere lame duck. Let me quote from the article:
Dawkins said Hawke's record was unmatched . . . But it was important to know when to go; and that time had come.
It continues:
Dawkins is finished with Hawke . . . and Hawke, let me assure you, is finished with Dawkins.
Paul Kelly says, in fact, that Dawkins's main role these days is his `informal capacity as Paul Keating's campaign manager'. Paul Kelly goes on to say:

Here is the extraordinary situation into which the Hawke Government has got itself-with two senior economic ministers, the Treasurer and Acting Treasurer, Keating and Dawkins, both telling Bob Hawke he should go.
The real issue now is the fracture and tension in the Cabinet. It is a serious problem concerning authority, tactics and power within the Hawke Government.
He does not have to say it, but he does write it, that `Keating and Dawkins are profoundly unhappy'. And as he said:
This is not a media creation or a beat-up or some line being peddled by some so-called Keating push. This is a fundamental problem for the Hawke Government.
He goes on, in words of very few syllables, to say:
Nobody knows where the Hawke economic team is going from here. But the good old days are over. The super-optimists who think everybody can kiss and make up are in a condition of super-delusion.
Perhaps Keating will go; maybe there will be another reshuffle. The one certainty is uncertainty.

Then Paul Kelly talks of Walsh going on the Sunday program Face to Face, having told colleagues mid-year that he was thinking of quitting. This article is in itself sufficient reasons for the Acting Treasurer to be in here explaining why.
Opposition members-Where is he?

TALK.START.PARA: —He will not come in. We shall have whatever the Minister is these days as he is recycled, Mr Kerin, come in and explain it. Behind the scenes is the spectre of the Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), because if Hawke is finished with Dawkins, we know who he wants to make Treasurer. The Grim Reaper goes and in comes the man at the table. Ten out of ten for you, mate! Ten out of ten for you turning up today. Bob will be pleased. A lot of brownie points have been notched up this morning-just by sitting there, son; you are almost there. The foot is there. All we have to do is have the real Acting Treasurer, not the pretender, as at the table, come in and tell us why he said Hawke had to go.

SPEECH.PARA: This is at the heart of government. It is disunity in the Cabinet. It is frustration. It is anger. It is hatred, and it is all the stuff of personal ambition being played out. All this is occurring at a time of the highest levels of taxation being dumped on Australians and the absolute incoherence in government.

I said earlier that, whilst we want Dawkins in to explain to the Australian people why he said the Prime Minister has to go, it is not confined to him. Courtesy of the Keating-Richardson telephone conversation-it did not get quite the run that the Kennett-Peacock one did because just as it was about to be published the Government proclaimed on Tuesday of that week the legislation preventing the publication of such things.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great shame.
—I thought it was a shame, too, but the essence was the demand of Keating that Hawke go, just as Dawkins is doing now.

SPEECH.PARA: The nub of it is that the Government is paralysed, the economic policy is incoherent. Honourable members have seen all the changes and, behind it all, the frustration, the anger and the ambition of Hawke Ministers. If the people of Oxley had read the Kelly article last week, it would not have been a 13 per cent swing to us; it would have been significantly greater. In fact, there would not even be a Labor member for Oxley coming in but rather one from our side.

So this is a request. It may be asking too much to ask for honesty from the Government, but let the Acting Treasurer, in a form, as it were, of purging himself, do what is fundamental in our system of government: tell the people what he is on about. He is answerable to this Parliament. He has, as the Acting Treasurer, gone to the Prime Minister and demanded the Prime Minister's resignation, but he is not in here. The pretender is here. The brownie points are notched up. All in good stead is it moving for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is at the table; but we need the Acting Treasurer in to explain it away.

If the article is headed `Dawkins and Hawke have split', it is worse than that-it is the essence of the Government itself. As I said in quoting the article, all the senior economic Ministers are wanting or have indicated a desire to resign. There is a touch of irony there. The only one they really want to go is hanging on for grim death. The Prime Minister himself-the lame duck-is essentially keeping it warm until the Grim Reaper returns from overseas and winds up the campaign. How do honourable members think the Grim Reaper must feel with all the jobs that have been done on him while he has been away?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the honourable member please refer to the Treasurer as the Treasurer?
—Are you assuming, Madam Speaker, that I was referring to the Treasurer as the Grim Reaper?
—I was.

—I will refer to him as the Treasurer. This Government has adopted three attitudes in its propaganda. First, it talks itself up; it says that it is the greatest government in the history of this nation and the problem is that it actually believes that, although nobody else does. Secondly, it dumps it on the Opposition and, thirdly, it promotes some notion of unity when there is deep division in the camp. The nation suffers as a consequence and that is why the Government cannot get its economic policy right. The Acting Treasurer today has a bounden duty to come here and explain to the people what he explained to the Prime Minister in words of a few syllables-that he ought to go.
—Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and wish to address this particular issue immediately. What we are looking at today is a matter of huge national importance. We are looking at a split between major economic Ministers and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In these very difficult economic times the Australian people are entitled to be reassured. The best outcome of this motion for the nation would be for the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to come here and deny that he ever made these remarks and deny this article. He should have been here beating us to the punch. He should have been jumping up on a personal explanation and telling us that not for one moment has he ever suggested to his Prime Minister that he should leave. He should say that he supports the Prime Minister totally. But the Acting Treasurer is notable by his absence and, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has pointed out, the man who would prefer to have his job is sitting in here apparently with the intention of arguing that it is absolutely unnecessary for the Acting Treasurer to come here and reassure the Australian people that this Government is still on track. He should be telling us that the situation is not as Mr Kelly has described it in his article. Mr Kelly said:

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody knows where the Hawke economic team is going from here. But the good old days are over.
We know why the Acting Treasurer is not here: he has been caught out on radio as well. On 29 August he went on AM and the interviewer, Mr Maher, said:
On another matter Mr Dawkins, do you agree with Senator John Button that the Prime Minister should announce a timetable for his departure from politics, to avoid tensions over his successor?
Mr Dawkins replied-and I heard this personally:
I think certainly the question of succession has to be sorted out and the sooner the better, I would have thought.
When Mr Maher asked him whether he thought Mr Keating would be the next leader of the Australian Labour Party, the Acting Treasurer replied:
Oh of course. He has my full support to become the next leader of the party.

What was not said on that program was that on that same day, 29 August, he went into the Prime Minister's office and said that the succession should be sorted out now. By his absence he, like the Treasurer (Mr Keating), shows an arrogant disregard for his Prime Minister. The Treasurer refused to deny that he had had that phone conversation with Senator Richardson and by his refusal he confirmed that that outrageous conversation had occurred. Now we have another Minister, the Acting Treasurer, being reported as saying that he had been to his Prime Minister and told him to resign. He too will not come in here and deny it. That is absolute confirmation that that occurred. It is also absolute confirmation that, as Mr Kelly said, nobody knows where the Hawke economic team is going from here, but the good old days are over.

We now find that arrogance is not only being practised upon the Australian people but also being practised by senior Ministers upon the Prime Minister and upon the office of Prime Minister. That is outrageous and of huge concern to the Australian people when they see their living standards falling daily and their taxes rising-$275 per individual Australian in the last Budget. What reassurance do they get? They see everybody fighting over the top job and a Prime Minister who is now clearly evidenced as having no control at all over the situation.

You will remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, the last time we raised dissent in this place. I had to point out to Madam Speaker that we could not judge the issue on this Prime Minister because clearly this Prime Minister was different. He did not have any responsibility for his Ministers because he had lost control of them. I guess it was reasonable therefore that he did not have to answer an embarrassing question about the activities and actions of his Ministers. However, it does not alter the fact that what we are confronted with today is a headline that says that Dawkins and Hawke have split.

We are confronted with an article that says that the Acting Treasurer on 29 August asked his Prime Minister to resign and make way for the Treasurer, that the Acting Treasurer is acting as the Treasurer's campaign manager and that, of course, the situation is very grim because everybody wants the top job. The Australian people have to be reassured. It is outrageous that the Acting Treasurer is not here to reassure them by saying that it never happened and that that is not going to happen. We know it happened. We know now that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the Acting Leader of the House, is going to get up in defence again of this Minister who has demonstrated over the last four or five days that he cannot even answer questions. Of course, we have seen disaster for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Acting Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would have to be pretty blooming silly to take this censure motion seriously. The Opposition is fluttering around like the bogong moths in the chamber. Members of the Opposition come in and put on a bit of a display. The Peacock preens his feathers hoping to get a bit of a flash of blue. There are no policies from the Opposition. This Government has been responsible for the most fundamental restructuring of the economy. We pulled the economy out of the mess that the Opposition left for us. There was massive unemployment. We needed a total restructuring of secondary industry in this country. There was an overvalued exchange rate that had the miners and the farmers of this country in absolutely diabolical trouble.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The House ought to be made aware and so should the Minister that this is not a censure motion. It is a motion to give the Acting Treasurer an opportunity to explain his position.
—There is no point of order.

—I am quite happy to take the point of the honourable member for Hume. This suspension of Standing Orders is an absolute nonsense. It is all about a suspension based on a newspaper article. This is how good this Opposition is. The once great Liberal Party of Australia has sunk to this. The only thing it can ever come into the House about is a newspaper article. Last night I heard the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) say that he had read something in a newspaper. Now the Opposition accepts it as fact. Even the honourable member for Kooyong has said that I am going to be the Treasurer because he read it in an article by Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin-would you believe it. So anything that is written down the poor old Opposition believes because it has no policies. It has no capacity to analyse what is happening in this country. It has no capacity to put forward alternative economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: What is this all about? This is all about a cover-up for the weak, rotten leadership of the Liberal and National parties. They are in their opportunistic mode. What do we hear? One day we hear that the Leader will be John Elliott, then it will be Sallyanne Atkinson, then it could be Ian McLachlan. Anyone out there who gets a headline or two could be the next Leader of the Liberal Party. We have a totally opportunistic Opposition. There is not an ounce of courage or guts in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. On the matter of relevance--
—There is no point of order.
—I am sorry, there is a point of order. You have not heard my point of order at this stage.
—You had better quickly come to it.
—On the matter of relevance, the Minister is apparently here to defend the absent Acting Treasurer.
—There is no point of order.

—The Opposition is in its opportunistic mode. It has no economic policies. What happened? We had a terms of trade collapse in this country through 1985, 1986 and 1987. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) never said a word about that-it never existed. All he could talk about was that living standards might have dropped a bit. What would the Opposition have done? It would have thrown the economy into reverse. Honourable members should see what John Stone said about the October stock market crash. The only policy the Opposition had was to throw the economy into reverse. That is what it is all about. If the Opposition reads something in the newspapers it will come in here and try to suspend Standing Orders. The Opposition reads something in the polls, for example Asian immigration, and as a result decides that it will run that for a while. It will run anything that it sees as opportunistic, for example, the referendums. At all costs the Opposition had to preserve the coalition; so one vote one value had to be rejected. The Opposition could not upset the National Party of Australia about that. So what does the Opposition do? It knocks the whole lot over.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The motion before the House is about the suspension of Standing Orders to give the Acting Treasurer an opportunity to explain the reported statement. The Minister is not addressing the question. He is addressing other matters, and you should instruct him accordingly.
—Order! The Minister is bringing forward reasons why the motion should not be agreed to. The Minister is in order.

—Members of the Opposition have ranged widely and I am telling them the facts. This is opportunism. Anything they read in the newspapers they take as factual. This is just a nonsense. What did we have before the Victorian election? We had all the allegations about the Reserve Bank of Australia. Mr Johnston had to come out and say how stupid it was. Members of the Opposition are totally opportunistic. They can only run on what they see in a few polls around the place. Today we have the once great Liberal Party of Australia running on what it sees in the newspapers. This is an absolute nonsense. I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a few matters relating to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in discussing the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89. I begin by endorsing the words of my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who pointed out that agriculture still is our major export earner. As he said, despite all the rhetoric and all the efforts of some to get other industries involved more in exports agriculture is still the No. 1 export earner. It is important to keep this perspective on these appropriations and in particular on the way in which the Government has altered some of the recording of these appropriations.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw attention to the fact that, with agriculture still the major export earner, it is amazing how the Government places such a low priority on trade in general when we still have this chronic balance of payments problem. In the past two months the balance of payments has come out far worse than the Government would have anticipated and far worse, I think, than all Australians would like to see. In addition, we have had a clear warning from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), as reported in the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 26 September. With respect to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, I will read from this newspaper cutting because it is worth taking note of. It was pointed out:

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has predicted another glut in farm goods, and lower market prices, resulting from the continuing $300 billion a year in agricultural subsidies.
It goes on:
The OECD report warns that the longer the significant reduction in supports-
that is, overseas-
is delayed the greater will be the extent of the eventual adjustment.

With that background it is very disturbing to notice that in relation to the Government's emphasis on trade, although there is a lot of rhetoric, and maybe encouraging rhetoric, when we look at the cold, hard facts and the Budget statements for 1988-89 we find that the assistance to export industries has been cut. Assistance for trade in the export market development schemes, export trade promotion and the other various forms of government assistance for improving our trade have been cut. Not only have they been cut, but they have been cut by a massive 25 per cent.

When we look at the problems of our balance of trade and the warnings the OECD has been putting out about the future for agricultural trade in particular, and bearing in mind that agricultural trade is still our major export earner, it is very disturbing to find the Government's Budget statements telling us that the Government seems to think so little of improving trade that it has made a 25 per cent reduction in the amount of funds allocated for trade development.

The other matter I should like to draw to honourable members' attention is the way the Government has changed its accounting procedures in reporting the assistance to agriculture, forestry and fishing, as pointed out in the Budget Papers. I find this very disturbing, even though the Minister admits that he is well aware of it. We find an extraordinary change. In order to make it clearer, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables, one from last year's Budget statements and one from page 217 of this year's Budget statements, which show the change in the financial outlays for agriculture.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. We see the way the Government has changed its method of accounting. In the past the Government included the net outlays going to a particular agricultural industry only because it was recognised, and recognised quite correctly, that where levies were raised by the Government on behalf of a particular industry and those levies were agreed to by the industry then that was not really government assistance but in fact was an industry helping itself. We see from the tables some remarkable changes in the accounting.

SPEECH.PARA: In the latest Budget statements the Government has included the full value of these levies as though they were government outlays. If we compare these two tables and have a quick look at a couple of the figures, in the summary from last year for agricultural and pastoral industries, the actual outlays in the wool industry, for example, were $96.9m. That includes promotion, research and a few other things. Looking at the sum recorded in this year's Budget statements, we find for under 1986-87, the same year, the figure has miraculously jumped from $96.9m to $342.7m. Same year, same industry, and yet the figure has increased by 3 1/2 times. This new accounting system, I feel, ought to be changed back to the old one. It gives a highly misleading picture of the Government's real outlays for the industry. Someone who is not fully au fait with what is going on gets a very inflated picture of the true level of the assistance the Government is giving to the various primary industries.

Taking another example, the 1986-87 actual amount for the dairy industry in last year's Budget statements shows that in fact there is a credit of $3.2m. Yet miraculously, when we look at the figures for the same year in this year's Budget statements, that $3.2m credit has been altered to $217.3m debit. In other words, it appears to someone who is not really informed about it that the Government has given the dairy industry $217m, which of course is absolute rubbish. It is very misleading and I think it behoves the Minister, if he is fair dinkum about the importance of presenting a fair and true picture of the real state of assistance to various industries, to alter the accounting procedures that have been adopted in this year's Budget statement back to what they were.

It would be very easy for people who are not fully informed about what is going on in the industry to misunderstand these figures. For example the gross figures for the various primary industries, again taking 1986-87, in last year's Budget Statements show the total as $460m. If we look at this year's Budget statements, that figure has jumped to $1.3 billion. It is the same year but a different accounting method has been used. This is something I view very seriously and I hope the Minister will give some undertaking about that for next year's Budget Papers, irrespective of whether he is still the Minister. We heard earlier this morning that he may be in for a promotion. He is nodding his head in agreement; he is looking forward to that promotion. Before he shifts he has to get that fixed, even if he happens to be the Treasurer.

In the short time left to me I would like to repeat the concern that members of the Opposition have for the cuts in the Budget to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). We have seen some very serious cuts, not just in the last year but over five years. In fact, if we look at the changes, starting in 1983-84-this Government's first year in office-in real terms the CSIRO budget was $331.6m. It has been cut every year in real terms since then. In 1984-85 it was cut by 6 per cent; in 1985-86 by 2 per cent; in 1986-87 by another 2 per cent; in 1987-88 by 12 per cent; and in the current Budget by a further 8 per cent. This is causing enormous problems. As the shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), has already pointed out, people working for the CSIRO are becoming very disillusioned and are rapidly looking for ways and means of getting out of it. What will the Government do? We will have another inquiry. The figures speak for themselves. We do not need another inquiry to tell us what is wrong. What is wrong is the cuts to the Budget.

I think it is important for the Minister to address the points that have been raised. In order to improve our trade we need a commitment by the Government to the importance of maintaining a consistent level of funding. We need a commitment to clarify in the Budget Papers the method of accounting so that people do not get inflated ideas of what the Government's real level of assistance to primary industry is. We need a commitment to the importance of maintaining a real effort in our research. Without those things there is no doubt that not only the agricultural sector but also Australia in general will be worse off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have contributed to the discussion of the estimates for the portfolio of Primary Industries and Energy, particularly the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin). No member of the Opposition spoke on the resources and energy part of the portfolio. That is understandable, given the composition of the seats of many honourable members opposite. I point out that the resources and energy industries are very much part of rural Australia, as are the people who live in the towns and provincial cities.

SPEECH.PARA: One Opposition member, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), concentrated his remarks on the research portfolio. Those questions would be better directed to the responsible Minister, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), who has a responsibility as spokesman on resources, did not speak. The former Opposition spokesman on energy, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), has been replaced in that role by the honourable member for Gippsland, so it seems that it is a fair case to make that the Opposition does not take energy all that seriously.

In responding to some of the comments I will contain my remarks to agriculture. One can sum up the contribution of the Opposition as being, `Yes, it is very important to cut government spending, but certainly not here. It is very good to apply all sorts of strictures to the rest of the economy, but not here'. The double standard prevails. In many of the comments there was a lot of selective figuring. There is a double standard in the general claims by the Opposition that there should be incentives for agriculture, for trade. It says, `Remove protection for secondary industries, but not agricultural subsidies and protection'.

I will try to put the whole question of levels of assistance to agriculture into the overall context, because the decisions we took in the May statement in respect of across-the-board industry protection, including in some of the agricultural industries, will mean, in time, a saving of $300m to $400m a year in costs for each of the agriculture and resources sectors. Some of the most recent Treasury and Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates show that, all things being equal-of course, we know that things are not equal all the time-and on current projections we will get, from that measure alone, an additional $1.2 billion worth of exports in the early 1990s.

Let us look at the cost situation compared with that which prevailed when we came to office. We now have the best terms of trade figures for 17 years and the lowest farm cost figure of about 4 per cent or 5 per cent, compared with 11 per cent when we came to government. An indication of the health of the sector is that land values are rising again. There is a lot of re-investment in agriculture. That is a good thing. I am not one to talk about people never having had it so good. Agriculture never had it so bad in quite recent times, particularly during 1985-86, but even then, some industries were getting on reasonably well. The really bad part of the agriculture sector was the cereal sector. It certainly went through the toughest time that we have known for a very long time.

We do not say one thing here and another thing abroad. Mr Anthony, after the 1977 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round, said that he did not have to touch one item of secondary industry protection and that we got off scot-free. We all know-and now the more economically literate members of the Opposition know-that levels of secondary industry protection are a tax on exporters. What we in government are trying to say is that cuts in protection do not advantage just the exporting sectors; they advantage all of us as consumers in society.

There has been quite a bit of discussion on interest rates. Basically interest rates go up and down. If a country has a floating currency, a deregulated financial market, if it has measures of money supply, a credit economy, a plastic card economy, many of these things must be dealt with under a whole new perspective. The 90-day bank bill rate-the rate at which the banks borrow-peaked at 19.8 per cent at the beginning of 1986 and dropped to just under 11 per cent by January this year. So there was a drop during that two-year period. During the life of the last Government, the 90-day bank bill rate was 21.75 per cent for a period and dropped in 1984 to 9 per cent. I do not make much of those figures, other than to say that interest rates will go up and down and they will fluctuate when there is a floating currency and deregulated financial markets. That is the nature of it. Sure, it can always be exploited. The argument on interest rates can never be won because everyone wants low interest rates. But interest rates are one of the policy instruments available to the Government which help fortify our exporting industries, in as much as if the price for our commodities falls overseas and the exchange rate falls, that provides a cushion, but, of course, interest rates must increase. That is the new ball game that exists.

We have cut Government spending. The Opposition would like to cut a lot more, but historically we are in surplus and have a nil public sector borrowing requirement. We are heading for a lower inflation rate. If we can hold together all the parameters through this year, in terms of our economic management, using all of the measures available to us flexibly, we will get lower inflation and, therefore, lower interest rates. That is what the Government is talking about. The Liberal Party is saying that we should give tax cuts now. It never accepted the trade problem which existed, particularly during 1985, 1986 and 1987. It never really contemplated looking at the effects of some of its non-policies, particularly those which would suck in imports and wreck our inflationary position.

During that period when there was a massive terms of trade crisis, the Opposition never stated what its alternative policy would be. Unspoken, its policy was that the economy should be thrown into reverse. The same prognostications came from various people such as Senator Stone during the October stock market crash. The instant thing to do was to throw the economy into reverse. The comments by members of the Opposition show that they have learnt little or that they are appeasing their country constituents by telling them what they want to hear. I have never adopted that path.

Now that the portfolio has been expanded to include primary industries and energy, my portfolio is associated with 80 to 85 per cent of Australia's exports. That proportion coming from primary and resources industries will remain at that level in the future, as far as we can see it. Of course, we should try to broaden the base of the economy. The 1985-86 terms of trade collapse showed how thin and vulnerable Australia was to exposure on corrupt international markets for commodities.

In the past we have had debates in this House and in the community that centred on agriculture versus mining. At least, with the big industry portfolios, both the agriculturalists and the miners know that they are in the one boat and that their own interests are mutually supportive. Now we have the debate that agriculture and mining are somehow against the secondary industries. What I say to the Opposition and outside commentators is that the more constructive approach is to look at the linkages and look at the complementarities. As I have said, the Government's strategy concentrates very much on the float, financial deregulation, the wages accord, and the fact that we will deregulate where there are sensible reasons; that we are not engaging in deregulation or privatisation from any ideological bent. We have these very fundamental economic measures in place because that will be bringing around a restructuring, and when there is an increasing job situation, increasing jobs on the domestic market, when all the economic policies are not throwing the economy into reverse, jobs are created and then cuts to industry protection can effectively be put in place. That is what we are doing-unlike the Whitlam years and the 25 per cent across the board cut, which really had a bad effect because the economy was not expanding. So we have put in place these measures that really bring about a restructuring and are broadening our base, and because we are able to lower levels of protection we are lowering costs. Because of all these measures we are getting fundamental restructuring and are enabled to pass on the benefits of cuts in tariffs.

I will not comment on it too much but, obviously, the alternative economic policy is one to throw it into reverse. That is what Senator Stone still says. Senator Stone now says, with a fair amount of veracity, that we should not give big tax cuts now-which is against the opportunistic statements of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

There has been some discussion on research, and I have been well and truly involved in this debate in the broader community. There are some matters I can put forward in the context of what I have already said. First of all, we have been underspending on research in the CSIRO. I do not back away from that statement at all. It is a statement I have made in other places and it is a statement that the Prime Minister and the Cabinet have taken on board due to the work of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business and of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and myself. However, I would like to make some additional points.

First of all, on the crude figuring, if one compares this year's with last year's figures for the CSIRO, the Institute of Animal Products and Processing was actually up by 2.9 per cent; the Institute of Plant Production and Processing was down by 1.8 per cent, a decrease of $1.5m. What these crude budget figures do not tell, of course, is the amount of funds coming in from outside for the CSIRO. The institutes that handle industry and information industries were up; by some $5.8m for the Institute of Industrial Technologies and by $3.5m for the Information and Communications Technologies Institute.

They were up, but I make the point that more expenditure on research in the manufacturing parts of CSIRO is no bad thing necessarily for primary industries. If they emphasise their work, put emphasis on value adding, that adds value to our primary exports, our resource exports. I make the point that if there is additional money spent on service industries, this is no bad thing. If we get better transport, better financial services and better services as a whole, this is no bad thing. So I am bringing out the linkages and the complementarities.

Similarly, with information industries, the information base to our society, there is need for research there. Computer-aided livestock marketing, what the CSIRO will be able to do with reinterpretation of weather data electronically, distance education, all of these new technologies-again, they are no bad thing for our primary and resource industries. We want to look more and more at the linkages and the complementarities, rather than some bald analysis which is just based on figures or sector versus sector.

As honourable members know, the rural industry research funds have expanded greatly in the amount of funds being attributed to them. The special research grant scheme has also vastly expanded since the days of the previous Government and we have set up various research and development corporations, and they are certainly leading the way in expending quite a lot more money.

A comment was made that secondary industry does not levy itself whereas primary industries do have to put in some money. I suppose one has to think about what is the nature of secondary industry and what is the nature of primary industry. Primary industry has something like 170,000 units; atomistic competition: no one person is able to do his or her research. Therefore, it is best to go in on a basis whereby the Government is contributing money. In other words, there is a very good argument for public contribution of funds. Similarly, there is a very good argument for a levy mechanism, and by giving incentives we have been able to get a lot more money into research through this way. With secondary industry we have gone for a taxation deduction because, in many industries, we are dealing literally with a handful of firms. That is by far the better way to go than trying to levy them somehow.

I make all these points, as I made them a few minutes ago in the debate on the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, in the light of the fact that we took office when there was a recessed economy. At that time there had been a wage blow-out and there was a very high exchange rate, which was crippling our export industries. We saw the near destruction of secondary industry. What we have in place are policies aimed at the restructuring of the Australian economy. So we got through that recessed period-and then we faced the commodity price crash. Through 1985, 1986 and 1987, this, of course, pushed up interest rates. The exchange rates dropped for some commodities by up to 45 per cent-about 45 per cent for coal, and about a 37 per cent drop in the value of the dollar for the full bracket of agricultural industries. The depreciation kept us in business, but of course, international debt rose. What the Opposition never answered then-and the Leader of the Opposition seriously avoids it-is what they would have done. The only alternative economic strategy would have been to throw the economy into reverse and cause another half a million people to be unemployed.

What was remarkable about the 1985, 1986 and into 1987 crash was that the prices of nearly all commodities came down. In the commodity markets, we are now back into the more usual situation where some are up and some are down. There are about 21 commodities in my portfolio-with exports worth from $350m per annum to $5.6 billion and $5.8 billion per annum for coal and wool. But we are now in the more usual situation. We have just held the line on coking coal. We have had an actual increase on steaming coal. Iron ore prices are still depressed. Wheat has been terrible, as I have said, but it looks like facing a year or two of good prices. Lead is still down. Sugar has been up high and is now settling down to a new sort of position. Aluminium clearly will hold, by an examination of the order books, through calendar 1989. So we know where we are. It is the more usual pattern. Some commodity prices are up and some are down, and this is giving a balancing.

There has been a lot of speculation about the commodity price outlook as factored into the Budget itself. We are saying-and it is the basis of those calculations-that when the pluses and the minuses are put together, by and large we face a zero change in resource sector prices, along with the forecast of about a 7 per cent increase in farm sector prices. On the resource side, with that additional money we got for steaming coal and the other prices as they come in from the other markets, we will probably have an increase right through the year on resource sector prices. But if it is put together with the latest figuring, there will be average increases in commodity export prices of about 3 per cent this year.

That may be seen by some to contradict the Budget forecast of a 9.4 per cent increase in Australia's terms of trade, but this increase has occurred despite a 12 per cent currency appreciation in trade weighted terms. So it represents a 17 per cent increase in commodity prices in world prices. If this currency change is fully passed on in lower import prices, then these forecasts imply a terms of trade increase at this stage of well over 10 per cent compared with the Budget forecast of 9.4 per cent.

These commodity matters, resource trends and agricultural trends are given to me constantly. They appear in various documents at three-monthly intervals and I would advise honourable members who are confused about it all just to look at resource trends and the work by the ABARE. It is all out there in the public place. The estimates can be seen. Estimates can always go wrong, but at this stage we can say with certainty that in terms of commodity prices affecting the Budget, everything is very much on track. The Treasury estimates are conservative, certainly at least for the first six months of 1988-89.

The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) pointed out the problems of drought, particularly in the Eyre Peninsula and in other parts of South Australia. This is a constant problem. Recently I looked at some figures and found that in 41 per cent of all the months for the past 12 years one Pastures Protection Board area of New South Wales was in drought. Other parts of Australia have suffered drought for 31 per cent of months over the past 10 or 12 years. That means that for more than half the time over the past 12 years great parts of this country have been constantly in drought.

That may say something about drought declaration procedures, but I think it also says either that the traditional ways of looking at drought are not working as well as they could or that we need to have a redefinition of drought. When a piece of country, producing certain commodities, is in drought for all that time, perhaps people should face up to the fact that they will have to look at other ways of dealing with the problem. Natural disaster relief arrangements certainly will not address a problem of that dimension, particularly on very big properties. That is why we have revised the rural adjustment scheme funding arrangements. We will then have $28,000 up front. That legislation will come into the Parliament soon and it will enable people who are in an impossible situation to get off their properties with some dignity. I could speak at length about this, but I think the connection between land degradation and drought and the way that farmers can interact with some of the policy measures available to them will probably be the thing to look at in the future.

The honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) mentioned coal and soil conservation. I will not say much more on those matters. He pointed to discussions by the Australian Conservation Foundation at the weekend about the way in which farmers treat the land. I would simply say that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) made some pungent points about the way in which we look after our land, but thinking that this can be cured by legislative arrangements is wrong. I believe we need to continue to work with the States, the farmers and those people who look after the land. That is the only way to go on this most vital issue. In some places it is a question of `carrot and stick', with the stick to be exercised by the States and by the Commonwealth Government. But really we must consider more ideas of conservation farming. The reality is that there is an enormous amount of goodwill and thoughtfulness among our farmers to this end. These are issues on which we will have to continue to work.

My final point is in response to the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who spoke about trade. I have already pointed out that floating our currency probably did more for trade in this country than anything else. The formation of Austrade, the innovative agricultural marketing program and the marketing skills program we are developing, the work we are doing on value-added on early stage processing in wool, the work of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council and the wool initiative with China all point to the fact that this Government has emphasised trade in a way that no other government has. The Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) is overseas now and we are putting every effort into the Montreal meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the mid-term review. That is the longer term strategy. People quite realistically say that the prospects for getting freer world agricultural trade may be low, but the potential reward will be extremely high. That is the main game in town and we are playing it as hard as we can. I believe we are carrying out short term and medium term initiatives on trade on a day to day approach in every way that we possibly can.

Finally, I draw the attention of the honourable member for Wannon to page 411 in the Budget Statements 1988-89. In absolutely no way have I tried to purport that this change in the presentation of the Budget Estimates is supposed to represent a big increase in spending for the farm sector, or the primary industry and resources sector. It is simply the reclassification of primary industry charges and levies from outlays to revenue which has removed a major difference in treatment between the Budget and statistics of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It was done for better accounting and administration right through the Government. We are trying more and more to get this complete openness, transparency and consistency in Government figurings and the presentation of outlay and revenue figures, just as we are trying to get, and are succeeding in getting, more modern management systems right through the Public Service by taking a better approach to public administration.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Social Security
Proposed expenditure, $653,430,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government which has produced this Budget has had as its catchcry in recent years `social justice'. This Government came to power more than five years ago believing in compassion and concern, but there are many people in Australia who-as we saw last Saturday in the by-election in Queensland-now regard this Government as one which has lost touch with ordinary people, as one which is arrogant and out of touch with the realities of the circumstances facing the hundreds of thousands of low income Australians who, to one degree or another, are dependent upon the activities of the Department of Social Security and the social welfare policies of this Government. Put quite simply, I believe that most people have lost trust, not only in the rhetoric of the Government but also in its capacity, in an environment of steadily lowering standards of living, to come to grips in any real way with the impact of its policies on ordinary people.

SPEECH.PARA: Only a few weeks ago the Chairman of Committees, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and I addressed some 3,000 retirees and pensioners in Sydney. This was a very large and noisy public meeting organised by Greypower. Anyone who went there would have come away with nothing but the clear view that we were seeing just the edge of a massive rejection of Government policy. There were thousands of people there who had previously voted Labor, but who believed that they had now been forgotten and who were certainly not prepared to forgive the party in which they had previously placed their trust. Much of this has occurred because over the last five and a bit years this Government has failed to implement effectively a viable retirement incomes policy, despite its substantial rhetoric dating back to May 1983. For example, it has not effectively addressed double dipping, which is a problem in our system. It is a matter of great consequence because effectively it means that people who have the advantage of tax support through superannuation have, by one means or another, also been able to get access to the pension-a pension which has been funded by more than 50 per cent of the Australian work force who have no superannuation and who can justifiably argue that they are paying part of their taxes so that other people who have the advantage of superannuation can effectively have two bites at the cherry.

The Government has also introduced seven major changes to the treatment of pensioner income. Its last performance in the Budget was clearly an error on which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) was finally required to back down. The Budget was then changed not just because of the noises coming from Victoria, which was then facing an election, and the very real risk of a major pensioner backlash, but also-and more importantly-because the Government was wrong and it accepted that fact, albeit very late in the piece.

At the end of the day one thing is clear: there is now a state of massive confusion not only among pensioners and superannuants, not only among investment analysts and those who are involved in the superannuation industry but also, more importantly, among those affected, and anyone in Australia over the age of 50 has reason to be concerned about his or her financial viability in retirement. The vast majority of pensioners who own capital are people who, by their own common sense and hard work, have been able to accumulate modest amounts of capital during their working life. They now face the difficulty of trying to maintain a reasonable standard of living in the face of growing inflation, rising taxation and the onslaught of ever-changing regulations. We have seen successive pieces of legislation which have necessitated often complex calculation and record keeping, not just by large superannuation companies but by small superannuation companies as well.

The outcome of all of that is that over the next few years we will see thousands of those smaller schemes going to the wall. They will be incorporated in the National Mutuals, the AMPs and the big five. The outcome of all that will be that the power of the purse will influence not just the decision-making processes of companies in which these superannuation funds have invested, but more significantly even than that, the decisions of governments themselves. That will be the reality of the future because there is no doubt that if we are going to allow a massive concentration of economic power in the hands of a few we will have to do so at a cost. It will be a cost which will be expensive for all Australians in the future.

The Labor Government has failed to provide stability and security in retirement to over 2.3 million pensioners despite all the changes that we have seen in both superannuation and pensions in recent years. There have been seven changes to pensions in five years alone in terms of the income test. There have been over 20 major changes to superannuation. In all of that the Government has still managed to increase the tax take on superannuation because fundamentally the reforms it has introduced, despite all the rhetoric, are not about applying a better regime for retirement planning in Australia; they are about increasing revenue. How else can it defend the situation where over the last five years we have seen tax on superannuation alone increase by nearly 1,000 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that the tax revenue implications of his changes were a mere $1.4 billion. He is wrong; he will be shown to be wrong. He has five sets of tax points. He has applied 1.4 to two of them. What about the other three? How much revenue is he going to get from those three? We do not know; I doubt whether he does either.

Nevertheless, we see constant changes to the superannuation arrangements. The last May statement and the last Budget have added further confusion to people who in their later years ask for only two things: financial security, on the one hand, and health support on the other. They are the two most important elements of a retiree's expectation of what he should get from government in the future. What has been the reaction of the industry to these changes? Mr Mayer, the Managing Director of National Mutual Life Association of Australia, the erstwhile ally of the Treasurer, who was quoted on numerous occasions at the time of the last May statement, said:

There is quite significant concern about the fact that the legislation is not yet available. It should be better than this. Currently, what we have been doing is running our business on indications expressed by press release.
Another industry source said:
Many millions are being deducted by superannuation funds and are not being paid to people who are withdrawing. It doesn't have the force of law.

We were told at the last Budget that within two months the Government would bring into the House the superannuation legislation to put in law the changes announced last May. Since then we have seen six sets of new changes by press release, by public pronouncement, by speeches but not by act of Parliament. We are now in the enormously difficult situation where people who were meant to be trustees and the trust deed states explicitly their responsibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Blanchard, as I understand it, we are discussing the estimates for the Department of Social Security. I think what the honourable member for Bradfield is telling us about are some changes within the portfolio of the Treasurer and not changes that fit into the estimates of the Department of Social Security. I think that the honourable member should be asked to confine his remarks to the estimates that are actually before us.
—I have been listening to the honourable member. I can see that there is some relevance to the issue before the House. The honourable member can continue.

—The point I was making before that rude interruption was simply this: in a situation where retirement income planning depends on legislation, we have no legislation. The situation is that trustees responsible for superannuation, which is the very basis of retirement income planning for 1.6 million Australians, are now in an invidious position where they are unable to meet their requirements as trustees because they are also expected to be tax collectors for the Commissioner of Taxation. One cannot do it both ways. One cannot obey God and mammon in the environment in which this Government has placed the industry today. The result of all of that is that millions of dollars has been collected. On the Treasurer's own estimate $1.4 billion has been collected in a 12-month period which is not the Government's money because it has no legislation to collect it.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I would like to make a few comments about the contribution of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). In one sense I congratulate him for representing his constituents. He, of course, represents an area commonly known as the north shore of Sydney which includes areas such as St Ives. As one who represents the interests of his constituents he has opposed some of the reforms which this Government has brought in in relation to social security. When the previous Minister for Social Security, Senator Don Grimes, introduced the assets test the honourable member for Bradfield and his Party believed that millionaires should still continue to receive a pension irrespective of the level of their assets. There have been some rumours that they are reconsidering their position on that. But, at this stage I understand that the shadow Cabinet has not yet come to a decision. We will wait with bated breath to see what the honourable member for Bradfield does. Also, of course, as a good member for the suburb of St Ives he has opposed the tightening of the income test which this Government has brought in. He is correct that sometimes the closing of loopholes has been very complex. The Government has been forced to introduce some complex legislation to make the income test work fairly. The reason the Government has had to introduce very complex formulas to make the income test work fairly is that accountants and lawyers will go to amazing lengths to find new ways so that people can avoid that income test.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I think it is unfair that someone in my electorate who lives in Long Jetty and who has a very small amount of money in the bank or building society will start to lose part of his pension once he earns more than $40 a week in interest, yet someone in the electorate of the honourable member for Bradfield who lives in St Ives and who could have hundreds of thousands of dollars invested in a particular deferred annuity trust can continue to get the full pension. I think that is unfair and wrong. I support the Government's moves to change the rules so that the income test for future investments is fair. That is something I support. One contradiction which I thought appeared in the contribution of the honourable member for Bradfield today was his criticism of this Government for not having any retirement income package. He said that this Government has not done anything about double dipping because this Government has allowed people to continue to collect superannuation and then also to collect the full pension. Frankly, I think that is a bit opportunistic of him to make that allegation when he has opposed every attempt that this Government has made to make the system fairer. He should go back, think the system through, and stop trying to be an opportunist scoring political votes every chance he gets.

This morning I wish to address three issues in the time that is left to me, that is, firstly, the Child Support Agency; secondly, the need for some reform of independent advice to pensioners on where they should invest their money; and, if I have some time left, thirdly, the eligibility for fringe benefits. I support the Government's principle of introducing the Child Support Agency so that non-custodial parents make a contribution towards the upkeep of children who are living with the other parent. As we all know full well, 70 per cent of non-custodial parents today do not make any contribution towards the upkeep of their children. I support the decision of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to introduce a system so that the Taxation Office collects a contribution from that non-custodial parent and provides that to the parent who is looking after and rearing the children so that those children do have a standard of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support that.

—The shadow Minister for social security and retirement income, the honourable member for Bradfield, says that he supports that as well. I wish to mention one difficulty that has arisen with this scheme. As part of the package brought in by the Minister we introduced a new income test on maintenance. Previously, people could earn up to $40 a week in interest or maintenance and still receive the full pension. The new system means that, once a custodial parent receives more than $15 per week in maintenance, he or she starts to lose 50c in the dollar in his or her pension. I admit that the Minister introduced a measure which froze the current level of pensions for pensioners and it was expected that the new system would come into effect only if there was a change in circumstances. I had understood that to mean that, if a person received an increase in maintenance or an increase in interest earnings, the new arrangements would be triggered.

SPEECH.PARA: However, two women constituents of mine who are separated from their husbands receive the age pension and they were getting very modest maintenance but it was more than $15 per week. I was surprised to learn that simple increases in their pensions for consumer price index (CPI) adjustments have resulted in triggering the new arrangements. That has meant that these pensioners have not had a reduction in their pension but they have not had the normal CPI adjustment for inflation. So in real terms they are behind. That is something that I had not expected because we had said that only if there were a change in circumstances would the new arrangements come into effect. I suggest to the Minister that the new arrangements should be triggered only if there is an increase in maintenance or other non-pension income and simple CPI increases should not be considered as something that should trigger the new income test.

The second point I wish to raise this morning again goes back to the income test and the confusion that exists to a large extent in the community about what is considered income by the Department of Social Security. I am concerned about some of the investment advisers who, these days, are giving advice to retired people on where they should invest their money. Of course, there are some investment advisers and some investment companies that are competent and reputable and they give good advice. But I am afraid to say that I have come across some cases where constituents of mine who have retired have received very poor advice and, in some cases, they have been asked to pay quite exorbitant fees to these allegedly competent investment advisers. In other cases I am very concerned that perhaps these allegedly independent investment advisers are not independent; perhaps they might be receiving some form of inducement to recommend one form of investment over another. Perhaps the Government should consider providing some form of independent investment counselling through the Department of Social Security or through the Australian Taxation Office, or perhaps we could induce the people's bank, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, to increase the number of staff that it has available to provide retired people with investment advice. It has been my experience that the Commonwealth Bank, and usually the other major banks, provide good advice to retirees. But I am very concerned that some people who are not properly qualified are claiming to be giving independent and wise advice to pensioners when that is simply not the case.

The last point I wish to raise is the question of fringe benefits. This is something which is of great concern to many retired people. They wish to receive concessions on rates, electricity charges, telephone charges, car registration, drivers' licences and other items. In some cases qualifying for a fringe benefit card can mean that a pensioner receives a benefit worth up to $50 a week in cash. So fringe benefits are very important for the security of a retired person. As a result, some pensioners will go to amazing lengths to qualify for that fringe benefits card. We have an income limit and also an assets limit on eligibility for fringe benefits. Often it is very distressing for a pensioner who ends up a few cents a week or even a dollar a week over that limit and then loses eligibility for all his fringe benefits. I know that this is a problem that has existed for many years under governments of all political persuasions.

There are cases-of course, the Minister would be aware of these-where pensioners have invested very large amounts of money in interest-free cheque accounts or other interest-free accounts-perhaps more than $20,000-simply so that they can qualify for fringe benefits. The banks are quite happy to receive their money and not pay any interest to them. I just think some pensioners are not investing in their own best interests. So again I think there is need for some independent advice.

I wish to support the suggestions of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) that the Government look at a senior citizen's card which could be issued to all pensioners over the age of 70 so that they could receive concessions on transport, rates and other items. I believe that that is something that this Government should consider. It would mean that pensioners would not have to go to great lengths to try to reduce their income or hide their income so that they can receive their fringe benefits card. I am sure that, given this Minister's record, he will take up these comments in the positive manner in which they were made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the committee debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 I wish to speak about the Department of Social Security, under the heading `Secure Retirement'. The Hawke Labor Government has included in its Budget legislation measures that seriously affect the financial security of people in retirement. The legislation, in its original form, certainly had a glaring retrospective effect. Even after a quick patch-up job by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) the retrospective aspect remains. The legislation seeks to include as income for the purpose of the age pension income test-not for taxation purposes-returns from market-linked investments. Market-linked investments include approved deposit funds, deferred annuities, managed insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, equity trusts, property trusts and any other managed or pooled fund or trust. Exempt from the proposed new rules are direct share investments, direct property investments, friendly society bonds bought before the last new year and non-managed investments such as coins, gold and antiques. It is interesting to note that antique clocks remain exempt from the Hawke Labor Government's latest legislative attempt to fatten the Commonwealth coffers, which have quadrupled in size in the past five years.
—You could not guess why!
—I could not either! It is the nature of these exemptions which highlights just how intrusive the new legislation is.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation, in its original form, would have seen at least 33,000 age pensioners lose their pensioner benefit cards-estimated by the Australian Council of Social Service to be worth between $20 and $50 a week-and part, if not all, of their age pensions as a result of new laws affecting investment decisions made in a different environment. However, industry sources have estimated that those Australians affected would be in excess of 100,000. In addition we must consider the impact that that would have on the dependants of pensioners. People who are 70 years of age invariably have children in the 40 to 50 age group and they are most distraught that their parents might be denied this access in retirement. For weeks these people were stricken with anxiety over the possibility of having to rearrange their meagre portfolios and possibly suffer substantial cuts to their retirement income. The plans of a lifetime of a whole generation were left hanging in the balance. Meanwhile, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), who is from my home city of Adelaide, asked the House by way of interjection:
Why should they get special treatment?
The honourable member for Hawker went on to say that the `they' she was referring to were:
. . . pensioners who, until now, have been able to benefit from a loophole whereby income from market-linked investments is not assessed for social security purposes.

The honourable member for Hawker thinks she is talking about the rich retirees of Sanctuary Cove. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) talked about my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the north shore electorate. The people that I have been talking to, the working class constituents and the fair dinkum people whose doors I have knocked on, are in Greenacres, Prospect, Kilburn and Enfield. They are substantial suburbs in South Australia that are not flush with the luxury that the honourable member for Dobell thinks and the honourable member for Hawker believes Australia is full of.

Some of these people caught the bus to fill two meetings. I, along with several hundred other people, attended these meetings of the South Australian Council on the Ageing Inc.-SACOTA-to discuss their concerns, and they are all deeply concerned. These people have battled financial hardship all their lives to put a little by to live in dignity in their retirement. The personal grief and mental anguish of these people is tangible, yet this arrogant Government, again out of touch with the electorate, continues to use its sledgehammer-to-crack-a-nut policies, disadvantaging tens of thousands in its mania to prevent one retiree from getting away with one cent that he may not be entitled to, according to its socialist ideology. It is obscene to see just who is being affected by this proposed legislation. I ask honourable members to note that I say `is being affected' not `will be affected'. These people are already suffering.

The current generation of retirees have worked their whole lives in the belief that while there was a national superannuation scheme their taxes entitled them to an age pension. The pension has been central to their plans for a secure retirement. Now, since its advent in the 1960s, inflation has added another dimension to retirement and must be accounted for in retirement planning. A 55-year-old may need to fund a retirement equal in length to his or her entire working life, thanks to advances in medical science. A retiree needs some way to secure whatever nest egg he or she has against erosion by inflation, to provide for future expenses such as a new hot water system, clothes, shoes, bed linen and perhaps a new car 10 years down the track.

History shows that the purchasing power of $1 in 1972 was reduced to 34c in 1982. They are consumer price index figures. One's nest egg has to treble every 10 years to keep pace with inflation. In recent years a popular method of investing capital for future use has been market-linked investments. These investments are characterised by the fact that the annual returns are ploughed back in. One cannot spend them until the investment matures. The Australian Taxation Office realises that this annual growth factor is not income, but the Department of Social Security wants to treat it as income in assessing the age pension. In a magnanimous gesture, the Minister exempted those involved in market-linked investments prior to 9 September 1988 `to overcome', he said, `the retrospective nature of the legislation'. What about the bloke who retired last Friday or the lady who will finish up at the end of the month? The plans of their lifetime have just gone up in smoke at the eleventh hour. How will these people protect their super lump sums from the ravages of inflation? To make it perfectly clear who is hit by this--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. I think the honourable member did not listen to his shadow spokesman who said that essentially the treatment of capital growth had been there for eight years. It was introduced by a Liberal Government.
—Order! That is a debating point. There is no point of order. The Minister will resume his seat.

—A man or woman retiring with less than $20,000-to cite an example-will lose entitlement to a pensioner benefit card. Gone is the entitlement to travel on the bus for 20c a ride-he or she must pay full fare. He or she must pay the gap on all medical expenses and lose free dental cover, optometry rebates, concessions on council rates, water rates, electricity charges and Telecom bills. That is worth between $20 and $50 per week. It is quite a bit to someone on $120 per week. To top it off he or she gets no consideration for the erosion of capital due to inflation, inflation that has been largely created by the Government in the first place. It is not the high rollers at the top of the tree who are hit by the new legislation. As usual with the Hawke Labor Government, it is the little people who are clouted as the Government takes a swipe at the big fish. At least that is what it always claims to be doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The people who will be hurt by this legislation are those at the bottom of the income scale. Many people will be forced to put their capital in an interest free account, such as a cheque account. This matter has been debated before. Over time, as pensioners use up their capital in order to make up for a smaller pension, the investment income will decrease and thus their pension entitlement will increase. Rather than make Australians less reliant on pensions to fund their retirement, the Government is actually making people more reliant on pensions. The Government is discouraging people to seek financial independence; the very thing Australians should be striving for. As the baby boomers move through middle age and begin the leg to retirement, everyone will have to provide for a pensionless retirement.

The Oxley by-election landslide is another episode in the Hawke Labor Government's refusal to acknowledge the electorate. We beat Labor in Adelaide and, as the member for Adelaide, I can tell the House that the conversation in the front bars of the working men's pubs, not on the north shore or in the electorate of Dobell, but up and down Main North Road, is about superannuation and the pension. The main cause for concern on the doorsteps from Ingle Farm to Klemzig is superannuation and the pension. This social security legislation, tucked away in the Appropriation Bills will blow up in the Hawke Government's face-and so it should. I say to the Government: hands off the livelihoods of our parents. Stop hitting the pensioners who have spent their lives building and defending this country. How about a fair go for the elderly?
