SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears from the comments made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) that the Opposition is pursuing its campaign of targeting pensioners to try to score political points around this country. It is a pity it did not start telling people some of the facts, the truth. I am glad that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) interjected by way of a point of order to explain the truth in relation to the allegations made previously. It is almost shades of Peter Sawyer, with Sawyer running around saying that the Government will take away pensions and introduce some sort of voucher system. Honourable members opposite repeatedly create confusion and misunderstanding, and a false perception of what the Government is doing. Clearly the Government has listened to the desires and demands of people. It has acted on those needs, obviously in line with restraint and equity. In these economic circumstances that is a must.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make some comparisons and explain what is happening to the lot of the pensioner. It will never be perfect, but this Government is conscious of those who are on lower incomes and those who are disadvantaged in our community, particularly from a purchasing power point of view. Prior to 1983 the tax free threshold for pensioners was $5,428. It is now $6,892-a massive increase of over $1,500. The provisional tax threshold at that time was $1,000. So a pensioner who earned $1 more than $1,000 over and above the pension paid provisional tax. That allowable income-the pension, interest and dividends, the lot-has been increased to $10,332. It means, for instance, that a married pensioner can now earn another $5,000 from interest and dividends and not be faced with paying provisional tax. Who introduced this measure? It was the Labor Government on the initiative of the Minister for Social Security who is sitting at the table. The tax-free rebate was $250. In other words, a person could earn at that time around $1,000 without paying tax. That pensioner can now earn over $1,700 because the rebate jumped to $430. The allowable income of $30 has increased to $40 for a single person; for a married person it was $50 and it has gone to $70. The single pension in 1983 was $77.25; it is now $120.05. The pension for each of a married couple at that time was $64.40; it is now $100.05.

To give honourable members an example of the purchasing power of people in 1983, pensioners on $10,000 paid $1,371.50 in tax. Five years later the tax payable on the same amount has dropped almost $250 to $1,134. Rent assistance was $10. It will increase in July to $20. In 1983 the pension amounted to 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings; today it is almost 25 per cent. The average payment to the aged in 1983 across the board-that is over 1.3 million pensioners-was $3,435 per person; today it is $5,478. There is a real increase over inflation. Pensions have been increased by the inflation rate plus another 8.2 per cent. A married couple now can receive a part pension until their income is 97.2 per cent of average weekly earnings. Yet we have members of the Opposition saying that we are doing nothing.

Of course there will be some problems, but we are trying to address the economic resources of this country firstly to those who are in need. That has been proved by the Minister's own initiative. He announced in the recent Budget that the 12 weeks bereavement payment is now tax free. Previously, it was possible for a person to receive 12 weeks payment if a spouse died and at the end of the financial year to be suddenly hit with a tax burden because that payment had to be included as income. Because of requests made by me and other members to the Minister, and on his own initiative, the Minister announced in the Budget that bereavement payment was to be tax free. It can now be obtained in one lump sum to meet funeral costs. That is something the Opposition never thought of; it was never even considered. The bereavement payment was lumped in as income and taxed. A pensioner could receive an extra $1100 and pay tax of about $330, and nothing was done about it.

There is a need for change; I accept that. There is a need for allowable earnings to be tax free. If I have any criticism of the system, it is that there does not seem to be coordination between the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security. That is certainly not the fault of the Minister for Social Security or of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). However, we need to work together and ensure that if a pensioner can earn $40 a week, or a married couple can earn $70 a week, that ought not to be taxed. There is confusion, which, unfortunately, Opposition members grab hold of and spread, creating trauma for many aged people.

There is also a need to index the tax rebate. We addressed that need in the Budget by increasing the tax rebate from $250 to $430, but because it was not indexed there was an erosion. A person could earn up to $6,142 without paying tax but as a single pensioner he was getting $5,900 anyway in his pension, which gave him barely $200 a year to earn because of the tax rebate-a matter of a few dollars a week. There has to be a reconsideration of this position. I hope that there will be, as a result of the representations that have been made to government. We have to do it that way. I hope we take an apolitical position on this. Pensioners should not be political targets. We ought to show them special respect and, regardless of our political persuasion, we should help them en masse. If we take into account the veterans, we are talking about two million people out of a population of 16 million. At the moment there is a pensioner for every five people in the work force, but by the year 2025 there will be a pensioner for every two people in the work force. There will be many more pensioners who will need to be considered. So, as I said, there is a need to review this position on an apolitical basis.

There are also concerns about the assets test. I have directed this matter to the Government and I hope that we can take it up further. We have an assets test in place, which is necessary, because we do not want a person who owns $1m-worth of land getting a pension if that land could be sold, creating an income for that person. I know that is the position of some honourable members opposite. Assets valuation was set in the last two years. The Taxation Office is now revaluing those assets. Only recently, certain land which in the last 12 months was said to be worth $90,000, suddenly became worth $146,000 and there were no sales in the area. I do not know how it happens. I have asked the taxation valuers to sort it out for review. But that takes time and it causes stress, because immediately the Department of Social Security acts on a valuation there is a diminution of the pension received. The person does not have another source of income. He has a piece of land which he has not sold-in some cases he cannot sell it-and he is caught with a lower income. That means less purchasing power and a reduced quality of life. We need to review the position.

This brings me back to my point that we need coordination. We should not have one department, be it the Taxation Office or the Department of Social Security, running out on one tangent and the other department doing something else. That is certainly true when it comes to the allowable income earned and valuing the assets of pensioners. I would like to see some independent assessment made, because there is constant confusion over the income test and how it applies as against the assets test. Our responsibility ought to be aimed at the quality of life of these people, people who have worked hard for this country, who have pioneered it. I believe that they deserve something better than the confusion and trauma that has been created by the likes of Peter Sawyer and, regrettably, a minority of Opposition members-sometimes because of sheer ignorance, because people just do not know.

I have noted with some pleasure the Minister's willingness to try to improve pensioners' knowledge of their rights and the delivery of Commonwealth services in country areas. The Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security have combined in many areas; my own township of Biloela was used as a pilot scheme. We need to ensure that people know their rights. We also need certainty, consistency, stability and simplicity in the laws and rules that people have to adhere to.

I make one final point as my time disappears. Let us get rid of the anomaly that exists whereby senior citizens organisations can get a sales tax exemption but pensioners leagues cannot. Again this demonstrates the confusion and inconsistency that exists and the lack of cooperation and coordination between the two departments. In all, this Government is working to achieve equity and improve quality of life for the aged. However, we must ensure that we remove the anomalies which, unfortunately, exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who has just resumed his seat, talked about the confusion facing many pensioners. What he has failed to acknowledge is that the confusion, concern and worry that confront many pensioners have been directly caused by the Government he supports. He talked about the low level of income at which a pensioner first faces an income tax liability. Who caused that? It was the Labor Government, by failing to index the tax threshold, not only for pensioners but for all taxpayers. That has meant that since the Labor Party has been in office the tax-free area between the pension income and the tax threshold has narrowed continually. It has been alleviated only by ad hoc adjustments to the age pension tax rebate. As the honourable member for Capricornia pointed out, that still leaves only a relatively small amount of income that a pensioner can have before he faces an income tax liability.

SPEECH.PARA: What does that mean? It means that many pensioners must put in tax returns. They have to define their income, which means more confusion, because one month pensioners receive from the Department of Social Security a statement requiring them to disclose the income received. That is easy, one might think. But this Government has introduced a very complex definition of income for pension purposes and a different, and equally complex, definition of income for income tax purposes.

I support the honourable member for Capricornia when he says that the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security should get together. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) should get together. They need their heads banged together so that they will try to simplify and clarify the income test and the income tax test in a way that makes the definition uniform for both systems.

Earlier in this debate reference was made to changes in respect of managed investments. The Government has only recently, in the May statement, further complicated the whole process by defining as income for income test purposes receipts which, under the income tax legislation, are regarded as capital. For example, a pensioner selling an asset for a price higher than the price at which that asset was purchased is liable to bring in the nominal capital gain as income for income test purposes, not the real capital gain as is the case with the capital gains tax.

Is the Minister able to assure the House as to the position of a pensioner's residence? As I understand it, according to the department, a pensioner's residence is a domestic asset. Therefore, if a pensioner sells a house and buys another, but in the process makes a capital gain on the house sold, the capital gain is not income for income test purposes. I hope that the Minister can assure me that that is the case. I would have thought that a domestic asset was more like the furniture, the pots and pans, the garden utensils and implements. The Minister may be able to reassure me. Nevertheless, if the pensioner is selling a modest beach house because that person has reached an age when he or she cannot travel to the coast and a capital gain is made, that capital gain is brought into account as income for income test purposes-not the real capital gain but rather the nominal capital gain. For how long is that income brought into account and over what period? One has to go through a maze of complex administrative instructions to discover whether the gain is averaged over a year or brought into account in the week in which the capital gain is received. It is not clear. It is different from assessment for income tax purposes.

The honourable member for Capricornia has a huge job on his hands in trying to persuade this Minister for Social Security and the Treasurer to get their act together so that there is a common definition for income under both systems. The pension system is really the reverse side of the coin from the tax system. Most age pensioners have formerly been taxpayers and they, properly in my view, believe that as they have been taxpayers they have earned the right to the pension that they receive. Having earned that right, being entitled to that pension but subject to an income test and subject to an income tax test, surely it should be made simple for them. They should be told what is income. The same definition should be used in both systems.

These people should be told that, instead of having to notify the Department of Social Security within 14 days of an adjustment of income, they have 12 months in which to give that notification, provided the income variation is not substantial. That is done under the tax system. There, one pays provisional tax if one has a high level of interest or similar income and if the income varies, one's provisional tax can be varied. Why should not the same system apply to age pensioners? I would apply it to more than age pensioners.

A few weeks ago the Minister gave a response to a question in the House and tried to justify this intrusive fortnightly review of pensioners' incomes. He said that a pensioner has to be given income in a particular week because he has no other income, therefore he must be assessed in that week. Most age pensioners are living in predictable income circumstances and for the life of me I cannot understand why we do not tell people who reach pension age to put in a return once a year just as they put in their tax return before they retired. If the Government underpays a pensioner because it has thought the pensioner would receive a higher income than was actually received, the Government should make an excess payment to bring the pension payment up to the entitlement. The Commissioner of Taxation does that for people who overpay their tax through the pay as you earn system.

If, on the other hand, a pensioner-who by definition is a part-pensioner, because it involves only those who have their pensions adjusted because of other income or assets-receives a higher level of non-personal income than would entitle that person to the rate of pension actually received, why could not that pensioner then be sent a debit account to pay back the overpayment of pension? Perhaps an instalment could be deducted fortnightly for a certain period of time until the overpayment had been recovered. If there is a fear that these pensioners will die or run away overseas to spend the investments from which they are getting the interest, upper limits could be placed on the amount so that if a pensioner receives $500 or $1,000 more than his previously declared income, an appropriate notification must be made to the Department.

The illustrations I have given make it clear that there needs to be much closer integration of the function of the Department of Social Security and the Taxation Office in the area of the definition of income, in the requirements of each of the departments and the Taxation Office imposed on pensioners in respect of the times and places they must fill in forms setting out their incomes and assets. Surely in the area of assets there should be a similar definition for income derived from assets as in the case of the capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise two items in discussing these appropriations for the Department of Social Security. The first is once again the matter of earning limits for the widows pension. I have made a habit of raising this matter every time these appropriations are discussed. The Government has set up a new jobs, employment and training program to help work force re-entry for widows and sole parents. There is no doubt that this program will fill a gap, and I commend the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for that. I know that the Minister has at times a compassionate heart; albeit that those times are too rare, they do occur from time to time. The area of widows' earning limits needs to be thought about very carefully. The greatest barrier to gradual work force re-entry of widows and single mothers, combining work with parenthood while receiving adequate income and work experience, is the current cut-off point for benefits once a woman starts to earn an income.

SPEECH.PARA: Every day when we come in here Madam Speaker says a prayer seeking guidance. I know the Minister is very well aware of the scriptural injunction that we take special care of widows, and they do get some pre-eminence in the care that we as people, as governments, exercise. It is important to say that because that responsibility does not stop when we come in the front door of this place; it becomes a great reality when we legislate here for our fellow humans. I urge the Minister to look not at some marginal lift in the wage benefit cut-off point but at a significant boost to the amount a widow can earn before she loses benefits. At present she can earn $40 and I believe one of the serious deficiencies in this system is that widows, who have great family responsibilities, and many of whom are very young, are being forced out into the cash economy. In fact, this is forcing them into engaging in criminal activities. If they earn cash in excess of that $40 that is not accountable they are engaging in a criminal activity. We must look hard at this concept of raising the threshold, particularly for widows, for the earnings they can receive before their pensions are reduced or removed.

The second matter I raise concerns the need to ensure that increased disposable income for low and average income families is achieved through less taxation rather than greater dependence on government benefits. One of the classic works of liberalism is the book The Servile State. I am sure the Minister, who is widely read in these matters, will have read it. It warns against the development of a society characterised by utter dependence on the state for income security-a fairly serious warning. There is no doubt that our welfare system needs the mechanisms of redistribution and targeting for a good many people who are unable to care for themselves or their families in times of difficulties. We know that. Nevertheless, I must say that I find it dangerous that real improvements in disposable income have come to many working families from welfare payments when they could have and should have been achieved by tax cuts.

Getting a person a job and then letting him keep his earnings, rewarding self-reliance, minimising reliance on the state-these should be the key social objectives. It is neither good for the individual nor prudent politically constantly to increase the level of reliance on the state for income security. I point out that real improvements in disposable income and living standards should come as far as possible-I know it cannot be done in every instance-from tax cuts. That is, increased disposable income can and must come from the state getting off the worker's back as far as possible. There is a lot of room for this to be done in this portfolio.

I raise the question, therefore, of whether the Government can review its social justice strategy with a view to giving welfare payments less of a role in future growth in disposable income for low and average income earners. It is better for self-esteem if a person is able to live off the income that he or she receives with reduced taxation rather than to have a taxed income and have it supplemented by benefits from taxation. I suggest that the Government shift the balance of tax to tax cuts, which produce independence as well as improved living standards. I urge the Minister for Social Security to consider these very brief points. I am sure he will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank the contributors to the debate and make just a few comments on various issues that were raised in the course of the debate. I was somewhat surprised that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) raised the question of the Greypower meeting in Sydney and my non-attendance at that meeting. I suggest with some care and sensitivity to the honourable member, whom I respect, that he do a little research before he attends another meeting which is chaired by Robert Clarke. I do not make any imputations about the character of this individual, but I think it is important that Opposition members, when they attend meetings, are careful who they associate with. In particular, I suggest that the honourable member might like to consult page 99 of Mr Grassby's book The Morning After, where he refers to some of the previous activities of the said Robert Clarke.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues have been raised in the debate. On the question of market linked investments, I am very interested in the Opposition's position on this, although it has not been altogether clear what it is on about. It is certainly not clear that it has held a consistent position. The honourable member for Bradfield has referred constantly to the fact that the treatment of capital growth as part of market linked investments has taken account of income at the point of maturity of those investments since 1980. That is, those rules were introduced by a conservative government. In the years between 1980 and 1983 I am sure there was no suggestion made by the Government of that time that some account should be taken of inflation. It took no initiative.

We now have a position where, as part of a scare campaign generated by some people in New South Wales, the Opposition has jumped onto the bandwagon and has not referred to the fact that all the Government has done has been to move the treatment of this capital growth factor to an accrual basis rather than at the point of realisation. In principle, the Opposition introduced the treatment of those market linked investments and capital growth funds in a way that took account of that capital growth disregarding inflation. We get a lot of nonsense, if I might say so, spoken in this Parliament and I think we have had some nonsense spoken in relation to this issue for what could be regarded only as extremely opportunistic reasons.

With respect to other contributions on the issue of the aged population, the Government is very concerned to achieve a retirement income policy not only for the next few years but to serve us well into the early years of the next century. As part of the social security review we have had Professor Cass looking at the issue of retirement incomes and she is about to publish her issues paper No. 6 around that theme. The Government has made a number of changes with respect to occupational superannuation, making it much more available to the work force than it has ever been before. We have also made a number of changes to provide incentives for people to preserve money invested in occupational superannuation for the purposes of providing a retirement income. In the next few weeks, as that paper is published, the Government will move to give consideration to making some time next year a major statement on the issue of retirement income policy.

We make no apologies for measures which were designed to ensure that our income-tested system operates in a fair way and indeed in a targeted way. The Government introduced an assets test, reintroduced a means test for the over 70s pension, and has moved to ensure that our system is targeted. That is necessary, given the very difficult fiscal climate in which the Government has operated. At the same time, as the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) pointed out, there have been very significant increases in the real incomes of age pensioners in this country-increases in the rate of the pension of 8.2 per cent real. We are now at 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings in the level of the pension. We have eased income tests in the free area from $30 to $40 and from $50 to $70 for married couples. We have moved to ensure that fringe benefit limits are indexed and indeed we have indexed the limits with respect to the age pension.

We cannot look at the Government's policy with respect to the aged only in terms of what it has done in income security. The Government has also sought to put in place far-reaching restructuring of nursing home and hostel accommodation for the aged. That is designed to support our policy of ensuring that aged people are able to remain as active as possible. The home and community care program is a visionary program which will certainly support the aim of helping people to remain within their own homes and within their local community for as long as possible.

Within the tight fiscal framework in which we operate we have needed to give emphasis to targeting, but we have sought to achieve some real increases in disposable incomes of age pensioners. We will in the next few months set out our objectives in long term retirement income policy. There will be ample opportunity for debate within the community. My hope is that we can get a consensus within the community with regard to the directions of retirement income policy. The issue is too serious for people to be subject to changes every time there happens to be a change of government. They need to know what the ground rules are.

What we are talking about is an increase in the proportion of the aged population-those aged over 65-from about 10 per cent currently to about 16 per cent in 2011. So in the next 20 years we need a farsighted retirement income policy that has broad support within the community-amongst the aged themselves, political parties, industry and those who represent aged people. I will certainly be working very hard to achieve the basis of that policy. I am sure that the paper by Bettina Cass will be an extremely helpful resource to the community as well as to the Parliament in considering these issues. That, together with a number of background papers, will represent a very substantial resource in terms of documenting what we know about the ageing of the Australian population and issues that are relevant to that.

I will not take up much more time. A number of other contributions have been made-for example, by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who indicated some concerns about the changes in relation to the income test on maintenance, particularly in regard to aged people. I am currently looking at that issue. I cannot make an immediate response, but we are trying to deal with the kind of situation that he had in mind in that area. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and I are looking at the issue of investment advisers. We are not looking at that as a Government function, or as a function of the Department of Social Security, but we think it is important that there be access to objective advice for pensioners who often make quite difficult investment decisions. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) made a rather emotional speech. It was typical of the opportunism that one often sees reflected in Opposition comments. He ought to think through the issues a bit more. Perhaps he will have the opportunity to do that within the party room as the Opposition discusses its retirement income policy.

Finally, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) made a very strong plea for simplicity. Of course, that is a central issue that will be looked at by the Government in its response to the retirement income paper by Professor Cass. It is one for which I have some sympathy, although I think that the notion that somehow one can take the treatment of income by the taxation system and proceed with a similar definition in the social security system is a little more complex than the honourable member suggested. In terms of social security, we are very much concerned with the immediate availability of funds and access to those funds. That is not quite the same issue in relation to the equity concerns of taxation. The point that we ought to have simpler interaction between the tax and social security systems is well taken and one to which I will give further consideration. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Administrative Services
Proposed expenditure, $1,362,935,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I thank you for facilitating the opportunity for me to be able to participate in this debate. I therefore commend you for your chairmanship. As I am talking about the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services, I am pleased to see that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) is present, accompanied by, I am sure, his very able officers. I take the opportunity of canvassing particular aspects of the expenditure of the Department of Administrative Services. In doing so, I note that the amounts of money involved are very large. I lament, in a sense, that the procedures of this place, unlike those of the Senate, do not necessarily permit a detailed examination of Estimates and, therefore, a useful dialogue on some of the issues that might be raised. It is very much a question of a contribution by me in relation to the issue that I intend to press, and a response by the Minister. It may well be that a dialogue would produce much more valuable information than might be elicited by the technique that currently exists. I think it is a matter that we will have to examine in the future. As I understand it, increasingly, as we have procedures for ensuring efficient operation of departments, with performance monitoring against objectives, the question of whether the task of examining Estimates is effective will decide whether this Parliament provides any useful input into the way in which departments operate.

SPEECH.PARA: The area that I intend to address relates to the function of the Australian property services. The amounts of money involved are large. If one looks at the appropriation for rent for office and other accommodation for departments, the extimate of expenditure for this year is $397,000,000. With other services, involving equally large sums, the amount involved is $459,250,000. When overseas property services are added, the amounts of money involved become larger. Division 119 relates to the fitting out of leased premises by the Commonwealth, which involves another $80m this year. These are very large sums of money. Those large sums of money could well involve very considerable losses of Commonwealth money. There could well be expenditure patterns which are less than efficient. It could well be that there are serious matters relating to the administration, not necessarily of the Department of Administrative Services, but of other departments, and the way in which money is spent.

The particular concerns I have are in relation to the fitting out of leased premises by the Department of Administrative Services. They relate to the Commonwealth's involvement in the supervision and fitting out of the Commonwealth Centre in Parramatta, which is close to my constituency. Honourable members would know that the building erected at Parramatta which is presently being fitted out is one which has been erected on a lease-purchase arrangement. It is a new arrangement for the Commonwealth. The building is very large and it is one that is to be occupied eventually, as I understand it, by the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Administrative Services, and some aspects of the Australian Taxation Office. So it is a very large operation involving the coordination of the occupation of that building in the fitting out stage of many other government departments.

As I understand it, in fitting out this building there was an effort to install a telephone system which was to be the largest of its type. We are all familiar with these PABX arrangements for large buildings. The telephone service was to be the optimum type, known as an NEC 240 UMG, and that was to have all of the departments connected to it. It was to have links to other systems outside of the building itself. It was designed with the most sophisticated equipment for safeguarding its use by users of the building. The expenditure involved in the purchase of that equipment was about $3m.

As I understand it-the Minister might like to confirm this when he responds to me-the design phase involved the Department of Administrative Services coordinating with other departments to ensure that their needs were met. I assume that that is what they did. The Minister might like to give me certain assurances in relation to the way in which those negotiations were undertaken, the discussions that took place and the result of them, because-and the Minister might care to confirm this or otherwise-after the decision to purchase the equipment had been taken-that is, $3m of public money committed to the PABX system for building-wide use to satisfy the needs of all the client departments, and that done in consultation with them-I understand one of those departments, the Tax Office, decided that that system no longer met its needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is extraordinary.

—I ask for the Minister's confirmation-and that is why I say I am not satisfied that these procedures are altogether adequate for eliciting information-that the Tax Office now has decided to install its own PABX, an NEC 240 MMG system.
—How much is that going to cost?

—I do not know the amounts involved. The Minister may be able to help us with that answer, but it could well be in the order of additional millions of dollars. It is a smaller system and not quite as advanced, but apparently the Tax Office has some views that the security arrangements for the original system were not satisfactory for its purposes. It wanted to have a unique system, presumably for privacy reasons. If I thought those privacy reasons were appropriate, I am sure they would have been appropriate when the original discussions were entertained. I do not think they would suddenly emerge at a later point in time. But apparently they were seen to be of sufficient importance that the Department of Administrative Services was borne upon at the highest of levels to cooperate with these new arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is the case, I think it is appropriate that the House be informed. As I have mentioned, the installation of a separate telephone system means that much of the equipment, cabling and hardware involved in the original PABX system is now redundant. The system will have considerable surplus capacity. I am sure the Minister's Department would seek to deal with this matter properly and perhaps sell off some of the equipment. I am informed that there is not a ready market for subselling advanced equipment of a part of a system, but no doubt they are trying to minimise the losses that are involved.

However, regrettably, at the point at which this decision had to be reworked, I am told-and the Minister could perhaps inform us better on this matter-that it was not possible then to review the contracts; it was not possible to renegotiate them. I am also informed that there may well be considerable other losses involved, losses in terms of the decision-making time of the departmental officers involved in producing the original design arrangements and undertaking the consultations, the redesigning of the equipment, as well as the direct equipment costs. This is all in addition to the Tax Office having itself designed and installed a separate system of its own.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak at this stage of the debate. We are dealing with the Department of Administrative Services and, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said, it is quite a significant amount of money-about $1.7 billion. Although that seems a lot of money, the Department of Administrative Services draws its functions now from nine portfolios of the previous Administration. The main ones of these are Housing and Construction, Local Government and Administrative Services, and Special Minister of State.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with interest to what the honourable member for Dundas said, and I suppose it is a debatable point whether we should have a more effective scrutiny system, such as that which exists in the other House. I am not familiar with the telephone system in the building at Parramatta, but a lot of this work that comes under the Department goes to scrutiny in other forms. Also, of course, the Public Works Committee scrutinises all these works.

The broad range of the operations of the Administrative Services portfolio is emphasised by the allocations made in the 1988-89 Budget. In each aspect of its work, the portfolio fulfils roles vital to Australia's future. The portfolio is a provider of common services to other departments and agencies, a provider of specialised technical services, and manager of the Commonwealth estate and capital works program. The Budget allocation reflects the importance of the Department.

One important aspect, of course, is the management of government records. The objective of this program, administered under the Archives Act, is to ensure that the body of records generated by Commonwealth agencies from Federation to present day is managed efficiently and consistently in order to promote administrative economy and efficiency and to satisfy the needs, rights or interests of agencies and the public. During 1988-89 the Archives expect to achieve through enhanced automatic data processing operations more efficient access to a range of essential information relating to the internal management of records in custody and its dealings with agencies and the public, and this will cost about $400,000.

The Archives expect to acquire further repository facilities in Canberra. The facility in Hobart has recently been handed over. It is a building especially designed to meet the requirements there. There is also the Melbourne office. Worthwhile savings will be achieved through the vacation of leased premises in Canberra. In addition, other leased premises in Melbourne will replace substandard accommodation for staff and public users at Brighton.

It is a matter of personal regret to me, and a matter I have brought up with the Minister, that the Government has not made a decision to proceed with a national archive building. I urge the Government to give consideration to this matter. I believe that a prestigious building should be constructed on the site already allocated in the Parliamentary Triangle. This site is adjacent to the National Library of Australia and the just-opened splendid National Science Centre, and, together, all three would complement each other as great access to information and information retrieval centres.

Another important aspect of this portfolio is the Overseas Property Group. We see that major new projects will commence in 1988-89, including the construction of a new chancellery, 43 apartments and associated recreational facilities in Tokyo; construction of two houses on a residence site in Washington; development of a new residential site in Washington; development of new residential accommodation in Port Moresby; conversion of leased residences to chancellery and Head of Mission residence and other residential accommodation and recreational facilities in Hanoi; and the extension of the chancellery building in New Delhi, which I believe is very important. Anyone who has visited our mission in New Delhi will agree that we have to do something about it. Also included in the projects are residences in the Solomon Islands. I note that there have been delays in the construction of our embassy building in Beijing. I know that the Minister is concerned about this and has recently moved to speed up the process but there is concern that there have been considerable delays in the building of that new embassy. That embassy should come on stream as quickly as possible.

Another part of the portfolio deals with this very building, the new Parliament House. As we know, the Parliament House Construction Authority was established in 1979 to undertake the design and construction of the new Parliament House. Now that we have moved into this building we find there is an allocation of $82m for further work on it. Although I am very pleased to be in this new building, I must point out that there are some deficiencies in it. I hope that these problems will soon be ironed out and will result in the better working of this building. A lot of people in my area talk about this building as a new Taj Mahal for the politicians and make other extravagant claims about it. I have always argued that, although it is very nice that we politicians at last have decent office accommodation so that we can do our work, this building is for all Australians. It is one in which all Australians can take pride. It is very important that the building be able to work to its full capacity.

I return to the comments made by the honourable member for Dundas about the scrutiny of aspects of this portfolio. I am very involved in one area of this portfolio, the Public Works Committee. The Committee has frequent contact with the Australian Property Group and the Australian Construction Services. The Public Works Committee Act is now administered by the Department of Administrative Services. Under this Act the Government is involved in a wide range of works and these works come before the Public Works Committee to receive the scrutiny that the honourable member for Dundas was talking about. Recently we looked at the new Commonwealth centres in Sydney and Melbourne. There has been a lot of defence work, such as the upgrading of facilities at HMAS Cerberus and the Holsworthy military police complex, new government offices at Logan City and work on the Derby Airport. All these important matters have come before the Public Works Committee and have received scrutiny. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), who is at the table, is always very helpful to the Committee, as indeed are the officers from the Australian Property Group and the Australian Construction Services. When they appear before the Committee they are always well briefed and helpful.

As has been said, we are dealing with a large amount of money when looking at the appropriations for the Department of Administrative Services. But when one looks at the range of areas covered by this Department one realises why this allocation is so large. We have the Australian Property Group, the Overseas Property Group, the Australian Construction Services, the Australian Archives, the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories, the Australian Protective Services, the Bureau of Meteorology, the Purchasing and Sales Group, the Parliament House Construction Authority, the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group, the Parliamentary Services and Information Group, the Australian Government Publishing Service, the Transport and Storage Group and the Australian Electoral Commission.

In conclusion, I wish to give the Government and this Department credit for establishing the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I believe that that inquiry has served a very useful purpose. Often it has not done Australia a lot of credit, but it was very necessary that the Government establish this inquiry which has received an allocation under this portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes before lunch I wish to address a few remarks to a matter falling within the portfolio of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West). This matter was touched upon in Question Time yesterday and it relates to Commonwealth purchasing procedures. I understood the Minister to say yesterday-and I understand it is the case, from general talk around the place-that there is a proposal to change the procedures followed by the Commonwealth in its purchasing policies and practices. There are regulations applying at the moment and they are subject to the general proposition that at least for large purchases there should be a general tendering procedure. With some blemishes on the side, that tendering procedure has basically stood the test of time. There is a proposal to make that procedure more flexible-I think that is the euphemism-but what that really means of course is that in some cases it will be done away with.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make two comments about that. The first is that the Government should think very carefully before it makes any substantial inroads into the current tendering system. Secondly, I have had occasion recently to look at a few Government purchasing activities which are conducted subject to the present tendering procedures and they have left me with some concern, to the extent that I think any weakening of the system would make that system even worse. In other words, if one looks at a matter which has gone through the tendering procedure and concludes that that was sloppy, did not give the taxpayer good value for his money and was subject to if not improprieties then certainly shortcomings in administration, for that reason alone one should think very carefully before abandoning a tried and tested tendering system.

Some of those matters which I have had occasion to look at have arisen at the international terminal building at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, and one of them relates to the concession or franchise which the Commonwealth allows to run shops at the airport. These are particularly valuable franchises and concessions-indeed, they are worth many millions of dollars. Recently I have been looking at the concession for the newsagency and gift shop at the airport. In this case the Commonwealth called for tenders, tenders remained open, but a very curious and interesting thing happened during the period for which tenders were open. The Trade Practices Commission drew to the attention of the Federal Airports Corporation that some provisions of its tender contract-the contract on which tenderers were tendering-were in fact in breach of the Trade Practices Act. That was a very serious matter. Here was the Trade Practices Commission saying to a Federal corporation, `Look, you have put out a draft contract on which companies are tendering, and some provisions of that draft contract are in breach of the Trade Practices Act'.

Honourable members may well ask: What happened then? The Federal Airports Corporation conducted an examination of the draft contract and particularly the clauses to which the Trade Practices Commission had drawn attention, and as a result of that examination it altered the terms of the contract after tenders had closed. Can honourable members believe that in any system of tendering a government corporation should, after tenders had closed, alter the terms of the draft contract?

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Howard having addressed a question to the Acting Treasurer-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order. It is not within the Minister's portfolio.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise the House what actions the Government has taken to ensure that, following the termination of the two airlines agreement in 1990, new entrant airlines will not be prevented from entering the industry through lack of access to airline terminals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As members of the House would know, this Government has moved to bring to an end the two airlines agreement which, as notice was given in October last year, will come to an end in October 1990. That will end almost four decades of very substantial regulation of a major industry in this country and introduce a new era in which there will be the possibility of new entrants to the domestic airline industry in a way which, of course, has not been possible under the highly regulated two airlines agreement. The Government has been concerned not only to ensure that we are providing for the new entrants by way of ending the two-airline agreement but also to make that practically possible by taking substantive action to ensure that there will be access to terminals for new entrants. To do that we have renegotiated leases which had been negotiated under the Fraser Government and which locked up the terminals in most of our major airports until as late as 1993.

ANSWER.PARA: Those renegotiations have meant that, following the ending of the two airlines agreement in October 1990, each of the two airlines will be required to make available gateway access and passenger baggage handling facilities and associated facilities at each of the airports. In Sydney and Melbourne they will be required to provide two gates each and at smaller airports one gate each. This will mean that there is guaranteed access for new entrants via those facilities. There will also, of course, be capacity for the common user facilities which already exist in the new Brisbane Airport. At Hobart there is space available for common user facilities. So we do not need to have that requirement apply in those two airports. It will also mean that if any new entrant wishes to build its own terminal it can get the approval of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) to have that terminal constructed if the proposal is appropriate. The FAC is presently advertising for expressions of interest from various possible new entrants to see what the requirements might be and whether there would be a need for new terminals to be constructed.

The situation in short is that we are moving towards a new era in which this most important industry is being deregulated. The practical steps have been taken to ensure that there will be access for new entrants and that after October 1990 a new era of greatly increased competition in the airline industry will come into being.
