DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith the following motion of censure:
That this House censures the Acting Treasurer for his failure to explain to the House the reasons for his calling on the Prime Minister to consider resigning.

It is perfectly obvious that when an allegation has been made in a newspaper of repute in this country the forms of the House are available to a Minister to put the record straight. I remind the House that there appeared in the Australian newspaper this morning under the by-line of Paul Kelly an article entitled `Why Dawkins and Hawke have split'. That article was based upon a report of a conversation between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). It was a conversation which, according to the correspondent Mr Kelly, contained in substance a request from the Acting Treasurer to the Prime Minister that the Prime Minister consider resigning. In any other circumstance, with any other government, with any other Minister, and in any other situation, that Minister would have taken advantage of the opportunities that are clearly available in order to deny the accuracy of that report. Did the Acting Treasurer tell the media that that report was wrong? Did the Acting Treasurer come into the Parliament this morning when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition moved for a suspension of Standing Orders? Did he respond to the Deputy Leader's motion? Of course he did not. Like the political coward that he is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should withdraw that comment.
—What comment?
—The comment you made about the Acting Treasurer.
—I will withdraw it, and there are a few more to come.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kerin I just rise to indicate that the Government is prepared to debate the censure motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative, by an absolute majority.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Acting Treasurer for his failure to explain to the House the reasons for his calling on the Prime Minister to consider resigning.

This is no joking matter. It is not a trivial proposition. It goes to the very heart and stability of this Government. It goes to the veracity of the economic management of this Government at a time when average Australian families are suffering an unprecedented decline in their living standards. It may well be that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Ministers of this Government treat the proprieties of the Westminster system with contempt. It may be that this Prime Minister does not believe that this Parliament is entitled to an explanation of the relationship between himself and his Ministers. But I would say to the Prime Minister and his colleagues, as demonstrated by a number of political events in recent times-not least the devastating rejection of the Prime Minister and his policies as evidenced in the Oxley by-election last weekend-that the Australian people are becoming increasingly concerned about the arrogant, out of touch character of this Government. It stands without any question that this Parliament is owed an explanation as to what is going on in the upper levels of this Government.

Today the Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), has had three occasions on which to make it plain to this House that the substance of the article that appeared in the Australian newspaper today was incorrect. He could have come into the Parliament this morning and denied it. He could have responded to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), this morning, and, more importantly, Madam Speaker, he need not have hidden behind the ruling that you gave a few moments ago. It would have been perfectly open to the Acting Treasurer, if he really has an answer to the allegation contained in the Australian newspaper article, simply to have said a few moments ago, `No, do not worry about the Standing Orders. I will take that question. I will nail the article for the lie that it is. I will say to Mr Kelly that I did not tell him when I saw him a few days ago that I told Old Silver to stand down'. He could easily have done that. He could easily have said to this Parliament and, through this Parliament, to the Australian people, `No, I have every confidence in the Prime Minister. Like the Treasurer, I want the Prime Minister to go on and lead us to the next election'. He had the opportunity to do that. But no; he passed up that opportunity. On three occasions, the Acting Treasurer has had the opportunity to tell this Parliament that he has every confidence in the Prime Minister and on three occasions he has passed that opportunity over. In the absence of those denials we are left with the inescapable conclusion that the substance of this claim is correct.

Of course, as honourable members opposite and on this side of the Parliament do not need to be told, all is not well in the upper reaches of this Government. Everyone knows that Keating wants Hawke's job, that Dawkins wants Keating's job and that Simon Crean wants Keating's job. John Kerin hopes that he will get Keating's job and the drover's dog will settle for any good old trick that happens to be going around. That is the heart of the paralysis of the operation of this Government at present.

If it was only something that concerned the personal ambitions of a few people in the Australian Labor Party, if it only related to the soaring vanity of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and the ambitions of the Acting Treasurer, if it only related to the long term ambitions of the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, if it only related to the power aspirations in the trade union movement of the President of the New South Wales Labor Party, Mr MacBean, maybe it would not matter. We on this side of the House and the Australian people would be entitled to say to the Labor Party, `You go away and play your little ambitious games. You go away and play your political musical chairs. You go away and have your conversations on car telephones. You go away and excoriate each other. You go away and do all of that. We really do not care'. But there is a cost. The cost of the paralysis in the decision-making processes of this Government is a direct result of the rivalry and the power ambition that are going on between the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and, more recently, the Acting Treasurer. The Acting Treasurer is the self-appointed campaign manager, no less, of the Treasurer in the Treasurer's ambition to succeed the Prime Minister as the leader of the Labor Party.

What is the product in policy paralysis of this power rivalry that is going on within the upper reaches of the Government? We saw it very clearly, starkly and eloquently illustrated last week. We do not have one version of the Government's wages policy; we do not have two versions of the Government's wages policy; and we do not even have three versions of the Government's wages policy. Rather we have four versions of the Government's wages policy. First of all, we had the Prime Minister with sweaty palms running around in Ipswich trying to rustle up the traditional Labor vote in this most Labor of all Queensland provincial towns. Unbelievably, a Prime Minister of a Labor government went twice to Ipswich trying to beg and bribe the traditional voters of that Labor Party heartland in Queensland to vote for him.

What did the people get? They did not just get a promise of a tax cut. They did not just get a promise of a wage cut. They got a promise for both of them. When Bob went to Ipswich he said, `Do not worry. If you vote for me on Saturday your living standards will be restored. In 12 months' time, you will have the greatest tax cut in history. In 12 months' time, we will be giving you a huge wage increase as well. And, if you vote for good old Bob Hawke in the by-election on Saturday, all of your worries will be over and all of your problems will be solved'. That was message No. 1.

If one were a traditional Labor voter in Ipswich or one of those surrounding areas, one would have been entitled to say to oneself, `This is not bad. My living standards may have gone down by $56 a week over the last 5 1/2 years; I may be paying the highest mortgage rate ever; I may be paying the highest tax rate ever; I may find it hard to pay for my children's school excursions; and I may find that I now have to work 49 weeks a year to buy a new car rather than 33 weeks a year 5 1/2 years ago. But, despite all that, it is all going to be fixed if I vote for Bob on Saturday. He is going to fix it. He is going to give me a wage increase and he is also going to give me a tax cut. It is all going to come at once. All the effort of the last 5 1/2 years will be rewarded and I will get all that nice juicy living standard put back into my hip pocket'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new dawn.

—`That is the new dawn if I vote for Bob in the Ipswich by-election'. Unfortunately, that poor, befuddled, misled, traditional Labor voter in Oxley did not count on the Grim Reaper over there in the Big Apple. There he said, `Oh, no; you cannot have a wage increase and a tax cut. I cannot allow that to happen. I cannot allow Old Silver to dangle that sort of carrot because that might make him a bit popular. They might in fact vote for him'.
—Order! Would the honourable member please refer to members of the House by their correct titles.
—I will refer to Old Silver as the Prime Minister.
—Thank you.

—No doubt the Treasurer said, `I cannot really allow him to get away with that so I will bring him down to earth. I will bell the cat on the Prime Minister while he is in Oxley. I will really tell it as it is'. And he told it as he saw it. He said, `Oh, no; you might get a tax cut if you are a good boy but you will not get a wage increase that is any bigger than I can possibly stop it from being and, desirably, I will not let you have a wage increase at all. What I would really like to have is a zero wage increase'. So that is version No. 2.

SPEECH.PARA: But, of course, not to be outdone, we have good old Senator Walsh, who thought to himself, `I am thinking of resigning. I am thinking of giving the whole show away. So, I think I will bring both of them down to earth with a great big thud'. Senator Walsh went to Adelaide and expounded the extraordinary proposition-disputed incidentally by senior Treasury officials before Senate Estimates Committee C last night-that there has been no fall in Australian living standards over the last 5 1/2 years. Senator Walsh would have to be the only person in Australia who really believes that. Not only did he say that but he also said, `We may not be able to have a tax cut at all, let alone a wage cut'. To cap the whole matter off, we have Simon Crean coming along and saying that everything that has been said by the three of them is absolute nonsense and it is really a matter that has to be determined by the trade union movement after all.

We have the Prime Minister saying, `A tax cut and a wage cut'. We have the Treasurer saying, `A tax cut but no wage cut'. We have the Minister for Finance saying, `Neither a tax cut nor a wage increase because you do not really need it as your living standard has gone up instead of going down over the last 5 1/2 years'. Then, to top it all off, we have Simon Crean coming along and saying, `You are all completely wrong. The trade union movement is led by me. I want ultimately to be the Treasurer in a government led by Mr Keating. I, the trade union movement, will decide whether you get any of it at all'.

Is it any wonder that, faced with that total and utter confusion and that total and utter policy paralysis, the traditional Labor voters of Oxley, of Ipswich and the surrounding areas, voted in their thousands against the Hawke Government last Saturday? They voted in their thousands because they are fed up with their falling living standard. They are fed up with a government that congratulates itself on non-existent excellence. They are fed up with being led by a government composed of people who are doing nothing more than jockeying for positions of power and privilege in a government that is fast losing the support and the respect of the Australian people. The reason this is happening, more than anything else, is the appalling mistrust and rivalry that now exists between the senior members of the Hawke Government. It is one thing for people to have differences of policy and attitude on matters of substance and public policy, but it is entirely another matter for the senior Ministers of a government to so hate and mistrust each other as to have allowed things to develop as they have in recent weeks.

Everyone knows that, immediately after the Budget, the Prime Minister got a fit of pique. He thought that the Treasurer was getting too much credit for the economic policies of the Government and he decided to put him in his place by making some offhanded remarks, quite calculatedly, about how long he was going to stay around as Prime Minister. Then Senator Richardson ordered him to recant those words on a television program. It all seemed to be papered over, but a few days later the Treasurer was at it again. His minders were tramping around the press gallery giving one or two journalists a transcript of some remarks he made to a gathering of members of the left wing of the Labor Party. The genie was out of the bottle again.

As the Treasurer goes off, symbolically, to try to repay some of the huge debt that he has racked up in the 5 1/2 years that he has been Treasurer of this country, everyone in this Parliament knows that the Prime Minister's minders have been working overtime, dumping it on the Treasurer in every nook and cranny of the press gallery. Members of the Prime Minister's staff have been going around briefing the gallery about how if Keating thinks he can get Hawke's job in the next 12 months he has another think coming. All the while, the craven little office manager, the man who did such an outstanding job as Acting Treasurer in this Parliament a couple of weeks ago, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the self-appointed campaign manager, was tramping around the press gallery saying, `The Prime Minister ought to go. He has had his turn. He has had his 5 1/2 years. It is about time the Prime Minister stood down. It is about time that he made way for Paul, and it is about time that I became Treasurer of Australia'. Mr Kelly, a journalist with whom I do not always agree, is a journalist who I think has built a reputation for not normally writing on matters of straight fact without having got the substance of the story correct. Honourable members can bet anything they like that Mr Kelly and the Acting Treasurer had a very convivial dinner a few nights ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Monday night, to be exact.

—Monday night, it is alleged. Honourable members can probably imagine that as the night wore on Kelly said, `Come on, Joe, what did you really say to Old Silver?' As the time wore on and the story came out I imagine he would have told Old--
—Jellyback.

—Jellyback. The Acting Treasurer would have told the Prime Minister, `You have had your 5 1/2 years. You told the Treasurer as early as September 1984 that you were going to stand down at a particular time and he has never forgotten it. Why don't you honour the promise you made to the Treasurer? Why don't you stand down?' We can imagine how popular the Acting Treasurer was when he said that. We can imagine who was almost as happy as we were, watching the Acting Treasurer struggle with some basic economic questions a couple of weeks ago. I think the Prime Minister was just as amused as our side was at the total inability of the Acting Treasurer to handle any of those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the upper reaches of this Government we have a group of people who no longer trust each other, who spend far more time backgrounding against each other, backbiting each other, talking each other down, blackguarding each other to the press gallery through their minders than they do making rational decisions about the future of this country. As the correspondent Paul Kelly remarked this morning:
Nobody knows where the Hawke economic team is going from here. But the good old days are over. The super optimists who think everybody can kiss and make up are in a condition of super-delusion.

Perhaps a Hawke-Keating deal is still on, but that would leak and create a `lame duck' problem for Hawke at the next election. It seems far too risky. Perhaps Keating will go; maybe there will be another reshuffle. The one certainty is uncertainty.

I would add one other certainty to the certainty that was nominated by Mr Kelly. It is that the real sufferers are the average individuals and the average families of Australia. It is those people who, under this group of power hungry rivals, have seen their living standards over the last 5 1/2 years decline by $56 a week. No matter how the Government twists and turns and explains it, no matter how often the Treasurer goes overseas and showers himself with congratulations, no matter how often the Prime Minister parades before the business community of Australia, no matter how much the Government congratulates itself on what it is alleged to have done, the reality is that every time it is tested before the bar of opinion of ordinary Australians it loses and it loses very heavily. There is a very simple reason for that: average Australians and their families are clearly, demonstrably, by any measure, much worse off now than they were 5 1/2 years ago when this Government came to power. It does not really matter whether this Government is led by the present Prime Minister, by the Treasurer, by the Acting Treasurer, by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is sitting at the table, or by anybody else: the Australian people increasingly know that under any Labor government led by anybody in this Parliament their living standards, their hopes, their future and their aspirations will continue to go down the drain. They will go down the drain because the priorities of this Government are now out of touch with the aspirations and the realities of the predicament of Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has all been said before.

—The honourable member for Corio may well say that this has been said before. I can say that it will be said again and again over the next 18 months because the repetition of the truth about what has happened to the living standards of Australian families is the most relevant political issue on the agenda in Australia today. There is no issue more relevant than what this group of people has done to the living standards of Australians. The failure of the Acting Treasurer to explain himself properly, to express his confidence in the Prime Minister, to deny that he asked the Prime Minister to stand down, serves yet again to underline the bitterness and dissension within this Government between the Prime Minister and his senior Ministers. That, more than anything else, is producing the paralysis in policy, and the real victims of that are Australian families.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), the Acting Treasurer, has two choices: he can either resign, as he should now, or he should tell us why and in what way he told the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he, the Prime Minister, should resign. When the proceedings of the Parliament began this morning, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition came into this place and referred--
—And he did a very good job.

—And he did a very good job, as he so modestly says. He referred to an article in this morning's Australian by Paul Kelly, headed `Why Dawkins and Hawke have split'. This is a matter which has been before the Parliament since 10 a.m. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has not deigned to come in here and make a personal explanation.
—Why should he?

—Because he can confirm or deny this, he should do so. If it is not true, there are procedures available to the Minister-and to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), and to any member of the Government-to explain to the Parliament and to the people why he thinks the Prime Minister should stay. But, of course, he does not want the Prime Minister to stay. The genesis of this whole matter is one that surrounds the increasing dispute within the front bench and the power brokers of the Labor Party. It is affecting the Labor Party fundamentally. But for us in this Parliament and for the people of Australia, it is even more profound.

SPEECH.PARA: When we came into the chamber this morning we learnt that the Leader of the House, and Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), the Minister in this place representing the new Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade-the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy)-and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) were absent. Yesterday the Parliament resumed. We had been away for 12 days. We learnt then that not only was the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on his jaunt around the world and the former Foreign Minister, the Governor-General designate, on his jaunt around the world, but so, too, were the Deputy Prime Minister-the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). So in the course of two days, yesterday and today-we have been away for 12 days-nearly a quarter of the Ministry, half of the Cabinet, are away from the sittings in this place. The other Ministers might be sitting in the other place, but five senior Ministers are not present.

That is why this Government has lost touch. Its members are too busy out there enjoying the perks of office. We hear the Treasurer talking about the baton in his knapsack. Goodness me! He is out there rattling it and beating Old Silver around the head. I am sorry, he is beating the Prime Minister around the head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—It is really a case of heave-ho Silver, if I have ever seen one. Last Monday night was the genesis of this story. But it is not something new. We heard about `Keating Attacks Hawke's Manchu Court' at the beginning of 1986. We remember the nasty things the Treasurer said about the minders of the Prime Minister backgrounding journalists on Mr Hawke's trip to China, which led to reports that Mr Hawke was displeased with Mr Keating because of his controversial comments on the economy and that he was shouldering him aside.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that this has been going on for a while. Today is just a continuation of the same old saga, the bitterness and the anger that these two have towards each other. We were told this morning-and how right it was-that Paul Keating's campaign manager at long last fronted up. I am told that he is going to follow me in this debate. We are all looking forward to him telling us whether there is a campaign, whether he is the campaign manager and whether he went in and talked to the Prime Minister as Mr Kelly, I am sure reflecting the comments of last Monday night's Tang Dynasty discussion, suggested. Did he, when he was telling the Prime Minister that he ought to go, set down the schedule of who was going to take over and when he was going to take over? I think the Australian people have an interest in this matter.

Remember how sparse the Government front benches were when we came in to Question Time today? The Ministers are not bothered about coming into the chamber. They can be off attending an air show-important though it might be. What is wrong with the end of the week? Why cannot Ministers go on Friday?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is opening it.

—It would not be the first show that was not opened on the opening day. As far as the Deputy Prime Minister is concerned, surely, when the Treasurer is away, is it that important that the two most senior Ministers have to be away? After all, it is the Keating-Hawke Government. We have the Deputy Prime Minister and the Treasurer somewhere overseas. This shows yet again that the concern about living standards, about the directions of economic policy, is treated as a farce.

SPEECH.PARA: That is where this all began. In regard to the directions of economic policy, prior to the Oxley election we had the absolute farce of the man who is Acting Treasurer coming into the chamber at the beginning of the week and saying that interest rates were trending down. The rest of the week he bungled and fumbled his way along, question by question-he did not know, he thought he might know, he could not answer, he deferred his answer, he suggested something else. In the last sitting week we learnt that the Acting Treasurer really did not know anything about the management of the economy. Yet this is the man who apparently is the stage manager for the Treasurer and his aspirations to exercise that position of influence-Prime Minister of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Short John Silver.

—Short John Silver is right. Why is the Acting Treasurer not prepared to tell us what is happening and why he went along to tell the Prime Minister to resign? I will tell honourable members why it happened. The Prime Minister is a lame duck Prime Minister. The Treasurer has decided that it is now or never. There has been a succession of by-elections. There has been a magnificent New South Wales election. The Labor Party has, properly and justifiably, lost the confidence of the Australian people. The Treasurer has decided that it is time for him to try to take over from the Prime Minister, for if he does not do so now, then, come the next election, there will no longer be any chance for him to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Including the resignation of the former Foreign Minister, the Governor-General designate, 10 senior Ministers of the original Hawke Ministry have resigned-some from this chamber and some from the other place. In the early stages those Ministers tried to set what they thought was a responsible, alternative course for Australia. Now they have gone. We had men like Mick Young. We were all quite confident that in his bluff Irish way we would get a laugh or two. We knew that he should have gone years before. After all, it was about him that Mr Justice Hope made remarks on conduct that no one could condone. After each one of these Ministers left, the hopes of all those on the back benches--

TALK.START.PARA: —Punchy.
—Including even the hopes of my friend up the back there, who has a bit of verbal diarrhoea-were that one day they might get on the front bench.
—Oh, no!

—Piteous. The Government has lost its sense of direction. It certainly no longer has the capacity to act in unison. All those individuals are running off in their several directions. Above all, the people at the core are beginning to sense that they have to do something about it. We can see the cauldron bubbling. We saw how the Prime Minister is prepared to do anything to placate the man from whom he stole the leadership of the Labor Party. Now he is reluctant to let go.

SPEECH.PARA: The Acting Treasurer went along to the Prime Minister and said, `Look, Bob, we have to do something about this. We have just about had it. We think you have lost your sense of direction. You are up there; you have forgotten how ordinary people live and the costs that affect them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never milked a cow in you life.
—If the Minister had heard the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) yesterday, he would know that he addressed the issues that the Minister has forgotten about.
—You have milked a till, but not a cow.
—The Minister will cease interjecting.
—He is worried about living standards, about people who normally go into shopping centres-not like the Minister; he probably sends his driver-and what they have to pay for ordinary foodstuffs.
—Order! The Chair has asked the Minister to stop interjecting and expects him to assist the Chair in doing so.

—If the Minister had been here yesterday, he would have heard the honourable member for Riverina-Darling talk about the issues that affect the average Australian who is concerned about living standards. Sadly, honourable members opposite are above it all. They go and talk to their powerful friends. They say to the leaders of the union movement, `Do not worry about all that. We do not have to worry about ordinary Australians. We have this power game all sewn up'. We know, and the electors of Oxley, Adelaide, Port Adelaide and New South Wales know, that things are not quite like that.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Acting Treasurer went along to see the Prime Minister he was reflecting the genuine concern that a few honourable members opposite have about the directions of the Government. If honourable members think, `Oh, but that is all up in the high-minded game', let us turn to two other examples. What did Senator Walsh say? He was reflecting the view of many Australians when he said that the Government has to address concerns about productivity. He said that if last month's current account deficit was as bad as it was for the previous two months of this financial year, we will have to do something about cutting public sector Federal spending.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the only one in step.

—He is. Senator Walsh has drawn all the flourish from the crowd opposite. Senator Walsh has said to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, `Never mind all this eulogising to the electors of Oxley, never mind preaching to the International Monetary Fund or telling the Americans and the Europeans how to run their economies. What about coming back home and running ours?' Where has the Treasurer been? He was away all the last week we sat. He was away the 12 days when the House was in recess. He has been away all of this week and he will be away half of the next sitting week. Although he has paid off one small element of debt, at home the debts rise at twice the rate he is repaying them.

SPEECH.PARA: The economy is in the control and management of the man who has told the Prime Minister he must go. A Government cannot operate with all of its Ministers away. Members of the House know that the present Acting Treasurer is responsible for running the economy and he does not really know whether interest rates are rising or falling. Members of the Government cannot even answer questions about these things during the proceedings of the House. Today not only were all the Ministers absent but a new boy was Leader of the House. I wish him well. We heard this morning that he wants to be Treasurer in the new show. He will not do much of a job as Leader of the House. He did not know what to do or how to handle things. Members of the Government were at odds and evens.

This morning the Deputy Leader of the Opposition properly asked the Acting Treasurer to tell us why he and the Prime Minister had split, to tell us why he went in and told the Prime Minister that the Prime Minister should resign. Members of the Government do not even know how to handle the House, how to handle the Government. They certainly do not know how to handle the economy. It is just not good enough. It is about time the Australian Labor Party addressed the responsibilities it has as a government in this place.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) will never make it. He has had it. I know he is out there behind Long John Silver. What will he say to his friends at the table? Is he one of the guys in favour of telling the Prime Minister to go? Perhaps he ought to get up and tell us. There are a few others up there. I know all the boys on the Left want him to go. We have heard all about it. It says in this newspaper article by Paul Kelly that the Minister was telling the Prime Minister what he has already said face to face to others. He felt obliged to tell Hawke to his face what he was saying to others. Full marks for his honesty. Why can he not be honest with us?

SPEECH.PARA: That is what the censure motion is all about. The Acting Treasurer has a responsibility to this House to tell honourable members why he told the Prime Minister that he should resign. The Acting Treasurer has a responsibility to tell us just how and in what way the Prime Minister reacted to his request. The Acting Treasurer has a responsibility to tell us that he will cease acting on behalf of the Treasurer, that they are all a happy band of brothers again. If he tells us that, we will know what a farce it is.

The reality is that the Prime Minister is a lame duck Prime Minister. What the Acting Treasurer said is true. The Prime Minister ought to come into this House and tell honourable members when he is going because that is what this is all about. The Acting Treasurer knows the Prime Minister has to go and the public know the Prime Minister has to go. All we want to know is when he will go. The Acting Treasurer deserves to be censured and all honourable members will be interested in whether he has any explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Government rejects the motion. The reason is that there is simply no case to answer. The Opposition, in what must have been one of the most lacklustre performances in a debate on a censure motion, simply failed to make a case against me, to make a case against the Government, to make a case against anybody.

SPEECH.PARA: We are lectured constantly by the Opposition about the forms of the House. We have a constant string of points of order telling us how we should behave and conduct ourselves in this House and yet members of the Opposition use probably one of the most grave devices within the House, that of moving a censure motion against a Minister, with such flippancy and triviality as to expose their real view about this particular issue and their own contempt for the Parliament itself. Matters for censure should be grave and should be based on some evidence and some fact and not on some vague assertion.

What is the evidence that has been presented to us today? It is simply an article which appeared in today's Australian which quotes nobody, which has no authority in terms of the normal standards of evidence that one would expect; that is, people actually being quoted. This is an inadequate basis for launching a censure motion against anybody. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) told us yesterday, one should be careful not to believe everything one reads in the paper. That is what he said in relation to his little skirmish with the aerobics class a couple of days ago.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.
—We want the truth.
—The honourable member for Mayo is included in that warning.

—I agree with him. One should not believe everything one reads in the newspaper. I wish to speak a little about the issue which apparently is at the substance of this debate-the leadership of this Government. Firstly, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has led a remarkably successful Government. Our success has been so bewildering to Opposition members that they have not been able to hold a candle to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The two previous speakers were heard in relative silence. I expect the same courtesy to be extended to the Minister. I expect the honourable member for Deakin to cease interjecting. His interjections are becoming almost vexatious.

—The Prime Minister has led a remarkably successful Government. It does not matter what one wants to measure-whether it is economic performance and the way this Government has turned around the circumstances of this country from the chaos we inherited from those opposite; the remarkably successful foreign policy the Government has been pursuing; the remarkably successful health policy we have introduced into this country; or the remarkably successful education policy for which I now have responsibility. The Opposition is bewildered by the pace of change and by the success of the achievements of this Government led by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, in three successive general elections, has created history by getting a Labor government elected and then re-elected twice. As I have said before, both privately and publicly, I support the Prime Minister's remaining Leader of this Party for however long he chooses to remain. I say in passing to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who moved this censure motion, that I wish he would remain Leader of the Opposition forever. If anyone should be well aware of the electoral success of this Prime Minister, it is both the Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy. The Prime Minister has beaten them both.

SPEECH.PARA: This censure motion is a shameless attempt to deflect attention from where the real leadership problems exist in this Parliament, and that is on the other side of the House. It is a matter of utter dismay to hear the Leader of the Opposition talking in these terms about me. After all, he is the master of treachery when it comes to questions of leadership. It was he who got the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his sights and week after week, month after month, went around in a most treacherous fashion until finally he was able to secure his replacement as Leader of the Opposition. Lots of people on this side of the House were not too worried about that. We cheered and applauded when the current Leader of the Opposition became Leader of the Opposition, because we have known for a long time--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. As a preliminary, I read to you the censure motion:

INTERJECT.PARA: That this House censures the Acting Treasurer for his failure to explain to the House the reasons for his calling on the Prime Minister to consider resigning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—There is a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. You have not got my point of order yet. Do me the privilege of listening.
—Hurry up.
—The point of order is one of relevance. The Minister is talking to this Parliament like he talks to his tax accountants.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—He keeps telling them lies.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—I require that to be withdrawn.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that you require the honourable member for O'Connor to withdraw that accusation of lying.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will withdraw the accusation that the Minister was lying.
—I will withdraw the word `lie'.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—Not the reference to his tax accountant.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—Seeing that the honourable member for O'Connor has bought into this in the kind of clumsy way he tries to buy into everything, I would like to refer, in the context of the shambles of the leadership on the other side, to a very well read newspaper in Western Australia known as the Avon Valley Advocate. We had the honourable member for O'Connor addressing a meeting of the Liberal Party in Northam. In this context I will read a couple of short passages to give the honourable members some--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A motion of censure has been moved against the Minister by the Opposition. The Opposition should listen to the Minister's response. Opposition members were heard in silence and the Minister should be heard in silence. If there are any further interjections of the type made just now by the honourable member for North Sydney, I will name those involved.

—At this meeting of the Liberal Party in Northam, the honourable member for O'Connor was apparently outlining his views on health policies, views which are now irrelevant because he has been sacked as Opposition spokesman on health and now has the unenviable task of shadowing me. During this meeting the issue of Federal Party leadership was obviously still a contentious matter. We were told in this newspaper:

SPEECH.PARA: When asked to comment on recent media speculation about Mr Howard's future as Opposition leader Mr Tuckey asked if the press was going to report what he had to say.
After being informed that his comments would be reported Mr Tuckey declined to speak on the issue.

If the honourable member for O'Connor was prepared to give a ringing endorsement to this embattled Leader of the Opposition, one would have thought he would appreciate the fact that the press was there and was going to report it. The only possible conclusion one can come to is that what he was not prepared to do publicly but was prepared to do privately was to bag and undermine the Leader of the Opposition. So we should not have the honourable member for O'Connor buying into this debate in this way.

As I said, we have had here talking about leadership the great failed duumvirate of Sinclair and Howard, the Leader of the National Party and the Leader of the Opposition. We do not have to rely on unsourced newspaper articles to find out what the people think, what everyone in the country thinks about this particular leadership band. We have only to refer to a report in the Australian Financial Review, based on the Quantum survey, for an assessment. That article says that the perception of Mr Howard's performance as Liberal Leader is almost entirely negative. He is Mr 25 per cent, yet he still parades himself as an alternative Prime Minister. We do not have to rely on surveys. We do not know what the basis of that Quantum survey was. We have actual, real, live authentic people on whom to rely. We have no less than the Western Australian Leader of the National Party:
Mr Cowan said yesterday he had not changed his stance that Mr Sinclair and Mr Howard had to go . . .
`With Sinclair and Howard at the helm the conservatives can't win'.

Here we have authentic evidence from a leader of one of their parties who is perfectly happy to put on the record what his view is of this leadership team. On 9 October, at the National Party conference in Queensland, one of the delegates said that Mr Sinclair was not a winner and should step down if the Nationals were not in government after the next election. He might as well go now because we know the answer to that particular question. He went on to say that Mr Sinclair should sack himself for the sake of the Party.

These are the real issues of leadership as far as current politics are concerned; but it would be a mistake to think that leadership was the only question on the Opposition side. The real problem with the Opposition is the fact that this Government has been so spectacularly successful across the whole range of policy initiatives. That is the real issue: it cannot hold a candle to us. It has no policies. For evidence of that we need only refer to a former staff member of the current Leader of the Opposition, Gerard Henderson, who simply says that the Opposition's problem goes much deeper than leadership. It is a problem on the front bench, it is a problem on the back bench, it is a problem of no policies, no direction, no ideas and, as was easily exposed today, no enthusiasm whatsoever for the task in front of it.

I have said that this Government has been spectacularly successful, but the House does not have to rely on my assessment alone. The new boy on the Opposition front bench, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), in his loquacious articles in the Business Review Weekly often had some very interesting comments to make about this Government and politics in general.
Mr Moore interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Ryan.
—On 15 May 1987 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government is very professional and is probably the best front bench since World War II.

That is the case. That is the judgment of the honourable member for Wentworth. I would not have thought he was a man who lightly changed his mind. After all, he keeps telling us what a fantastic economist he is, and I suppose he would also claim to be a man of some principle. We have the assessment from the front bench by the newest member-appointed by the Leader of the Opposition-that this is the best government since World War II. It is the best government since World War II at least, and will continue to be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move an extension of time to give the Minister an opportunity to answer the charge. He has not done so.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Hume does not have the call. He will resume his seat.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the question be now put.
A division having been called and the bells being rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order to seek clarification. Because of the importance of this censure motion I draw your attention to the fact that the broadcasting sign has been on since the censure motion was moved. It is a Senate broadcast day. The Senate was being broadcast during Question Time. Presumably the Senate will revert to Estimates committees at 3 o'clock. I seek your confirmation as to whether this House in fact has been broadcast during this very important censure motion against the Minister.

—The honourable member for Farrer might be more aware of whether that is a fact than I am. I will inquire and let him know. It might have occurred to honourable members on my left that I have been sitting in the chair while they have been walking in and out of the chamber.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABSENCE OF MINISTERS DURING QUESTION TIME

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, may I ask you a question?
—Certainly.

—In view of the absence of a large number of Ministers during Question Time today, could you take up with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) whether he could provide a list of Ministers who will be available to answer questions tomorrow? Could such a list be circulated before Question Time?
—I will consider the question asked of me by the honourable member for Hume.

—Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to comment on the matter raised by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). There are 11 members of the Government Party missing. They are all paired with members opposite. There are five Ministers missing, one of whom is Dr Blewett.
—Madam Speaker, I apologise. I did not hear your answer to my question. Would you take it up with the Prime Minister?
—I said I will deliberate on your question and give you an answer.

—Pursuant to statutes, I present the annual reports and financial statements of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, together with the Auditor-General's report thereon, for the year ended 30 June 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the papers will be recorded in Hansard and the Votes and Proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule read as follows-
Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation-Annual Report 1987-88-including the Auditor-General's Report-section 49 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977.
Resolutions of the Australian Agricultural Council-130th Meeting-Cairns, 14 July 1988.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 is part of the Government's reform package for the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) as announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, on 25 May this year. The reforms to government business enterprises are central to the Government's micro-economic reform agenda to restructure the public sector. In the present difficult and fiercely competitive international trading environment public sector efficiency is especially important. Many public business enterprises-particularly those in the Transport and Communications portfolio-not only final produce goods and services for the consumer, but also provide intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures.

OTC is established under the Overseas Telecommunications Act. This Act was passed by Parliament in 1946, following the acquisition by the Federal Government of the radiocommunications assets of two companies, Cable and Wireless, and Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia), which had hitherto operated cable and beam wireless communications systems between Australia and the rest of the world. Since then OTC has operated as a separate body. The 25 May ministerial statement affirmed the Government's decision to retain each of the telecommunications carriers-Telecom, OTC and Aussat-as separate entities.

Given the increasing competitiveness of international telecommunications, the importance of telecommunications to our economy, the growth in this sector and the fact that OTC serves no explicit social obligations, the Government has decided that OTC will be renamed the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation and it will be incorporated under companies legislation as OTC Ltd.

OTC is an organisation which already operates in a commercial manner. It is subject to all Commonwealth taxes and charges and pays substantial dividends to the Commonwealth. It has an effective monopoly over the central core of its operations, but it faces competition in other areas such as delivery of value added services and consultancy services. OTC has a sound financial structure with a debt to equity ratio of around 65 : 35. On conversion to a company, there will be no need to alter OTC's financial structure nor will the ownership change-that is, OTC will continue to be owned by the Commonwealth.

In future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day to day activities of OTC. Instead, it will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets, and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an ongoing basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. A myriad of unnecessary government controls over day to day management decision-making will be removed. The Government aims, through this approach, to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the board and management.

The OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 amends the Overseas Telecommunications Act and deems OTC to be a public company. Like the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 introduced by my colleague the former Minister for Transport and Communications Support and present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), this approach is consistent with that adopted for Australian Airlines' conversion to company status. As the same legal entity is transferred to company status there is no need to rewrite existing contracts and the like. The date for conversion is set by proclamation-at this stage intended to be 1 January 1989.

OTC Ltd will be expected to operate like other companies under the companies code. This means most of the provisions of the Overseas Telecommunications Act will not be needed and can be repealed. Included among these are provisions which deal with staffing matters. The Bill includes provisions to ensure continuity of employment and the maintenance of existing accrued entitlements for each employee on conversion of OTC to a company.

In future OTC will be responsible for terms and conditions of employment. OTC is currently consulting staff associations on how existing terms and conditions will be dealt with in awards or agreements. The Government expects OTC to make arrangements to transfer terms and conditions and to ensure that no current staff member loses any entitlement or classification on transfer to OTC Ltd. The Government will not proclaim the Bill until it is satisfied that the interests of OTC employees are protected and terms and conditions are satisfactorily transferred.

The Bill minimises day to day government controls in line with the enhanced responsibilities and accountability of the board. There will be appropriate mechanisms to allow the Minister to exercise strategic oversight, through the corporate plan and financial targets. OTC will be free to engage, on its own authority, in such standard business practices as entering into contracts, partnerships, joint ventures, and normal business investment arrangements. In some cases, such as establishing subsidiary companies, the board will be required to notify the Minister in writing before business activities are expanded. Subject to overall Loan Council scrutiny, OTC will not be required to obtain ministerial approval to the terms and conditions of individual borrowings.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of OTC that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of OTC's services. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Since the deregulation of the industry at the beginning of 1988, oil producers have proven to be quick to develop new markets and innovative marketing techniques. In this way they have been able to maximise the value of their output, both to themselves and the nation. However, as a result of these developments certain types of crude oil transactions have occurred which are not strictly covered by the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987, since these transactions were not envisaged when the Act was passed.

The principal purpose of this Bill, which is largely of a technical nature, is to amend the 1987 Act to provide the Minister with additional powers to fix, for the purpose of excise determination, prices for certain types of crude oil transactions. Such transactions include sales where a quantity of crude oil is disposed of either by exchange, having the oil converted to products which are then sold or by any means other than direct sale-for example, by barter.

Commonwealth excise on crude oil production is estimated at $1.4 billion in 1988-89. This Bill is essential to ensure that excise on the transactions described is assessed on a fair and accurate basis. In addition, the Bill will allow crude oil producers the greatest possible flexibility in the use of marketing techniques. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to honourable members.
