DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
This Bill is an omnibus Bill for legislation administered within the primary industries and energy portfolio. Its introduction will facilitate the passage of amendments to existing legislation.
Sugar Agreement Act 1985

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Sugar Agreement Act 1985 with effect from 1 July 1989. The Act prohibits the importation of sugar and sugar products as described in the 1984 Commonwealth-Queensland Sugar Agreement. The Agreement is set out in the schedule to the Act. The Agreement expires on 30 June 1989. This expiry notwithstanding, the Act provides that the import prohibition extends beyond 30 June 1989.

As part of the Government's economic statement of 25 May 1988, it was announced that the prohibition on the importation of sugar and sugar products was to be replaced by ad valorem tariffs of 35 per cent and 25 per cent on raw and refined sugar respectively, phasing down to 15 per cent in 1992. The initial tariff rates are set to provide a similar level of support as the current import embargo and domestic price arrangements.

The industry has sought a different form of tariff protection, and the government is considering that approach. In addition, the current domestic administered pricing arrangements will be terminated on the expiry on 30 June 1989 of the current Commonwealth-Queensland Sugar Agreement. The industry is considering the desirability of a future Commonwealth-Queensland Sugar Agreement. The Government will introduce further legislation to implement such an agreement if necessary.

The revised arrangements for the sugar industry are part of a package of measures based upon the outcome of the recent review of government programs and policies within the primary industries sector, known as the industry development review. The review outcome, which was comprehensive and far reaching, was considered by the Government along with proposals for general industry assistance reductions and proposals for reforming the business taxation structure. This had the advantage of allowing consideration of the important linkages between assistance measures for various sectors as well as their interaction with taxation measures. One of the strengths of the package of measures is that it is not restricted to one or two sectors of the economy. As a result, the outcome should be far more effective than the sum of the individual contributions by each sector.
Repeals of Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Legislation

The introduction on 1 July 1988 of a fee for service charging regime under the Export Control Act 1982, for export slaughter floor meat inspection by the Commonwealth, has obviated the need for the livestock slaughter export inspection charge legislation, which related to a per carcass charge on the slaughter of livestock.
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977

The first amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act removes the requirement that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy approve orders to be made by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) in relation to the export shipping of meat or livestock. The change is consistent with the Government's policy of deregulating the activities of statutory authorities and will permit the implementation of agreements which have been negotiated between the AMLC and shipping companies on a commercial basis. The second amendment is to vary sub-paragraph 30d (1) (a) (ii) of the Act, pertaining to the time requirements for notification of motions to be put to the annual general meeting of the Corporation. This amendment removes an inconsistency in the Act which resulted from amendments made in 1987.
Wool Marketing Act 1987

Wool is Australia's major export earner with exports valued at some $5.8 billion last year. To preserve the competitiveness of wool and its profile as a high quality fibre it is important that we maintain the confidence of buyers in the quality and description of the wool they are purchasing. An important source of this confidence is the integrity of wool testing procedures. Nearly all wool sold at auction is tested for key characteristics which form the basis for a commercial assessment by buyers. This testing is done by testing houses on the basis of a sample. Buyers also visually appraise the wool for sale on the basis of a sample displayed on the show floor.

Section 127 of the Wool Marketing Act provides for regulations to be made in relation to registration and inspection of sampling sites and registration of wool test houses. An amendment to provide for the inspection of wool test houses is being considered by Parliament in these sittings. However, there are no provisions for the registration and inspection of wool display areas and sample security areas which are central to the wool selling system. To ensure the integrity of the description of wool and the wool auction system, it is necessary to provide for registration and inspection of these areas. Provision is also required for the payment of fees in relation to registration and inspection costs. Regulation-making powers providing for registration and inspection of wool display areas and sample security areas, and payment of fees in respect of these, will therefore be inserted in section 127 of the Act. The proposed amendments in this Bill have no financial implications for the Commonwealth. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The new arrangements for the rural adjustment scheme outlined in this Bill represent a landmark with respect to both structural adjustment policy and the management of Commonwealth-State programs. The Bill will serve two purposes. It will allow the rural adjustment scheme to operate in a more flexible and innovative way so as to address more adequately the changing structural adjustment forces acting on businesses in the Australian agricultural sector. It will also set in place innovative arrangements for the management of Commonwealth-State programs. Under these arrangements the Commonwealth's role will be restricted to setting broad policy guidelines. The States will have total managerial and financial responsibility. They will be accountable to the Commonwealth only for the effective achievement of the scheme's objectives.

In a structural adjustment policy sense the Bill recognises that structural adjustment arises from a whole spectrum of reasons, ranging from the adoption of exciting new computer and biological technologies through to the painful process of facilitating the exit from the sector of producers who are no longer viable. Adjustment has become an increasingly more significant issue for the farm business because of the greater degree of volatility of external factors it is now likely to face. This volatility arises from a host of circumstances including variability in world commodity prices, exchange rates, interest rates and climatic conditions. Rigid policy responses and smothering administrative regulations cannot cope with this type of variability. Flexibility and adaptability of policy responses are essential in this context. The Bill also aims at ensuring that structural adjustment assistance does not centre upon the provision of short term, quick fix solutions or on the treatment of symptoms. Rather, it aims to ensure that attention is given to the longer term result and the causes of problems.

To accomplish these two aspects the agreement, which is a schedule to the Bill, sets out clearly defined purposes, objectives and strategies which directly address these aims. Commonwealth and State Ministers will meet annually to determine the priorities for the provision of structural adjustment assistance. They will determine which industries are in particular need of adjustment assistance at any time and, if necessary, the types of farm build-up and farm improvement activities which should receive priority attention. For example, if a series of widespread good years has occurred, Ministers may decide to emphasise the provision of assistance for drought proofing or soil conservation measures directed at giving businesses in the agricultural sector the long term capacity to accommodate climatic variations within their normal operations. Provided productive activities of this type can be identified and implemented, Commonwealth funding of the scheme need not necessarily decline in good times when demand for funds, due to the impact of variability of costs and output, declines.

To ensure that a long term approach is adopted, the legislation retains the previous Commonwealth commitment to provide funds for seven years. The Commonwealth and the States have developed a range of policy measures with each State having the freedom to choose which measures it will use. For example, some States may wish to engage in limited land trading to facilitate the exit of non-viable farmers from the industry or farm build-up. Other States may decide not to utilise that particular policy measure. The Bill also allows for new policy measures to be developed and implemented in the future to meet changing needs and circumstances. The role of the Commonwealth will be to develop, in consultation with the States, ministerial determinations which will set out the broad policy parameters to be applied to each policy instrument. It will be up to the States to develop the management guidelines to govern the use of each policy instrument. This legislation will also allow for variation between the States in the management procedures adopted with respect to specific policy measures.

The third key policy aspect is that there is to be a much stronger emphasis on the notion that farming is first and foremost a business-a business which must be run along sound business management lines if it is to survive and prosper. Two provisions are made in the Bill specifically to facilitate meeting this objective. Training for farmers is recognised as an appropriate activity to be funded under the scheme. In addition, provision is made for ongoing funding to improve the quality of financial analysis which is undertaken before assistance is provided to the farmer. In this context, the Bill aims to ensure that the real causes of a farmer's business problems are identified before assistance is provided. Hopefully, this type of analysis will also allow the States to:
integrate the provisions of assistance to farm businesses from a number of sources such as the rural adjustment scheme, State extension services, rural counsellors and private financing bodies; and
use a number of the scheme's assistance measures together, in conjunction with each other, more effectively in order to address the adjustment needs of particular farm businesses.

The other adjustment policy measure incorporated in the legislation which deserves special mention is the new arrangement for the provision of re-establishment assistance under part C of the scheme. The new arrangement will enable farmers whose businesses are clearly not capable of surviving without assistance into the long term to leave the sector with dignity and to provide a base from which to establish themselves once they have left farming. To facilitate less traumatic and more dignified adjustment the legislation provides for the payment of a re-establishment grant of up to $28,000 to a farmer leaving the sector. This amount is indexed annually and subject to an assets test, excluding personal effects. A farmer will be able to leave the sector with a maximum of $28,000 of assets plus a $28,000 re-establishment grant. As the value of assets rises above $28,000 the re-establishment grant will decline on a dollar for dollar basis.

In association with this, the provision of household support assistance under part C will be changed in a number of ways including making it available for a maximum of two years. Commonwealth and State Ministers considered this period allowed more than enough time for the farmer, once he or she has taken the decision to leave farming, to sell the business. It was felt that the old arrangements were having a negative adjustment impact and, in some circumstances, may have been eroding the capital base of the farmer's business.

As I have pointed out, structural adjustment policy is not the only matter addressed by the Bill. It is also a landmark piece of legislation in terms of being the first attempt at applying, in the context of cooperative Commonwealth-State relations, the principles of devolution of financial management encapsulated in concepts such as program budgeting and the financial management improvement program. To implement this devolution, the legislation and agreement:
include a clear mission statement for the rural adjustment scheme;
provide for the State rural adjustment authority to have sole responsibility for the management and administration of the policy measures available under the scheme;
provide for the State rural adjustment authority to have total freedom, within the bounds of responsible financial administration, to manage funds provided for the purpose of the scheme; and

provide for the establishment of a management information system to meet the States' own management requirements and to allow them to report to the Commonwealth on the effectiveness of the scheme's operations.

This approach has been adopted because it has been demonstrated, by the experience of the last three years, that it is impractical for the Commonwealth to control the detailed financial and managerial operations of the State adjustment authorities. As a corollary to these changes it may, of course, be necessary for the States to improve the quality of resources available to their adjustment authorities.

The mission statement contained in the statement of purposes and objectives set out in the agreement will, as I have already pointed out, change the policy focus of the scheme. It will aid more effective operation and management of the scheme. It will allow ends and means to be more directly related. It will allow for more efficient usage of funds. It will also aid the States in their accounting to the Commonwealth for the effective operation of the scheme.

The legislation will allow the State adjustment authorities maximum management freedom. Policy guidelines will be determined by the Commonwealth; the responsibility for establishing and operating the management arrangements for effectively implementing these policies so as to achieve the scheme's objectives will rest with the States. The Commonwealth will not have any part to play in the management process but it will participate in regular meetings of State adjustment authority officers to provide for exchanges of information on management priorities and hence the more effective operation of the scheme.

The financial management of funds provided under the scheme will also rest entirely with State adjustment authorities. They will, of course, need to have their annual accounts audited by a registered auditor in accordance with Australian auditing standards. The radical degree of financial and managerial freedom allowed to State adjustment authorities under the legislation will, no doubt, require auditors to consider carefully the nature of the auditing activities they undertake. Equally, I except that State adjustment authorities will incorporate adequate fraud control measures into their managerial arrangements. The legislation, as part of this greater financial management freedom, will allow the State adjustment authorities to retain, within the scheme, current and future surpluses earned under the scheme and will require them to take over responsibility for the provision of funds to meet possible bad debts incurred under the scheme since its inception in 1985.

The last aspect of greater financial freedom for the State adjustment authorities will result from the States being given a single pool of funds under part A of the scheme. The Commonwealth will no longer determine the proportion of funds to be used for particular types of activity under the scheme. It will not set nominal maximum interest rates for the use of part A funds. Also, where appropriate, there will be greater freedom for part A funds to be used to facilities adjustment under part C of the scheme. In this context, I have in mind the new policy provisions for land trading on a limited scale. State Ministers have accepted that the greater degree of policy flexibility and the managerial and financial freedom allowed under this legislation, carries with it the responsibility to ensure, and account for, the effective achievement of the scheme's objectives. I cannot stress too much this requirement for accountability. A State which misuses this freedom, for example, to distort the scheme's objectives or to shift the risk of other State activities on to the scheme, will lose access to Commonwealth funds.

It is for this reason, and also to facilitate more efficient management by State adjustment authorities, that the Commonwealth and the States have agreed to set up a compatible management information system for the scheme. Under this arrangement the States will provide the Commonwealth with data on the operations and finances of the scheme in an electronic form. This will considerably reduce the State adjustment authorities' reporting workload. The Commonwealth will undertake its own analysis of this data to evaluate the effectiveness of the scheme's operations. The reports prepared as a result of this work will be provided to the State adjustment authorities and where appropriate to the Commonwealth Auditor-General, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the Department of Finance.

Three provisions of the new Bill will impact on the amount of funds provided to the States under the scheme. An additional $1.2m will be provided in 1988-89 to allow the States to improve the quality of financial analysis which is undertaken before assistance is provided to the farmer. The new arrangements for part C will mean some reduction in household support payments but larger payment for re-establishment assistance. It is not possible to assess how these two factors will balance out but it should be noted that funding for part C remains open-ended. The new arrangements for meeting State administrative expenses are expected to result in a saving to the Commonwealth of $0.4m in 1988-89. New part A funding will remain unchanged in 1988-89 at $6.7m.

In closing I would like to make three other points. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the consulting firm Coopers and Lybrand W. D. Scott for the excellent report they prepared reviewing the existing arrangements for the operation of the rural adjustment scheme. That report played a key part in the development of this legislation.

Secondly, I wish to reiterate that the purpose of this scheme is to allow effective structural adjustment to take place in farm business enterprises. It is not aimed at keeping farmers on the land. Using the scheme to prop up farm businesses that are not viable in the long term is not on. The scheme is aimed at making farm businesses independent of assistance as soon as possible or, if this cannot occur, helping farmers to leave the sector with dignity. The retention of farming as a desirable lifestyle will be a result of effective management of farm businesses and effective adjustment, not an objective of it.

Finally, I would point out that this scheme is only part of a package of measures, pursued both at the Commonwealth and the State level, to achieve effective adjustment. At the Commonwealth level other measures which are part of the agricultural adjustment process include tariff adjustment, the funding of research and development, assistance for education in rural areas, the rural counselling scheme, the countrylink program and the country town water supply improvement program. There are also relevant programs at the State level; for example, extension services have a key role to play. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr West, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill contains amendments to a number of Acts administered by the Administrative Services portfolio. The amendments are of a kind which, in recent years, it has been the practice to include in an omnibus Bill.
Amendment of the Public Works Committee Act 1969

As honourable members will be aware the Public Works Committee Act 1969 establishes the Public Works Committee to scrutinise the Executive's expenditure on public works. Since the inception of the Committee, departments and to an extent the Committee itself have regarded `works' as being limited to those of a permanent architectural or engineering nature carried out for or by the government. Moveable works, such as the construction of a ship, or of a submarine, et cetera, have long been been regarded as being of the nature of specialised procurements which ought not be subject to the Act.

However, in recent years, legal advice to the effect that moveable works may in certain circumstances indeed be works within the terms of the Public Works Committee Act has called this view into question. To remove the ambiguity as to what comes within the definition of a `work' for the purpose of the Act, the amendments introduced by this Bill provide that a `work' means an architectural or engineering work and specifically exclude intangible things, moveable works and engineering equipment not being integral components of a work.

The Bill also expands the definition of work to ensure that works which are financed by deferred payment or similar arrangements are referable to the Committee. In these times of economic restraint government bodies are increasingly turning to alternative methods of financing their public works. Under a deferred payment arrangement, the government body is not required to finance the work during construction but, effectively, it is paid off by instalments after occupancy. Such alternatives to traditional funding are attractive but in some situations the relevant works are not referable to the Committee under the existing provisions of the Act. Where there is a clear intention for the Government and its agencies to become the owner of such facilities, the amendment will allow the Public Works Committee to fulfil its established role.

The Bill also provides that, after consultation with the Committee, types of works can be declared to be works or public works by regulation for the purposes of the Act. Similarly, types of works can also be declared not to be works or public works by regulation. This approach is intended to facilitate consideration of new types of projects and delivery systems and to meet changing circumstances.
Amendment of the Protective Service Act 1987

The amendments to the Australian Protective Service Act 1987 extend the powers of arrest of protective service officers to the offences of escaping from lawful custody, aiding a person to escape from lawful custody or rescuing a person by force from lawful custody which were recently created by amendments to the Crimes Act 1914. This is essentially a consequential amendment.
Amendment of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973

Honourable members may be aware that presently the Chairman of the Commonwealth Grants Commission must be appointed on a full-time basis, whereas members can be appointed on either a full-time or part-time basis. The amendments to the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 provide for the option of appointing the chairperson also on a full-time or a part-time basis.
Amendment of the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979

The Parliament House Construction Authority will have successfully completed the major phase of the design and construction of the new Parliament House by early 1989. There are, however, financial and legal tasks related to the completion and termination of over 500 contracts requiring further work over the next two to three years. There are also minor construction works remaining to be completed.

While the functions to be undertaken by the Authority after early 1989 continue to be very important to the completion of the project, the range of matters to be managed will be more restricted than in earlier years. Consequently, the Government considers that the range of skills and experience required by Authority Board members in this period would not need to be as diverse as those required for the current and previous boards.

As well, the Act specifies that the Commissioner of the National Capital Development Commission shall be a member of the Authority. During the establishment and construction phases of the project it was essential to enlist the support and assistance of the Commissioner in view of his planning responsibilities for the national capital. However, in line with the projected reduction in the functions of the Authority, continued involvement of the relevant planning authority is unnecessary.

In recognition of the change in nature and scope of the remaining work, the Government took two decisions: firstly, that the Authority was to complete its remaining work and be terminated in June 1991; secondly, that consonant with the wind down phase commencing early in 1989, from that time the Authority Board would be restructured reducing its numbers from six to three part-time members, including the position of chairman. This Bill puts into effect the later decision. It is the Government's intention to bring forward in 1991 appropriate legislation terminating the Authority. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Fife) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the employment provisions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act. Sections 85 and 86 of the Act provide for the determination of salaries and terms and conditions of employment of ASIO staff by the Director-General of Security, the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department and the Chairman of the Public Service Board. Sections 34 and 35 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Act 1986 substitute the `Public Service Board' for the Chairman of the Board and the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. There is now no longer a Public Service Board or a Chairman. An amendment is therefore required to remove these outmoded references and to ensure that staff of the Organisation receive the benefit of wage increases awarded to the community.

In future, salaries and terms and conditions will be determined by the Director-General, who will be subject to any guidelines that the Attorney-General may give him pursuant to section 8a. The amendment to section 8a makes it clear that guidelines under the section can be given in relation to these matters. These amendments thus provide a mechanism for ensuring that public sector policy on pay and conditions is taken into account by the Director-General, as well as recognising the special circumstances associated with employment in the Organisation.

The references in sections 85 and 86 to the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department are also being removed, since it is no longer appropriate for this officer to be involved in the determination of pay and conditions.
Financial Impact Statement
The Bill has no financial impact. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

Proposed expenditure, $1,362,935,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the adjournment of the debate on the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services earlier today I was taking the opportunity to raise the question of the changes being contemplated by the Government in Commonwealth purchasing procedures. You will recall, Mr Deputy Chairman, that in Question Time yesterday the Minister gave an outline of the changes that were in the Government's mind. Without repeating word for word what the Minister had to say, if I can paraphrase what he said, he indicated that there may be some departure from the current tendering practices. It is true that he said that tendering would still be a very important delivery system, but the burden of his remarks was that there was to be a change from the basic system of tendering for major Commonwealth purchases. He indicated that there would be what are described as selected tenderers who would have prequalifications. It is a new and interesting notion that there should be prequalifications for selected tenderers. It is not clear.
—You should wait. I will make a statement on all this.
—I am grateful for that, but let me suggest a few things--
—You should not knock everything before you even hear it.

—And the Minister should not be making statements in Question Time if he has not considered what the Government's final position is. That is the point of order we take. The Minister gets up in Question Time and pontificates about considered Government positions, when Question Time was never intended for that purpose. Then, when someone challenges him, he says, `Do not take what we said as being the final word because there is more to come'. I accept that there is more to come. Frankly, there should be more to come. What I am suggesting-I hope in a constructive way-is that before the Minister makes his final statement he should bear in mind the contribution that I am making.

SPEECH.PARA: You will recall, Mr Deputy Chairman, that I was illustrating that by telling the Minister of a recent Federal Government tendering process I had been acquainted with. When the present tendering system, which has stood the test of time, has in individual cases weaknesses and shortcomings and when particular cases show inadequacies, it is wise to get that system correct first before one starts to think of abandoning it. I was illustrating this proposition by reference to a contract let by the Federal Airports Corporation at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport for the gift and newsagency shop concession, which is worth several million dollars a year.

The Federal Airports Corporation advertised for tenders. The tendering documents included a contract. When this contract came to the notice of the Trade Practices Commission it said to the Federal Airports Corporation, `There are three clauses in this contract which are in breach of the law. They are contrary to the Trade Practices Act'. The Federal Airports Corporation let the tenders close. It let the time expire. So the time had run and was finished. Having regard to the advice of the Trade Practices Commission-you will find this hard to believe, Mr Deputy Chairman-after the tenders had closed, the Corporation changed the terms of the contract, which was the basis upon which tenders had been put in, by omitting one clause of the contract and by amending another two of its clauses. As I say, that was after the tenders had closed.

Then-wonder of wonders-having done that, the Corporation awarded the contract, the concession, to the concessionaire who had had the concession in the first place. It did not tell the rest of the industry that it could tender again. It did not tell other tenderers that they had an opportunity-or should have had an opportunity-to submit amended tenders. It did nothing. It changed the contract after the tenders had closed. That is sloppy, loose tendering practice. There is certainly something fishy about the whole procedure. It should be investigated very thoroughly.

What I have said is correct. I use it as an illustration for my general proposition that the Government should look very closely, and think twice, before it abandons the present tendering system. It should be improved and made watertight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Administrative Services is now one of the largest departments in the Commonwealth Public Service. It was created in July last year after the machinery of government changes announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is all about providing services to the government and to the Commonwealth, and to the Department and its instrumentalities. Its functions are many and varied. The Department covers such areas as the Australian Property Group, the Construction Group, the Parliament House Construction Authority-officials of which are here today-the Surveying and Land Information Group, the Australian Archives, the Australian Protective Service, the Analytical Laboratories, the Bureau of Meteorology, the Purchasing and Sales Group, the Australian Government Publishing Service, the Transport and Storage Group, the Parliamentary Services and Information Group, which provides services to members and Ministers, and even the Commonwealth Grants Commission and the Australian Electoral Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The portfolio's total appropriations for the year were $1.727 billion. That was a decrease of around 17 per cent on the previous year's expenditure. There are a number of reasons for that decrease. There was a reduced requirement for the Parliament House Construction Authority, from $297m in 1987-88 to $82m in 1988-89; a non-recurrent Budget neutral transaction in 1987-88 whereby $168m was paid to the Transport and Storage trust account for the purchase of vehicles and equipment as it moved into the commercial mode; the revised funding arrangements for civil capital works which allowed for the appropriation of funds for new works in 1988-89 direct to client departments; and the off-Budget funding of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. We expect to generate within the portfolio revenue of some $525m, excluding special asset sales of $700m. That $525m is an increase of some 12 per cent on the previous year. Staff resources totalled 17,675 staff years, a reduction of 2.5 per cent.

As I just said-and this was not covered in the debate but I should draw attention to the work that is done-the biggest area in terms of employment and one of the biggest, if not the biggest, in terms of expenditure is construction services for civil and defence works and related on-Budget works. There is in train a total ongoing program with Budget approval of $2.9 billion. This year about $801.5m will be expended on the construction program. There are a number of major defence and civil works programs in most States, such as the new buildings for Commonwealth accommodation in Sydney at the Haymarket site-costing $160m-odd-and the fighter facilities at Williamtown, near Newcastle. In Melbourne an even larger Commonwealth centre is proposed, costing $187m, with a moderate amount of expenditure this year. There is the resiting of defence facilities from within Victoria to Mulwala, and that will cost $62.3m all up, almost $11m of which will be expended this financial year.

In Queensland, there are the defence works at the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base, Townsville, where construction of the utility helicopter facility is under way. Total expenditure will be over $17m for that project and the stage II RAAF base development at Townsville will cost $20m. There will be significant expenditure in each of those projects in this financial year. There are the new law courts in Perth, finally under way, with a $46.1m total cost, and several million dollars will be allocated this year.

We have completed, and it is now operational, the new Commonwealth centre in Adelaide, at a cost of almost $55m. In the Northern Territory, Tindal stage 1 is to cost $200m. That is well on the way to completion, and $25m is expected to be spent this year. Tindal stage II has been referred to the Public Works Committee. That is a $38m project, and we expect a recommendation to come back from the Public Works Committee soon. I expect the House to treat the project with expedition. Similarly, the naval project at HMAS Coonawarra, near Darwin, has Budget approval to the extent of $25m. In the Australian Capital Territory, to ease expenditure on the Budget, as honourable members will probably remember we have put out to tender a project for a new Commonwealth pre-committed leased building at Tuggeranong. I think its size will be 30,000 square metres, and I will be participating in the evaluation of tenders not for a government-owned building but for a pre-committed leased building owned by the private sector. We expect the central office for the Department of Social Security to be housed there when it is completed.

I should mention the massive changes under way in the way the Commonwealth will provide common government services to itself. Honourable members will remember I have mentioned this in the House several times at Question Time because I think it is important, as I think the other matter raised by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) is important. I will touch on it in a moment and provide further information. We are about commercialising without throwing the public interest baby out with the commercialisation bath water. In other words, it is a case by case appraisal. We will be, as far as we can, implementing cost recovery and commercialisation, which means untying clients to enable them to take bids for work from the private sector if they wish. Honourable members may remember that in this debate last year I said that the Government intended to do this and would work out a series of principles which would govern the way we applied or implemented these changes in the Department, division by division. We have done that. We have completed and endorsed the principles and we have already finalised the decisions for a whole number of divisions.

The Australian Property Group is complete, and so are Australian Construction Services and the Transport and Storage Group. The Australian Protective Service, the Australian Valuation Office and the Australian Surveying and Land Information Services are complete, and they are being commercialised to various degrees. Their implementation programs are well under way and I am receiving regular reports on their progress. The Australian Government Publishing Service, which services this Parliament and the departments and does other publishing to a minor degree, is being dealt with now and should be finalised in the next week or so, as is the case with the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories. The Purchasing and Sales Group is now in preparation and should be dealt with soon. That would make nine divisions which have been either commercialised or partly commercialised and made subject to cost recovery in many operational areas. The Committee would agree that we have virtually completed what I said, about a year ago, we would do.

I shall give an example of one of these achievements because I am extremely interested in the success of these programs-as I am sure the Opposition is. Australian Construction Services will probably go through the greatest degree of commercialisation of all. Government business enterprises are freed up already and can go straight to the private sector if they wish. The departments will be totally freed up in July of 1991, at the same time as we implement full cost recovery, which will include the cost of capital and so on. A range of costs will be integrated into a charging system which I will then integrate into a corporate plan which will govern the activities of Australian Construction Services. It is already charging commercial fees to the departments and instrumentalities, and will move to full cost recovery in June 1991. We will also be removing staffing levels and allowing the market-that is, the Construction Services' success rate in getting work-to determine how many staff it employs.

I now turn to some of the points raised during the debate. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) mentioned the Beijing Australian Embassy project. That project was commissioned by the Australian Government and is under construction, using Chinese services.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is behind schedule, isn't it?

—Yes, it is behind schedule. That is the point the honourable member for Throsby made. We are using a great amount of Australian materials and Chinese authorities are doing the construction. I visited Beijing several weeks ago with the Secretary to the Department of Administrative Services and the general manager of the overseas property group for discussions with the Chinese authorities and Ministers, including the Foreign Minister and the Assistant Foreign Minister and the Mayor of Beijing, to see how we could expedite completion of the project.

SPEECH.PARA: The background is that the Chinese Diplomatic Services Bureau holds the contract and the Beijing Construction Commission, which is the responsibility of the Mayor of Beijing, is the constructing authority. We were successful in arranging an extension to the original agreement with the Diplomatic Services Bureau of China, which was signed on our behalf by the Australian Ambassador. The end result of this should be that the project is expedited. The extended agreement includes such measures as agreement by the Chinese to increase their construction resources, that is, the numbers of people on the job and the numbers of shifts worked and so on. They are committed to producing a revised construction and management program which should offer completion by the end of next year, October being the date.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long behind is it so far?
—I think one could say it is fairly substantially behind schedule.
—A year?

—It would not be that long, but the Chinese authorities have always said they would finish on schedule in October 1989, and they are still giving us those assurances. The completion date is October 1989 and the Mayor of Beijing has given me a personal assurance that that will occur. The purpose of my visit was to gain those assurances and also to write a new or extended agreement, which in my view-not just the view of the Chinese but my view and the view of my Department-offered a fair chance that that could be achieved. We have done that. They have agreed to increase their resources; they have agreed to revise the construction and management program to allow completion by October 1989, as promised. We will make some changes to our project management arrangements in terms of personnel and responsibilities. There is only a small team there and it is not constructing-the honourable member must not run away with that idea-it is overviewing. The Chinese have agreed to put full time local building inspectors on the job at all times to assure on the spot construction integrity. As a minor matter, I might mention that they have also agreed to provide much extended covered storage space for the containers with a great number of valuable Australian materials. We have been keen to get the maximum use of Australian materials and there are a lot of these materials up there on the site now.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) raised an issue with regard to the Commonwealth building at Parramatta. I have asked for some explanation of that matter-as to what substance, if any, there is in what the honourable member for Dundas said about the installation of the PABX system and the attitude of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), for which I am not responsible, of course. The honourable member should understand that. I would like to report to the Committee that the Department of Administrative Services has purchased a PABX from Telecom Australia at $3.2m. The equipment has not been installed as yet. All the proposed occupants that were known at the time, including the Tax Office, were consulted and agreement obtained as to satisfying each client's requirements. The ATO has subsequently reconsidered its needs and regards the current system as now not satisfying its current and future needs. The problem, according to the ATO, is that the system envisaged does not have separate security and is unable to integrate with the new national communications system.

My Department is liaising with Telecom to consider rearranging the PABX already purchased to provide two separate systems within the PABX. The review may indicate that modifications are not economic. It is to indicate the preferred option in consultation with the ATO. I will be paying close attention to the outcome of that review. I have already made some preliminary verbal inquiries, and I do not think it would be true to say that even if changes were made, as I think the honourable member for Dundas alleged, we would be $3.2m down the chute. That would not be so because that would refer only to the Tax Office portion of the $3.2m, which could not possibly be the whole $3.2m. I stress the point I have just made: we have not made any decisions on that yet. The Tax Office agreed to a total integrated system and now wants a change and there is a review to see whether change is justified. As it is the client we have to go along with it and see what comes out of the review.

I conclude with the comments made by the honourable member for Menzies. First of all, he mentioned the general changes to procurement procedures that the Government has under consideration, and I will return to that in a moment. He also made reference to certain contracts held by the Federal Airports Corporation-which again, of course, is not within the administrative services portfolio-at Kingsford-Smith and to certain concessions and whether or not those contracts may have originally included a breach of Trade Practices Commission regulations. I have that matter under investigation. I am not in a position either to verify or not verify that point here, but I will certainly investigate it and write to the honourable member and give him the facts, whether they are positive or negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just gave the facts.

—The honourable member for Menzies says that is his position. I am telling him that this is the first I have heard of it. In the sense that it has been drawn explicitly to my attention, I will investigate it and get back to him. That is what these Estimates debates are all about. He would not expect me to answer off the top of my head anything he cares to raise on the spur of the moment. We will do it properly and I will get back to him.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the matter he referred to, which is an extremely important issue and I make no apologies for raising it in answer to a question yesterday, I do not have a concept of ministerial responsibility that says a Minister goes away and works out some major change, puts it through the Cabinet, and then comes back into the House and makes a statement about it. This matter regarding Commonwealth procurement has been under consideration, in case the honourable member has not noticed, for quite some time. It has been put to a number of seminars that have been held quite openly in capital cities with the main players in the procurement industries, suppliers in the private sector. We wanted them to have a good look at it; we wanted basically to test their views. We have done it with the instrumentalities-that is the GBEs-and we have done it with major government departments. The Government has not made a decision yet, but that is all right. It has been out in the public arena for some time. Business is discussing it, the departments are discussing it, and I see no reason why I cannot inform the House about the discussions before we actually take our decision. I am certainly discussing it with our Caucus committees and I will do so again in the next few days, before we go to Cabinet on the matter. That is the background.

I conclude on this note: the honourable member for Menzies raised the matter and I am telling him that we are really serious and quite open about this issue. So $8 billion a year is the figure we are talking about in terms of total procurement. The financial management improvement program conducted a review at the instigation of Ministers and the Department. The problem has been that for almost 200 years in Australia and 300 years in the United Kingdom-this all goes back to the British Admiralty systems of procurement by tender-a very rigid system has developed. We have a system now where within purchase and sales groups officers and departmental officers are operating a system-it is not their fault-where the procedure is virtually as important as the end result. No one is game to step outside rigid procedures. For instance, for anything under $2000 one gets a certain number of oral quotes, for anything under $20,000 a certain number of written quotes, and anything over $20,000 goes out to tender whether one likes it or not, unless one gets a certified exemption, et cetera. When the bids come in, there may be a hell of a blue if, for some reason, the officers think that they should not have to accept the lowest tender because of some other reason, such as contractor inability to perform, or whatever. There is always the possibility of parliamentary argument about that sort of thing. If someone leaks what has happened, it can be on for young and old, so to speak.

Let me be absolutely clear: I am not seeking to make savings or to streamline a procedure at the expense of probity or integrity. They must be maintained. But in this day and age one cannot say that the private sector acts in the way in which I described earlier-that is, in the manner of a totally rigid system. It can cost us about $60 just to process a very simple order. The Commonwealth spends $8 billion on procurement, to service itself, every year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Public money.

—Yes. Why should we not try to make savings in that area? We think that we will save at least one per cent, or $80m. We could save as much as 3 or 4 per cent per annum. In other words, we could be looking at savings of $300m to $400m. So why should I not canvass these matters? The Opposition parties were in government for a long time after the war. They were in government in the late 1970s and early 1980s. We heard a lot about deregulation, efficiency, commercialisation and the rest of it, but we did not see any real changes. There has been a lot of deregulation under this Government. I have never been regarded as a great deregulator or privatiser, as the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) would know, but I am convinced that in this particular field great savings in finance and in efficiency gains can be achieved. In doing so we can and must still maintain probity and integrity.

SPEECH.PARA: I explained the matter very briefly during Question Time yesterday. Of course, I could not begin to discuss the complex issues involved or what the explicit system might be. The Government must decide those details. However, I said-and I stand by this-that I will recommend to the Government that it no longer be mandatory to go to tender above the current $20,000 threshold. We should let the managers manage in the departments. A system should be chosen that might involve a series of guidelines that we give to them so that they choose the delivery system they think would best serve the transaction that they have in mind. They could decide simply to call for expressions of interest or, as I said yesterday, make a request for quotation, or they could set up preselected tenderers, as is sometimes the case in the construction area, or they could still go to tender with a right to conduct post-tender negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —With no ceiling? Up to what amount?

—No ceiling. We may include in the guidelines words such as these, `For anything over $50,000 or $60,000, we recommend that you follow certain procedures and it is up to you to select the one that suits you best. You must advertise your decision in the Gazette. You must advertise what the result is and you will be held responsible for your decision, and let the market prevail'. That is the position that I advocate.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope I have covered the debate adequately. I certainly think I have done so. I will get back to the honourable member for Menzies on the one matter on which I was not able to reply to him. I thank the honourable member and the several other honourable members who participated in the debate.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Community Services and Health
Proposed expenditure, $1,294,590,000.
Department of Veterans' Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $1,201,004,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The feature that stands out in the appropriations for the Department of Community Services and Health is that this Government's health care system is gobbling up funds at an ever increasing rate, yet is still failing to give taxpayers value for their dollars. The plain facts are these: health costs are rising; the quality of the service in many important respects is declining; and hospital waiting lists-hospital queues-are lengthening. The Parliamentary Library has calculated that in constant 1979-80 prices the changes between expenditure on health in the 1982-83 Budget and the 1987-88 Budget reflect a dramatic increase of 69.3 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government, the Hawke-Keating Government-or the Keating-Hawke Government, depending on which faction one belongs to-prides itself on its commitment to social justice and equity. Yet it is this very same arrogant and out of touch Government which has created a two-tier level of service in our health care system-a system in which low income earners, the most disadvantaged and least articulate or influential people, are being treated as second-class citizens. They are the ones who are languishing at the end of the public hospital queues. They are the ones who are waiting for hip replacement surgery, cataract removals and a host of other treatments. They are the ones who are experiencing needless pain and suffering while they wait for surgery which would immeasurably improve the quality of their lives. They stay at the end of those queues while those who can afford private health insurance or who can manipulate the public hospital waiting list system manage to get the treatment they need without delay.

It is the greatest and perhaps the cruellest irony that these people are the ones that Medicare is supposed to help. The poor and the disadvantaged stay on waiting lists simply because this Government refuses to acknowledge that its 1983 promise of a national, free and universal medical and hospital service is both unrealisable and unrealistic. These hospital waiting lists of more than 100,000 people are nothing more and nothing less than a means of rationing health care in an effort to contain costs which have dramatically blown out under Medicare. The lists are the tangible evidence of the undesirable and unachievable attempts by this Government to socialise our health care system.

To use a colourful analogy, Medicare is a monster eating itself out of existence. It can only be a matter of time before the whole edifice collapses under the sheer weight of its own insatiable appetite-an appetite which has been fuelled by the total breakdown of direct accountability on the part of both consumers and providers of health services. Unless the Government acknowledges that Medicare is the central cause of the crisis in our health care system and abandons its attempts to prop it up by tinkering at the edges, both the availability and quality of health care will continue to decline. The Medicare monster has well and truly outgrown its cage and no amount of sniping at doctors' fees and pharmacy remuneration or snipping away at pathology rebates and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will bring it back to size. Token gestures such as we find in this Budget, such as removing overseas student access to Medicare and replacing it with a tailor-made private medical and hospital insurance scheme, are not the answer.
I want to say something about that measure. It comes about as a result of a Government decision announced on page 124 of Budget Paper No. 1, which states:
The cost of providing Medicare services to overseas students will also be recouped, saving an estimated $0.6m in 1988-89 and $1.2m in a full year.

There was no explanation given for this decision, simply a bald statement of fact. This may not at first glance appear to be a very central issue in relation to the overall health budget, which is almost $11 billion. Put simply, the Government is asking private health insurance funds to prepare a special table of premiums to cover the medical and hospital insurance of overseas students.

I have two concerns about this. The first is that, since the introduction of Medicare on 1 February 1984, the private funds have been prohibited from providing medical insurance and they have no current costings on which to calculate this new premium. There is a very distinct possibility that, because of its special relationship with Medicare, Medibank Private will be well placed and advantaged in having access to such current information vis a vis the private health funds. That is concern No. 1.

Concern No. 2 is that private hospitals will be required to charge these students on a full cost recovery basis. I do not think it is too great a flight of fancy to suggest that this move may well be the tip of the iceberg, a softening up process which at some stage in the not too distant future could see all privately insured people being charged the full cost of any services they receive in public hospitals. If this comes to pass, it will be a further blow to private insurance, not only the health funds that provide that insurance but also the nation's need to encourage more and more Australians who can afford such private insurance to undertake such insurance. The problem of the waiting lists, which I identified in my earlier remarks comes about because so many Australians have abandoned private insurance and are clogging up our public hospital system to the disadvantage of the very people that the free and public system, Medicare, is supposed to assist. If the Government continues down that road and if this private overseas move is simply a toe in the water, in its own terms, it will hardly be compatible with the Government's promised free health care system which is supposedly designed to treat everyone as equals.

Of course, one does not have to dig around too much to penetrate this smokescreen. One only has to ask those people whose lives are dependent on the 53 drugs recently added to the authority only list of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. One has only to ask them if they think they are being treated fairly. I will give the House the example of a 12-year-old in my own electorate who is reliant on Epilim to control epilepsy. On visiting her neurologist on the morning of 27 September, she was prescribed more of the drug and the appropriate paperwork was dispatched to the Department. However, the approved prescription did not reach her until Monday, 3 October. Such a delay in receiving a prescription could well have placed her in a life-threatening situation and was in large part due to the fact that, even though the patient's name and address appeared on the prescription, the Department forwarded the authority to the medical practitioner.

I ask honourable members whether or not such an illustration of the operation of the new restrictions on the supply of drugs under the PBS arrangements represents either fairness or equity. Clearly it does not-any more than the ever-lengthening public hospital queues represent immediate access to health care in times of need.

The Government's ideologically motivated attacks on the private health care system, and on medical practitioners in particular, must also stop. The Government must accept before long the logic of the Liberal and National parties' position: that Australians will get the quality of health care they deserve only when there is an appropriate balance between the public and private health care services.

I return to that earlier analogy. The lumbering Medicare monster is not merely a creature whose time has passed; it is a creature whose time has never come, whose insatiable appetite for public funds has always clearly been beyond our means, and as a system it is approaching a crisis point. At the same time as the Government is shovelling more money in to feed this monster in its central concern, it is trying to snip around the edges in an effort to contain the cost blow-out. It simply will not work and before long this Government will have to face up to the fact that it is Medicare itself that is the problem.

Our health system was once amongst the best in the world. With the restoration of choice as a central element of health policy as advocated by us on this side of the House, we can again be up with the best of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to appropriations to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I have some 7,000 recipients of veterans' pensions in my electorate and I am pleased to say that the appropriations and, indeed, the Government's policies on veterans' affairs do them proud. Each and every one of those 7,000 or so veterans is well cared for by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I will detail briefly an account of some of the main features of the allocations of Veterans' Affairs. However, then I will raise what can only be described as a wildly inaccurate petition that is being circulated throughout the veteran community, which purports to criticise the Government for cutting back in some 15 areas of expenditure related to veterans. But first, I deal with the broad outline of expenditure.

It is clear that since we came to office expenditure in the portfolio has moved from $2.5 billion in the year 1988-89 to a total of $4.5 billion. We acknowledge that most of that increase is because pensions have been indexed and so many more people are at an age where they begin to pick up the service pension and, indeed, disability pensions. The point I wish to make is that we have held and increased the real value of those pensions, which are so important to the living standards of veterans. Beyond that, though, the fact is that we are also conscious that when people reach a certain age it is critical for them to maintain their health. So amongst a massive allocation that goes to pensions, we are also seeking to shift money into the health care system for pensioners. We have been able to increase the financial funding for those health and treatment programs by some 10.6 per cent. To illustrate that, some $17.5m has been spent on the Repatriation General Hospital at Greenslopes in Brisbane. As part of that, the Government intends to integrate the repatriation general hospitals into State health care systems. So not only are we continuing to spend money on the repatriation hospitals themselves but we want to integrate the repatriation hospitals with the State public sector hospitals. Why? As an example, Greenslopes in Brisbane is some 10 kilometres south of the Brisbane River. My electorate is 10, 15 and up to 25 kilometres north of the Brisbane River. It is a great deal to ask the wife of an ailing veteran to travel 20 or 30 kilometres to Greenslopes to visit that person. Therefore, we are seeking to provide all the best services of public sector hospitals to veterans-but never at the expense of the quality of the service that those veterans now receive in repatriation general hospitals.

I have a statistic which relates to the percentage of the treatment population and their distance from hospitals. Nearly 70 per cent of veteran pensioners live more than 15 kilometres away from repatriation hospitals. So it is only sensible to attempt to provide the services that veterans so dearly need closer to home, particularly as it relates to one of my areas, Redcliffe. It is such a long distance from Greenslopes that I believe in the near future pensioners in Redcliffe will be able to use the services of a nearby general hospital.

I refer to this enormous amount of misinformation that is circulating amongst the veteran community. I do not know who is circulating the petition. I am not suggesting it is any veteran group but on that petition are listed 15 accusations about how this Government is supposedly cutting back on veterans. The fact is that 14 of these accusations are absolutely wrong. One has some substance. I shall attempt to run through them. First was a complaint that the dependants pension has been deleted. The fact is that the dependants pension was a fairly ancient form of pension that was given to veterans' dependants. It has now simply been outmoded by things like the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. The level of those pensions had not been adjusted for children since 1952 and for wives since 1964. The complaint is about an ancient form of pension which has now been totally replaced through the general social security system. Therefore the first point is totally inaccurate.

The second complaint is that the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme does not apply to war widows, their dependants and service pensioners. The fact is that the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme caters for the needs of veterans with war caused disabilities. That has always been so. It is required that a veteran's problems be related to war in order for him to qualify under the scheme. Any other services are provided through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme operated by the Department of Community Services and Health.

Thirdly, there has been criticism about a reduction in dental benefits. Again, dental services for veterans with war caused disabilities are unlimited. However, we agree with, acknowledge and clarify the fact that there is a $300 limit on other people for certain sorts of expensive dental treatment, such as bridge work and gold inlays, and frankly that is not the sort of work that is normally done on pensioners' teeth.

Fourthly, there has been criticism relating to spectacles and the supposed deletion of the 10 per cent disability pension assessment. In the old days through the Commission it was often the case that a pensioner was given a 10 per cent incapacity rating simply because he had to wear glasses. With the introduction of the guide to the assessment of repatriation pensions, if there is no incapacity remaining once the glasses have been prescribed and are being worn, we simply do not rate it. That is not a great change. For instance, we do not normally allow an incapacity rating for those who wear false teeth, so I do not see any great change there.

The fifth criticism concerns an accusation that the Veterans' Entitlements Act took away the protection that totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) or special rate pensioners had once they reached the age of 65. The feeling was that perhaps beyond the age of 65 they might have their TPI pension taken away. Again, it was always implied in the Act-and we made it explicit in an amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act in December 1987-that when TPI and certain other pensions are granted, they are granted for life and they will not be taken away unless, of course, the circumstances change.

A sixth criticism is that there is no reimbursement of costs for medical opinions. I presume that this related to the fact that when an individual came before the Commission or the Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that person would have to supply the report. The fact is that there is adequate cover under the medical benefits schedule. There are item numbers which cover matters such as examination and written reports by doctors, so the pensioner is covered when he has to call on those reports to give them to the authorities.

A seventh criticism-also quite wrong-is that there is means testing of the veterans' children education scheme. That has occurred for years. The education allowances paid under the veterans' children education scheme have been subject to a measure of a student's income for a number years. So that criticism is also inaccurate. An eighth criticism-and I do not know where this came from-is that the intellectually handicapped dependants allowance was somehow cut out. There is no such thing as an intellectually handicapped dependants allowance paid for under the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The criticisms have been struck out eight times so far.

I will jump a few of the complaints because I realise that time is short. There is a criticism that there is no automatic admission to private hospitals without departmental approval. Private hospitalisation without departmental approval has never been a feature of the treatment system. There is no change there; it simply has not been a feature. But let us keep in mind that if there is an emergency it is possible for a veteran to go to a private hospital, or if there has been a negotiated agreement between the Department and the hospital the person can still go there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) I wish to impress upon him that there has been a series of cutbacks to veterans and war widows throughout this country and it does not do him any good to come in here and protest in the way that he has. Those cutbacks would have been all the greater had it not been for the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the attention that he paid to the adjustments and amendments made to the veterans' entitlements legislation about two years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted to speak on this occasion after the honourable member for Petrie because not only has he made certain allegations in connection with veterans, but in April this year he also made allegations against an organisation in Queensland called the Endeavour Foundation. On that occasion he accused the Foundation of being `vehement in its opposition to the Disability Services Act'. That is what I wish to speak about today. In actual fact the Endeavour Foundation has not been vehement in its opposition, but it has been deeply concerned about the lack of guidelines and cooperation given by the Department of Community Services and Health in the implementation of this Act. It is generally agreed that when that legislation came before this Parliament it had support from both sides of the House. It is in the guidelines and in the gazetting of certain things that the problems have arisen.

When the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), was here he talked about the socialisation of health. In both this Act and the others administered by the Department we have greater control of services by both the Government and the Department passing under the guise of greater accountability. For example, it appears that private suppliers to the disability area are not getting satisfaction, and this might happen in advance.

I return to the question of the Endeavour Foundation. This is not a profit-making private organisation. If there is profit in what the Foundation does, that profit is returned to additional services for which it often receives no subsidy at all. The Foundation is not in this field with its hand out. It is not catering for the disabled of this nation in the hope that it will profit from them. On all occasions I have found the Endeavour Foundation to be very good suppliers. The honourable member for Petrie mentioned the case of a Mrs X. In response to the allegations that he made, I must say that I have quite a few references and they are all in favour of the Foundation and what it is doing.

I return to the point that there is a grave lack of progress being made in talks with the Department on establishing guidelines. This matter was referred to me more than 12 months ago and I have had recent letters and representations from concerned organisations to suggest that they have not yet received satisfaction. While there have been gazettals of principles and objectives and also of the operational starting date, unless there is a gazettal of the service types under the guidelines the Government will not be able to satisfy these people because they do not want to buy a pig in a poke and go towards 1992 without some assurance that the service models are those that they can agree and work with. They are not against change; they want to work within the system. I suggest that the Government and the Department would do well to listen to the advice of experts in this matter because they have been suppliers in so many ways-in indoor and outdoor activities, sports, residential activities and so on.

The honourable member for Petrie claimed that we should deinstitutionalise. Perhaps we should say that we do not want to deinstitutionalise large institutions in order to get people into smaller institutions. If we are talking about removal of institutions, perhaps we should be looking at the education area and our boarding schools. We should be looking at the prisons. We should be looking at the nursing homes and those lines of things because in their own way they are institutions. There is nothing wrong with an institution that is properly run, that gives advantages to the disabled, advantages which they would otherwise not have. I give my support to contradict what was said in that grievance debate, because there were lots of inaccuracies as there were in connection with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I also suggest that they have a legitimate complaint and that they would like to work and move with departmental officers.

I now move to the area of day care and pick up on some of the comments that have been made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in this regard. Everybody knows that he has come in for some criticism from within his own Party and from within the Caucus about suggestions he has made to cut back the contributions from the Commonwealth in order that reductions can be made. I have here a regulatory impact statement entitled Children's Services Centres Regulations which was put out by the Victorian Government. It has put up a series of deregulation moves all of which are intended, yet again, not as accountability measures but as control measures. Somewhere along the line somebody has said that in exchange for the provision of 20 per cent of the cost, the Commonwealth wants to take control. This is a State government report. It was commissioned on the basis of deregulation in order to provide more trained staff within the care centres. Coupled with that was a costing requirement. This report gives a costing-I think it is on page 97-which suggests that this increase will be minimal, something like 1.5 per cent per year over a period of five years. In actual fact, this report was commissioned some three years ago. It has sat with the Government since May this year. It was released to the public in August this year and the public was given 21 days to respond, which was impossible given that no input was sought from the voluntary organisations.

The cost of this to the Government will be horrific. But worse than that, it will remove the private day care centres that are in existence in Victoria at the moment. Queensland has refused to accept this direction but other States have. In fact, I believe that Tasmania has accepted it to such an extent that the private institutions have gone right out the back door. This report has that capacity. The report has been issued not only in the manner that I indicated but also on false premises. As I said, costing measures were given which do not give the full story. The costing of the additional amounts goes back to 1984 to an award that is no longer included. Organisations and unions will welcome that in the future. In fact, the costing done by a firm of chartered accountants indicates that it will be five or six times the cost indicated in the report. We have had Senator Walsh questioning the cost of child care subsidies. In the Australian newspaper on 10 October 1988 he admitted that subsidising community centres was costing $177 a week in operating costs and $20-odd for capital; that is $197 all up per week. The private day care centres can provide for this at a rate of $70 to $75 per day. So, I suggest to the Minister again that when reports like this come to his notice he do everything that he can to put the proper situation, particularly in view of the concerns of Senator Walsh in this direction. I believe that whatever the area is, whether it is in relation to the disabled, nursing homes for the aged or certainly within child care centres, there is a place for the private system to operate in and compete with the community system. It is up to the Government to ensure that the cost that we keep seeing burgeoning out is curtailed but, at the same time, that the very good standard set by the private system-I believe also by the community based system-is maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address most of my comments in this committee stage to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The first thing I would like to do is to read a letter from Mr John Haines, the President of the New South Wales branch of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia (VVAA) to the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales. It is addressed to a Mr M. J. C. Cook of the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,

I write to you regarding a letter received from your office informing this Association of resolution passed by the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales on 27th July 1988, which indicates a means test will be applied by the Commission on Veteran Affairs matters including appearances by Lay Advocates before Veterans Review Board, Appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court.

I wish to offer, on behalf of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, a most severe protest at this means test which if implemented will cause undue and unnecessary hardship to Vietnam Veteran wishing to pursue an appeal through a process that has been available to them for some period of time.
