Your letter, does not set out the reasons for this new imposition, one can only assume it is another way of reneging on a commitment made to the Australian Returned Serviceman.

My initial investigation indicates that upon the transfer of the Australian Legal Aid Office to the Legal Aid Commission of NSW, there was nothing in the agreement that suggested a Means Test be applied in Veterans Affairs matters when the merger took place.

Also I have been informed that sufficient funding was transferred at the time of the merger to allow on going funding that would provide funds for a continuation of Legal Aid as was provided for by the Australian Legal Aid Office.
If this Means Test is allowed to be implemented it will deny Legal Aid to a very high percentage of Ex Service persons.

I would ask that I be allowed to discuss this matter further with members of the Commission so that a severe injustice will not be placed upon those members of the Community who were willing to offer their service for their Community.

This letter addresses something which I am very concerned about and something which I believe the shadow Minister at the table is also concerned about. It is a decision of the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales to abolish secretly the right of veterans in New South Wales to legal aid. When legal aid was provided by the Australian Legal Aid Offices (ALAO), veterans had an automatic right to obtain this free legal advice. I know that I and other members from New South Wales often suggest that veterans who come to see their local member with a problem should speak to the ALAO to obtain independent legal advice before going to the Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or, hopefully in rare cases, the Federal Court.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act is so complex that veterans need to have that legal advice to make sure that they have every opportunity of gaining benefits to which they are entitled. Therefore, I am extremely disturbed that a New South Wales Government statutory authority, under the Greiner Government, has decided to abolish this right of veterans in New South Wales to get legal aid. That is something which John Haines, President of the New South Wales branch of the VVAA, has rightly expressed his concern and outrage about. I have been personally contacted by the Hunter Valley and Central Coast Sub-Branch of the Vietnam Veterans Association. They have told me that they are very upset by this decision of the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales. I have taken the liberty of taking this matter up with both the Federal Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and the Federal Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). They advised me in September this year that they wrote to the Attorney-General of New South Wales, Mr John Dowd, asking him to reverse that decision. I understand that to date Mr Dowd, as far as I am aware, has not answered the correspondence from the Federal Ministers.

I think we should understand the circumstances behind this decision. When the Australian Legal Aid Offices was amalgamated with the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales the Federal Government agreed to provide funding to the new Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales. I believe that that is a sum of many millions of dollars. Within that allocation, I understand, there is at least $500,000 from the Federal Government to the New South Wales Government to provide continuing free legal aid to veterans. Yet the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales, a State independent authority, has taken it upon itself to abolish the right of veterans to get legal aid. I think that is something that people on both sides of the chamber should totally condemn. This body is still accepting the money from the Federal Government yet it is no longer giving veterans in New South Wales the right to obtain that legal advice. This is a matter which I mentioned briefly to the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the week before last. He told me that he would be making inquiries into this matter as well. I hope that he will speak to his Liberal and National Party colleagues who are Ministers in the Greiner Government to have this decision overturned as soon as possible.

What I find even more outrageous is that this decision was made in secret in July this year-a decision which would affect the right of veterans to obtain legal aid from 1 September this year-yet veterans in my electorate, and I am sure in other New South Wales electorates, were simply not told about this decision. Once again, I think that is something which leaves a lot to be desired about open government in New South Wales.

I wish to mention some other matters in passing today in this committee debate. First of all, I wish to commend the Government for speedily implementing the major recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. I believe that the Government has done the right thing in picking up those major recommendations to increase the extreme disability allowance. I am concerned about some of the speculation which has appeared in the media about the transfer of repatriation hospitals to the State Health Commissions. However, I understand that the Federal Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has promised that, as part of the negotiations, he will be ensuring that there is not some fire sale handover of the veterans' repatriation hospitals to the State health commissions. I think that is very important. There is no need to rush into this.

The Minister has said that he is keen to negotiate an agreement with the State health departments so that veterans will be given priority at local general hospitals. If that can be achieved in my electorate it will mean that veterans on the central coast of New South Wales will not be forced to travel to Concord in Sydney to have operations. It means that their families will not have to travel by public transport for many hours to visit veterans who are in hospital. If the Minister can provide me with a guarantee that the transfer of Concord at some stage in the future will provide my veterans with priority treatment at Gosford District Hospital, that will be something that will greatly benefit veterans in my electorate. As I have said, that will save them from having to travel great distances.

The last thing I want to touch on in the time available to me is a proposal by the Central Coast and Hunter Valley Vietnam Veterans Association to construct a hostel in my electorate. I understand that the Vietnam Veterans Association in my electorate has had negotiations with the Department of Community Services and Health with the aim of submitting an application for this hostel later this financial year. I wish to place on record my total support for this proposal which has been named Operation Hostel. I will certainly be encouraging the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, to ensure that the Government gives every possible consideration to this project because it will be of great assistance not only to Vietnam veterans but also to other veterans and their families in my electorate.

It is with great pleasure that I am able to support the decision for this amount of funding which is before the chamber at the moment. Once again I appeal to all members of this chamber to look very closely at this secret decision by the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission to abolish the right of veterans in New South Wales to obtain legal aid. I hope that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Farrer, who is at the table, will ensure that his promise to me to follow this up with his Liberal and National Party colleagues in New South Wales will be carried out as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I wish to speak predominantly to the estimates of the Department of Veterans' Affair, I wish to ask the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, to convey my deepest personal sympathy, and that of my many colleagues, to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in this very distressing and sad time for him.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs I want to place on record that, in all my parliamentary service, probably the most satisfying and fulfilling period was when I had the privilege to be Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I struck a rapport with veterans and their dependants throughout the whole of Australia and they still come and talk to me.

Although the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) said that he was very satisfied with the Budget allocation for the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the way that it was going-he read out a list of complaints-I want to assure him that the veterans are far from a happy community. They are a very concerned community. The veterans of his own electorate, which virtually adjoins mine, talk to me. I want to bring some of those concerns before the chamber because I believe that not one of us will not admit that the standard of living, the way of life and the freedoms that we have in this country were very dearly bought for us and defended by our veterans. I remember very well that, when we were recruiting in war-time and men and women were being coaxed to join the Services, many unqualified commitments and promises were made to them. What worries me now is that the time has come to meet some of those pledges and promises and we are trying to back off. We are trying to dilute some of the commitments and the promises that were made.

As I have very few minutes in which to speak let me outline some of the concerns that veterans bring to my attention. One is medication. The changes in the national health scheme (NHS) list have caused very great concern and alarm to veterans. When they go to their medical officers and are given prescriptions they find that they have been removed from the NHS list. When inquiries are made they are told that there are substitutes. Sometimes there are substitutes, that is true, but in many cases the substitutes are not acceptable to the doctors. They have tried them and they have said that they are not acceptable; they are not effective. What is worrying many of the doctors who ring me is that prescriptions are apparently to be written by the bureaucracy rather than the medical officers. I want the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) to take on board the concern that I and members from all over the chamber are getting from veterans who are unable to continue with the medication that has been effective over many years because of these changes. The letters that we get back when we write to the Department of Community Services and Health or the other departments are not the sorts of things that give confidence or comfort to veterans who are in this position.

I want to talk very briefly about the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) and disability pensions. These have been attacked; there is no question about that. Honourable members should ask any of the veterans. The concept of the TPI pension being a replacement pension for not being able to work is one that I have never accepted. I did not accept that when I was Minister; nor do I believe the Department implemented it in that way. It is not a pension; it is a compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Let me say again that it is a compensation. I believe that we ought to remember that very many men, and perhaps women also, were not capable of working when they came back from the wars but they did work. When they ought not to have worked they did not accept a pension and they did not accept a disability allowance. Because of their self-esteem and because they did not want to be cast off by society they struggled on and, at the end of the day, when they cannot work any longer, they find that they are not going to be given a TPI pension. They are not eligible because of this new concept of the TPI pension. I believe that this is unfair and unjust. It is unfair and unjust not only to the men themselves but also to their wives who have supported them, helped them and nursed them through the time that they have tried to work and put in this productive effort. Because they are denied the TPI pension these women, who have stood by them for so long, are denied the war widow's pension at the end of the day. I am not very happy with this new concept. I do not believe it is a compassionate or fair concept. I assure honourable members that no matter what is said it is a new concept. It did not apply eight years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that was mentioned today related to repatriation hospitals. Let us make no mistake, the veterans are very concerned about the prospect of their repatriation hospitals being absorbed into the State hospital system and that repatriation hospitals as such will disappear altogether. The requirement for repatriation hospitals has not yet, in my opinion, reached its peak. Veterans are becoming older and their disabilities are being exacerbated by the process of ageing. We have not yet seen the repatriation hospitals taxed as much as they will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Average age, 71.

—That is true. I believe that means that the repatriation hospitals ought to be preserved as repatriation hospitals. Where there are none in the outer centres-and I agree with my colleague from the other side, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee)-the general hospital system ought to be able to accommodate repatriation patients to save them long trips and trauma. It has happened in my time that some of the beds in repatriation hospitals were opened to the public if they were not required by entitled veterans. That is fair enough. That makes sense. We ought not to have empty beds in hospitals. Unfortunately, there is some sadness there because even non-entitled veterans feel that the repatriation hospitals are their hospitals. If they are sick they like to go there. Unfortunately, if they are not entitled, very often that does not happen. That is sad. I appeal to the Minister and I appeal to the Government: do not precipitately get rid of the repatriation hospitals and give them to the State hospital system.
—They have been trying to do it for years.

—Yes, they were trying to do it in my time. This ought not to be done. There is another difficulty in Government policy and it relates to the whole scheme of nursing home assistance. I am concerned about the way this is working. I am repeatedly told that I have enough nursing home beds in my area for the population that I serve. I wonder why it is then that all of these nursing homes have impossible waiting lists that are years long. Why are the doctors ringing me saying that they are worried silly? It is because they cannot get people into these nursing homes. Why are anxious relatives beating a path to my door? It is because there are no nursing home beds available. Perhaps some people can get them if they go far away, but I do not think that is a particularly good solution. If it were not for that excellent repatriation nursing home complex in Caboolture, which used to be in my electorate, we would have nothing within cooee of where I live. I am concerned about that aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister not to listen to the Department of the Treasury which has been saying for eight or 10 years that service pensions ought to be absorbed into the age pension system because after all it is only the age pension paid earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Kiss of death.

—Yes. There are departmental officers sitting in the chamber. Perhaps some of them have been in the Department a long time. This is not a new song; it is something that has been tried and tried. If the Government wants to get the veterans offside and absolutely destroy their self-respect that is the way to go. Veterans call the TPI the diggers' burnt out pension. Let us not let it become an age pension or a social security handout. I ask the Minister to remember that these fellows are on compensation; they are not being propped up by pensions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to make comments on the appropriation for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I wanted particularly to comment on the home and community care (HACC) program, but the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) mentioned the future integration of repatriation general hospitals into the various State systems.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal has my support. What must be said is that the decision was made bearing in mind that, under the agreements that need to be entered into with the State authorities, the health care services available to veterans should be maintained. In the comments of the honourable members I mentioned who preceded me, there was agreement on that point. We should not look upon the proposal with the great degree of fear that has been expressed. It is important to recognise that the Government has taken a softly, softly approach to this proposal. It is not something that we have raced into. It is something that has been recognised and it requires a great deal of cooperation by the Federal Government through the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the various State authorities. It is a proposal which has been well researched. Various committees have looked at the proposal. The final recommendations that are being enacted at the moment come out of the report of the Brand Committee of Review of the Repatriation Hospital System of 1984. We should see it in that context. It is something that can strengthen the health care services that are available to veterans. It is a continuing recognition of the Government's requirement to provide services for those who serve the country so well in times of conflict.

As I said at the outset, I wish to refer to the HACC program. It is obvious that the program is designed to prevent the premature institutionalisation of aged and disabled people. Its aim is to enable more people to live at home rather than in a hostel or nursing home. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his contribution at the committee stage of the debate on the appropriation for the Department of Social Security earlier this day, described the HACC program as a visionary program. That is true. That description recognises the great degree of work done by many people, particularly ex-Senator Don Grimes, both as the responsible Minister after the election of the Hawke Government and in particular as the shadow Minister during his years in opposition.

It has to be said that the present Opposition has not come to grips with its role. It has not necessarily kept its eye on alternative policies. If we look at the proposals that were put forward in the recent Victorian State election we will see that the Liberal Party went into that election without releasing a community services policy. In fact, the only reference made to those services was a brief reference in Opposition Leader Kennett's policy speech. He stated that a Liberal Government would build more nursing homes to help the elderly. So we have a winding back, a change in attitude about the direction. I am not sure whether his Federal colleagues agree that that is appropriate. But certainly whilst this Government has a continuing commitment to the provision of nursing home beds and, in particular, hostel beds, it has an overriding commitment to putting in place measures to ensure that more people can stay at home in familiar surroundings.

I recently attended a function at which the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, was a guest speaker. It was the annual general meeting of the Bundoora Extended Care Centre. I think the Minister impressed those who were there with his enthusiasm for his portfolio. He paid tribute to the work being done at the Bundoora Extended Care Centre through its geriatric assessment unit and its provision of a wide range of aged care services in the north-eastern region of suburban Melbourne. In the past the Minister has indicated that Government research has shown that old people much prefer to retain their independence, living at home for as long as possible, rather than entering residential care. In addition, HACC is less expensive than providing long term residential care.

This year over $209m will be set aside for the HACC program. This is an increase from $169m in 1987-88 and reflects the importance the Government attaches to the provision of home-based services according to need. HACC services are an integral part of the Government's aged care policy, providing better quality of life through a wide range of services. The diversity of those services should be recognised. Members of the aged population, like other members of the population, have varying needs. If they require such things as a home gardening service or a home maintenance service to enable them to stay in their homes, why is it not appropriate that those services be provided?

The issue of aged care is a matter of growing concern to the community. That is as much about the demographics of the population as anything else. As a consequence, the Hawke Government has made policy and program development for the aged a central policy issue. It is a central issue in the context of the Government's commitment to social justice. The HACC program has been a key element in the Government's strategy for the care of frail aged people and people with disabilities. It entails a shift in emphasis from residential care to community based care.

The national guidelines for the program, released in April this year, were developed in consultation with State governments and community groups and provide a broad understanding of the program. They also point to a number of areas where further development and review of the program is needed and ongoing. This process should be seen as a fine-tuning of the program. Some of the issues concerning the program which have been raised in the community include resource distribution. There is evidence of inequality in the allocation of resources among the States and of funds between regions within the States. That is a cause for concern. It is appropriate that any government program should be well targeted. It should address the needs of those whom the program was intended to help.

There are a number of elements as to why this resource distribution requires further work. There is the matter of historical context. The HACC program subsumed a number of services previously funded under a variety of Acts. We have brought those programs together under the one umbrella. There is a need to continue, where appropriate, the projects funded under those Acts. There is also a need to review the funding arrangements.

At the time of the recent Auditor-General's audit efficiency report the services that were previously funded under other legislation constituted 85 per cent of the program. Therefore, 2,380 former Commonwealth-funded programs and 1,665 new projects or extensions of projects receive HACC funding. In this way the determinants for funding under HACC are predominantly historical. As I said, as in other areas of government expenditure there is a need to ensure that the outcomes of such programs as the HACC program are the intended outcomes-that they provide the services to the appropriate people. I hope that is something the Government will take on board. I have pleasure in supporting the estimates before the Committee today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In the context of this debate I point out to the Committee that at this moment Vietnam veterans are gathering in Melbourne for their special international reunion, which has been planned for several months. It was a privilege to attend the formal civil reception in respect of the Vietnam veterans' international reunion at the Melbourne Town Hall, albeit briefly, earlier today. I hope that the reunion, which will culminate in a number of observances and commemorations and a march on Saturday, is an outstanding success.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with some of the honourable members who have spoken in the debate on the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. As far as the coalition side is concerned, I was delighted with the comments of the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann). As part of our team approach to this debate, he emphasised the compensatory nature of all service personnel pensions, Vietnam veterans' pensions, war widows' pensions and the like. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt), who will also be speaking, will spell out some of the policy aspects of the coalition with regard to a fair go for veterans but, of course, in the context of the Budget Estimates debate. I will be dealing with the extreme disability adjustment and the Australian War Memorial as time permits.

Turning to the Government members, the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) argued the case that there had been only one cutback. He failed to nominate that one cutback. Let me say to the honourable member for Petrie and to the Government that there have been a wide range of cutbacks and complex changes in the repatriation area ever since the May mini-Budget of 1985. Let me point out some of the details of those cutbacks. Let us take the poor old Defence Force retirement benefits (DFRB) pensioner for argument's sake. Those pensioners have been hit with a 2 per cent cut which this Government said it would reinstate after a short period. The only thing wrong with that was that the Government did it in such a way that it is a continuing 2 per cent cut to DFRB recipients. It is a breach of obligation, a breach of contract. Even in the most recent Budget, now before the Committee by way of Estimates, there has been no indication that there will be rectification of that cutback.

Let us take the case of war widows. What did the Government do to them in 1986? Not only did it eliminate them from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, but also it froze at $60 the social security component of a war widow's package, and in such a way that it is not indexed in any way. So its real value is continuing to erode. Then there is the position of veterans generally, particularly country veterans. During a Senate Estimates committee hearing yesterday we flushed out the Department and the officials in respect of the country travel allowance. I can confirm to the Committee that the 1985 May mini-Budget-that horror Budget for veterans-which slashed the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension arrangements also halved the travel allowance paid to veterans to go from Gippsland to the repatriation general hospital or to specialists in Melbourne and to veterans from Goulburn, in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), to go to Sydney from 27c to 11.16c a kilometre.

Since May 1985 there has been only one increase, a very generous increase of 1.12c last year. It is now the princely amount of 12.28c per kilometre. That is about half the Public Service rate. It is still less than half of what the veterans were receiving prior to May 1985. That is a very real cutback which I highlight to this Committee in the context of the remarks made for the honourable member for Petrie.

I noted the points made by the honourable members who have spoken with particular interest, including those of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). He referred to a complex matter-legal advice. I am waiting for some further information on that matter. I am quite confident that there is nothing but sympathy on the part of the New South Wales State Liberal-National Party Government for the plight of the Vietnam veterans and the veterans generally. I am sure that the honourable member for Dobell did not intend to suggest otherwise.

I turn to the Budget initiative which was taken from the coalition policy released in the winter recess, which, in turn, was taken in part from the independent monitoring committee report, released after the coalition policy but prior to the Budget, and that is the introduction of the extreme disablement adjustment-a new initiative for which we have been fighting for two years or more to try to overcome the TPI anomaly.

This new extreme disablement adjustment, or EDA, was the centrepiece of the coalition's fair go for veterans policy and it provides that veterans in the retirement phase who no longer have access to the TPI arrangements following the May 1985 mini-Budget and the Veterans' Entitlement Act at least will be able to apply under certain criteria for the extreme disablement adjustment which will come in at 150 per cent of the general disability rate. The centrepiece of the coalition policy, I am pleased to say, has now been adopted in this Budget, just a couple of months after our policy was released. I welcome that and give credit to the Government for taking up this aspect of the coalition policy which was also an aspect of the independent monitoring committee report. It goes part of the way, but only part of the way, towards resolving the TPI anomaly. Time does not allow me to detail all the ramifications of the EDA-for argument's sake, the fact that the war widows' eligibility aspect is not dealt with-but we await the legislation which will flow from the passage of this Budget in respect of the extreme disablement adjustment. Hopefully it will be administered in a way which, for once, leans in favour of rather than against the plight of the poor veteran, whose average age now is 71-as confirmed by officials yesterday-and who is sick and tired of these complex changes, sick and tired of the cutbacks and sick and tired of the new arrangements for example on income assessment, which the Government has already backed down on in relation to this Budget, and the retrospective aspects of that package. The extreme disablement adjustment is a most worthwhile step forward but it does not completely solve the problem. However, I welcome it because it was the centrepiece of the coalition's veterans' affairs policy, released during the winter recess.

I turn now to the Australian War Mem- orial, which was the subject of a number of detailed questions in Estimates committee hearings and the estimates of which are before the Committee at the present. There is trouble in the Australian War Memorial once again. The officials giving evidence yesterday confirmed that four key executive personnel had, for one reason or another, left the Australian War Memorial over recent weeks and that there are staffing problems there. To quote one of the officials giving evidence, there is a feeling of frustration, especially in terms of the cutbacks of staffing which have occurred-quite savage cutbacks in terms of the original establishment of some 254.

I realise that there must be priorities and that there is a very finite Government expenditure dollar especially in respect of veterans' affairs. However, some progress is being made, for example, with savings from the overpayment of service pensions-an amount of $5m listed in the Repatriation Commission's annual report for this financial year-and if only half of that was applied as a reordering of priorities within the Department of Veterans' Affairs umbrella it would be possible to solve overnight the problems associated with that priceless collection of significant military history and memorabilia which is held in our Australian War Memorial. I strongly support, and my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties strongly support, the traditional role of the Australian War Memorial and its being provided with the wherewithal to meet that traditional role in a dignified, appropriate and extended manner.

I believe the Government needs to look carefully again at what is happening in the Australian War Memorial, what is happening with staffing, and look again at the priorities associated with the allocations within the overall Department of Veterans' Affairs umbrella to ensure that the Australian War Memorial and its very significant collections which go to the heart of the history and heritage of this nation are maintained in a safe and appropriate manner. I believe I would have the support of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel across Australia in relation to those comments on the Australian War Memorial. We members of the Opposition parties express our concern over these priorities but welcome the introduction of the extreme disablement adjustment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to veterans and the Budget. I spoke earlier today on the plight of retirees and pensioners in Australia under the Hawke Labor Government. Pensioners and veterans alike are getting a rough deal in this latest Budget of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), so much so that their plight can only be called a national disgrace. The Government's constant rule changing since the reform of the Australian tax system has left thousands upon thousands of Australians in the dark as to their future security.

SPEECH.PARA: People trying to plan their retirements are being frustrated to the extreme by the Treasurer's procession of announcements which make sweeping changes to the status quo. People who have worked their whole lives building this nation, fighting and dying for king and country, are being robbed of the pensions and entitlements they have always believed would be there. At an average age of 71 years, these people are probably too tired to fight but I am more than happy to take up the cudgels on their behalf. As the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), often quotes, Prime Minister Ben Chifley said of the war:
The careers of hundreds of thousands of young men-
young men and women-
have been interrupted and, in some instances, partially ruined . . . On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.

It might be a grand new building that we are in but it is the same Parliament with the same responsibilities to the people who have served Australia. The Opposition clearly recognises that responsibility in the coalition veterans' affairs policy, providing new, efficient initiatives relating to the theme `a fair go for veterans'.

In summary, our policy commits a Liberal-National Party Government to: retaining a separate, modern Department of Veterans' Affairs; continuing to provide for an extreme disablement adjustment for veterans in the retirement phase of their lives who suffer further serious war related impairment at the 150 per cent disability pension rate; further improving the repatriation hospital system throughout Australia; continuing to monitor closely the operation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act and the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions; maintaining the independent monitoring committee; removing all forms of sex discrimination in relation to repatriation legislation; completing the transfer of the private sector of the Defence Service Home Loans Corporation and providing for improvements to the defence service home loans scheme when economic resources permit, including the portability of existing loans; retaining the national flag and maintaining the traditional role of the Australia War Memorial, as referred to by the honourable member for Farrer; and granting the Vietnam Medal to those who served on HMAS Sydney and other logistical support vessels during the Vietnam conflict. This weekend I was with a group of South Vietnamese veterans, army and navy personnel, who had a fundraiser at Athol Park. Mr Chung, Mr Tran and Mr Ho headed up that, and they were raising funds to march in Melbourne this weekend to link arms with our Vietnam veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should take John Howard along too.

—I thank the Minister. The Returned Services League (RSL) and veterans groups in my electorate of Adelaide, certainly those that I have been to at Kilburn and Prospect, are concerned about the shabby deal being dealt to them by the Hawke Labor Government. Petitions, I am sure, have been circulated by members on both sides of the House concerning the removal of 53 veterans from the pharmaceutical arrangements scheme, and it is pleasing to those items and to the RSL that the cases of at least 40 of those 53 have come back to be reviewed.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the deepest of veterans' concerns is the Government's move to divest the Commonwealth of repatriation hospitals throughout the country by the mid-1990s. I refer to the repatriation hospital in Daw Park, which is likely to be absorbed into the State transfer scheme. These men and women understand that the repatriation hospital is like their second home. They want that comfort and the security. Their average age is now 71 years. By the mid-1990s their age and infirmity will become more apparent. As the great body of Australia's returned service personnel enter the period of life when they most need medical attention, the Hawke Labor Government is proposing to wipe its hands of the responsibilities identified by Ben Chifley, of `seeing that the right thing shall be done'. Again we have this situation where a lifetime of planning for a secure retirement-in this case security in the knowledge of adequate medical entitlements-is being shattered at the eleventh hour by the Government changing the rules, reneging on its responsibilities.

As I said earlier when speaking on pensions and superannuation, retirement is a big issue. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) accused me of political opportunism, thinking that I would not be able to reply. The Minister claims to have improved the lot of pensioners by increasing the pension by some 8 per cent in real terms. The Minister's claim is a blatant distortion of the facts and I challenge the Government to get the Australian Bureau of Statistics to endorse it. Perhaps he should take a leaf from the book of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who said earlier today that pensioners ought to be those in the community to whom we give special respect. I applaud him for using my line. The same thing applies to our veterans.

We have an obligation to give these people, veterans and pensioners alike, that special respect and not to create misery, anxiety and anguish over the future. The Minister accuses me of opportunism over the maltreatment of these people, but he should consider that I might be speaking out on their behalf because I think they are getting a tough deal. If members on the government benches think they are doing such a great job, perhaps they should come along with me and meet some of my constituents, who are sick with sorry over the constant procession of changes to the rules. One facet which was brought to my attention was the suggestion that perhaps the Department should make all veterans members of the St John Ambulance scheme at a cost of about $26 per head. When the St John Ambulance is called, rather than having to pay an average of $126 to take a veteran to hospital he would in fact be linked into the St John Ambulance scheme, there-by saving about $100.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—A saving of $100. Multiply that factor across the number of veterans in Australia and I think it would be a worthwhile exercise that I am happy to pursue and give to the relevant Minister.
—But will they regard it in the same light?

—I hope they do. There is no greater gift that one can give one's fellow man than to give one's life. Australian men and women did that. I will always be conscious of their efforts to make this country free and democratic. Payment of pensions to our veterans is compensation and not welfare, as previously stated. The motto of the veterans and war widows of Australia is `Lest We Forget'. I say to the Minister: We must never forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in this debate to say just a little about those aspects of this portfolio which deal with the housing industry. It is incumbent on me to express the view on behalf of the Opposition that there are really fundamental differences between the approach of the Government to the housing industry and the approach of the Opposition. There are fundamental differences of practical policy but, more than that, there are fundamental differences of philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the way the housing industry is going in Australia today, and of course the Government's budgetary policies in relation to housing have to be taken in that context, then in terms of construction there is no doubt that the industry is strong. The Indicative Planning Council estimates this year that there will be somewhere between 150,000 and 160,000 housing commencements. This represents an enormous upturn from the disastrous collapse in the industry in 1985-86, when commencements declined by 11.1 per cent, and in 1986-87, when they declined by 14.5 per cent. Obviously it is good to see that there has been an improvement in those commencements.

The trouble is that the industry has been moving madly, like a big dipper, up and down and that has created all sorts of pressures which if we had a more stable housing industry would not have been necessary. One of the reasons why the industry moves up and down is natural cyclical factors, and one would expect some movement up and down. However, I think the reason why the industry has moved so dramatically over the last few years is that so many of the Government's economic policies have impinged particularly heavily on the housing industry. For example, the Government has used interest rates as almost its sole instrument of economic management. Housing interest rates have gone up, not just over the last year, when they rose from 13.5 per cent to 14.5 per cent not just in the last week when they rose in some instances, particularly for those people who have home loans or are taking out home loans with Citibank Ltd, to 15 per cent but over the whole period this Government has been in office, when they have risen from 11.5 per cent to 14.5 per cent. That represents an enormous increase in the burden on people taking out home loans.

I recall that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table during this committee stage debate, put out a press release before the Victorian election, responding to something that I and some of my colleagues had said about the prospect of housing interest rates rising after the Victorian election. The Minister said that it was nonsense that they would rise. The Minister was wrong. The State Bank of South Australia increased its home loan interest rates straight after the Victorian election and Citibank, which of course impinges more on Victoria than does the State Bank of South Australia, also increased its interest rates. We all know that there is enormous pressure on other banks to increase their home loan interest rates. Interest rate pressures have been a major problem for the industry. So has the fact that there have been 23 major changes to government housing policy over the five years that the Australian Labor Party has been in office.

The upturn in construction that we have had in the last few months has brought with it its own problems because the industry has come from such a deep trough. Subcontract rates are increasing at something like 20 per cent a year in markets such as Sydney, Brisbane and Perth. In a city such as Perth building costs are increasing by well over 2 per cent a month. We can see, therefore, that through both interest rates and the increases in the costs of building new houses the costs to home purchasers and potential home purchasers are absolutely enormous, and more and more people are consequently being excluded from the housing market. It is well known now, as a national statistic, that 170,000 people are on waiting lists for public housing, 45,000 in the State of South Australia alone. The waiting time on those housing lists is four to five years.

The Government's policy is basically that it does not support the principle of home ownership. That is why it is unconcerned about its main instrument of economic policy being interest rates, which is making it so hard for so many people to purchase their own homes. That is why the Government has reduced the first home owners scheme so dramatically-by 42 per cent in the last three years. By 1991 it will be reduced by 75 per cent, according to the Government's own forward projections. That makes it all the more difficult for new first home owners to put down a basic deposit and, in addition, to meet mortgage repayments on their first homes. In my view, the Government is ideologically committed to the whole concept of public housing. Although on this side of the Committee we recognise the importance of public housing, and we are not for one minute saying there is no role for public housing in our society to help those in particular need, we do not think it is the only solution. In contrast, that clearly is the Government's view.

It is interesting to reflect on what the report of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty said in relation to public housing. The point Henderson made was that there are a considerable number of people in public housing, which is designed to help low income, economically disadvantaged people, who are well off and who do not need that sort of support. By way of illustration to support the Henderson report, honourable members may be aware that one person who has been a beneficiary of public housing is a member of the Senate, Senator Devlin. Senator Devlin is a very lucky man. He has his own senatorial parliamentary salary. In addition, his wife works for him on his electoral staff. So they have a family income, excluding electoral allowances, in the vicinity of $80,000 a year, which is not bad. I think honourable members would agree. Senator Devlin is in a Tasmanian government house for which he pays $74 a week rent. For a family on $80,000 a year to be taking up that kind of urgently needed public accommodation, as Senator Devlin is doing, I submit is completely wrong.

The Australian Labor Party often pretends that it is concerned about the disadvantaged, yet we discover that Senator Devlin is taking a house away from the disadvantaged. That simply exposes the contradictions and cynicism of so many of the arguments that it puts to the electorate. Senator Devlin lives in Burnie. In Burnie there are 400 people on the waiting list for public housing. That may not concern Government Ministers, but it is a matter of gigantic concern to those 400 people in Burnie. Senator Devlin is taking away one of those places. In North West Tasmania 900 people are on waiting lists for public housing. Senator Devlin's public housing is costing him $74 a week. His wife works for him at taxpayers' expense as an electorate assistant.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Yes, she works for him. He and his wife are earning about $80,000 a year, excluding his electorate allowance. I think you would agree, Mr Deputy Chairman, that it is a pretty astonishing fact, but a very important illustration of the way in which the Government's ideological commitment to public housing has led to these sorts of anomalies. I hope that Senator Devlin is alone amongst members of this Parliament in depriving low income people of much needed housing, but he is probably not alone amongst high income earners who are also benefiting from the inequities that exist in public housing policies for which, ultimately, the Commonwealth has so much responsibility. Study after study has been produced for the Government to show that it would help the disadvantaged more if it channelled more assistance through the private sector, if it gave more support to the first home owners scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the Minister who is at the table knows only too well that the Government's housing policies do not work. That is why he has undertaken a review. He has not actually consulted widely with the industry; he has selected, as I understand it, a handful of economists who will probably come up with the conclusions that he wants them to come up with. The review is a concession on his part that the 23 policies that have already been introduced by this Government have not worked successfully. Let the Committee recall what Senator Devlin has done to deprive ordinary Australians on low incomes, in his case in North West Tasmania, who are struggling to make ends meet--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer briefly to the impact of the severity of the cuts made by the Commonwealth in its allocations to the States on health services. To New South Wales, in the mini-Budget, there was a cut of enormous proportion-no less than $540m. As a consequence the New South Wales Government has found it necessary to prune expenditure on health services. I have a particular concern because of a decision in the last few days to close the only hospital in the upper Clarence area in my electorate, located at Bonalbo. It is a hospital that serves about 4,000 residents. The community is very dependent on an effective health service. If the health service is withdrawn, so far as hospital facilities are concerned, a great strain will be placed on that community because there is no direct transport to other locations. There are no immediate alternatives. It creates very great distress. The consequence of the closure of the hospital will be that the only doctor servicing that community will find it necessary to close his practice because it is quite inappropriate for a doctor to try to serve that area unless he has hospital facilities at his disposal. Likewise, the only pharmacist in that area will not find his business viable if the hospital closes.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequence of cuts that have been made by the Federal Government to the States in essential health services is something which I am sure is of great concern to this Committee. Whilst time precludes me from sufficiently traversing all of the detail, let me say that hardships created by health services are unacceptable. The Federal Government has a responsibility because of the relationship between the administration of health facilities by the States and all of the other related agencies. We know, of course, that many agencies are jointly funded by the two governments. If these are impinged upon, so far as the availability of adequate funds for essential services is concerned, it will be a very sorry day for communities outside the metropolitan area.

Much is said about pressures on hospital services, a consequence of which is long waiting lists for elective surgery. Country people encounter many difficulties if they have to travel to a metropolitan area for specialist health treatment. But it is even worse in remote areas when there is a contraction involving the closure of a 15-bed hospital, with no appropriate alternative. I say to this Committee that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is directly responsible for health services, should look again at the impact of overall Budget provisions when both State and Federal instrumentalities are involved. We need to take into account the policies about which we have been informed in great detail prior to the Budget, in previous health debates and in respect of the future of Medicare. There is a very obvious need to ensure that the relationship between each of these services is recognised. Unless that is done the whole pattern of health services falls to the ground in terms of standard and availability to the needy.

In the area to which I have referred there are many people who are on social security benefits. There is a large Aboriginal community in the area. All of these people find it increasingly difficult to secure not only immediate hospital accommodation when required but those services that are provided by public hospitals these days. I refer to the provision of outpatient services, immediate needs in the case of accidents, and so on. There is an interrelationship between hospital services, medical services, pharmaceutical services and ambulance services. Unless this is recognised at the Federal funding level and at the level of the administration of the funding that flows through to the States and local institutions-they may be administered by local boards or administrators-it is impossible for us to have a satisfactory health service in the community. Therefore, I make an appeal to this Committee that there should be greater recognition of and greater coordination in the implementation of the funding of our health services.

I certainly say that what is being done by the health authorities in the matter to which I have referred is unsatisfactory. My State parliamentary colleague the member for Northern Tablelands in New South Wales has made a strong case to the New South Wales Government in this matter which is currently being considered. I believe that the New South Wales Government, which has recently come to office, has not yet had an opportunity fully to assess the effects of many of the policies that flow from the Federal Government in health services. Of course, it will take some little time in New South Wales to enable a clearer picture to be formulated in respect of the financing, the implementation and the ongoing administration of health services.

In conclusion: whatever decisions flow, they must take into account basic health needs. Unfortunately, there is a tendency today for too many well meaning proposals to be given some precedence whilst the real needs of hospital care and medical care are not receiving the priority that they should. It is essential that this be given the highest possible priority under funding which flows from the decisions of the Budget which has just been the subject of debate in this House and, of course, the estimate that is now before this Committee. I appeal to the Minister to ensure that that is considered at all levels in the administration of health services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care and Acting Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to many speakers in this part of the debate, I will make a number of comments. First, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) spoke at considerable length about Medicare and the problems the Government faces in that regard. It is worth recording that the honourable member for Tangney is, I think, the fifth shadow Minister since the Opposition has been on that side of the House. As yet the Opposition is still without a comprehensive or any real effective agreed policy between both the parties on the coalition side. So it is a little like blowing in the wind for members of the Opposition to come into the House and talk about health care policy, Medicare or whatever they want to talk about in that regard and criticise the Government when they do not even have a policy themselves. It was this Government that brought in Medicare and it was certainly one of the greatest social justice achievements in the last five years. It is worth noting, as the opposition tends to make comments about social justice in terms of ridiculing the Government, that `social justice' as a term was not really in the lexicon of this Parliament, let alone the Australian population, until this Government came into office.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the issues that the honourable member for Tangney raised about waiting lists, it is worth noting that the Opposition put forward no real solutions, either during this part of the debate or in its policies themselves. The Government has been acting in conjunction with the State governments, not only in building up the whole of the health care system but certainly in addressing the issues in the community of people waiting for medical services. The public hospital waiting lists assistance program is one direct measure taken to address that situation. This program is jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the States on a dollar for dollar basis. The two-year program commenced last year and it is designed or intended to assist specific State and Territory initiatives along the way. These initiatives have included the opening of dedicated surgical facilities, increased recruitment, training of nurses, additional theatre sessions and leasing of private facilities and day surgery enhancement.

It is a little early to gauge the full effect of the program, but preliminary reports indicate the program is quite successful in reducing both waiting lists and waiting times, particularly in those areas where it was possible to institute the initiatives rapidly. Some initiatives planned by the States have been difficult to implement as a result of an unfortunate lack of cooperation by groups of medical practitioners in some private hospitals. It is also worth indicating, to bring a little more balance into it, that many of the problems associated with waiting lists are related to a shortage of specialists and, in particular, of trained nurses in Australia. Other areas obviously need to be addressed within the profession itself because, as many doctors would know, access to specialist training is pretty restrictive compared with access to general practice. That is perhaps something that the shadow Minister would like to take up with the medical profession, as the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) certainly has on many occasions.

In relation to another matter raised by the honourable member about payment of medical benefits to overseas students, the Government decided in this Budget to discontinue payment of Medicare benefits for services rendered to certain classes of overseas students. This will take effect from 1 January next year. It will affect full fee paying students, and those students now studying in Australia who are sponsored or subsidised under the Government's programs will indeed remain eligible to receive Medicare benefits. It is considered inappropriate by the Government that overseas students who are in fact purchasing an education in Australia should be covered by general taxation funded programs such as Medicare. The honourable member for Tangney suggested that this was a foot in the door to extending this across a broader range.

TALK.START.PARA: —Toe in the water.

—I was not sure whether it was a foot in the door, toe in the water or thin end of the wedge. Whatever it was, it is a bit fanciful to suggest that the Government does not have anything like that under consideration. It is quite contrary to the Government's policies.
—You took your time telling us.

—Maybe, but I had to wait a long time to speak today. On the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS), a few matters need to be raised. Considerable concern has been generated in the community on the subject of authorities. The Government put 53 drugs, on recommendation of those drugs, on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme authority requirement following the May statement. Epilim, a specific pharmaceutical for treating several of the syndromes of epilepsy, is one of those drugs. Unfortunately, the Australian Medical Association (AMA), as distinct from the general medical profession, has sought to go into the community and create a lot of quite unnecessary hysteria and misinformation about what is actually happening and what people can and cannot do. Unfortunately, some members of the Opposition have also sought to make a lot of political capital out of scaring people quite unnecessarily. The honourable member for Tangney mentioned one person in his electorate. Obviously, I would not have the details of that, but the fact is that whether it be for Epilim or any of the other 52 drugs, they are now on authority as a result of being seen as expensive drugs and drugs which have cheaper alternatives, at least for some patients--
—Only some.

—That is all right, but there are a variety of ways in which the person can receive that medication without being inconvenienced in any way. The latest information I have from the Western Australian office is that it is a 24-hour turnaround within the Department. Of course, to that must be added the postage times. However, it varies. If there is concern for any person, if the doctor feels that that person should have the medication urgently, there are two other processes. One is the telephone approval on a 24 hours a day basis, and the other is very little different to the situation that exists for any normal pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescription, and that is, the doctor can fill out the authority requirement form, which is effectively just an extra piece of paper under the normal national health scheme (NHS) scrip. The person can then take the top two copies to the pharmacist, as would normally be done, and the doctor would then send in that bottom copy to the Department with the postage paid for by the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the Opposition has no enunciated policy on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Perhaps it would like to tell us now what it intends to do. How will it cope with the very rapidly escalating cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme? The cost of that scheme has gone up almost a couple of hundred million dollars in a year; it will go up much more than that and it is estimated that in three or four years it will cost $2,000m. The Opposition really has not enlightened us today on its policy. Perhaps it will go a `user pays' policy. Perhaps it will delist drugs. Perhaps it will charge people a special premium so that the wealthy will be healthy and those who are poor will not--

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be worrying about what you are doing while you are in government rather than worrying about what we will do.

—But this is the Opposition's opportunity to tell the people of Australia what it intends to do. Honourable members opposite will not do that. In protecting people's health through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the Government has ensured that drugs are available to those who the doctors say should have them. A very wide range of drugs is available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and people are not penalised if they do not have the money up front.
—ACE inhibitors?

—If people require an angiotensin converting enzyme, or ACE inhibitor, if their doctor says they need one-usually for moderate to severe hypertension-they will get it. That is quite clear, but Opposition members and others in the community are quite content to go around literally scaring the life out of people by suggesting that they will not get these things. That is wrong-it is wrong both in fact and in the way in which people in the community should be treated. That is just so typical of the way in which the Opposition approaches health and aged care issues. Opposition members talk about these things in this chamber yet they do not have a policy between them. All they do is go out into the community and scare people. We did not hear about any Opposition health policy today; we did not hear about any aged care policy-we heard nothing.
—You heard about a veterans' affairs policy.

—All right. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) raised the question of the Endeavour Foundation. The Department of Community Services and Health has been engaging in continuing consultations with the Foundation. I understand that the consultations are still going on and I am sure that the problems that existed there will be solved quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) was concerned about repatriation hospitals being transferred to State hospital systems. In his position he should be aware that no hospital will be transferred unless the priority of access to hospitals and maintenance of the current standards of care provided to entitled veterans and war widows in each State are protected. That planning is continuing in strong consultation with the community of ex-service personnel and people associated with them.

The honourable member for Fairfax also expressed concerns about nursing home waiting lists. I point out that there is more to aged care in Australia today than nursing homes. Once again we do not have an aged care policy from the Opposition so we do not know its current thinking on this matter, but when the Opposition was running the country its aged care policy was basically that aged people could either be at home or go into a nursing home. There was no alternative; there was not the full expansion of the home and community care (HACC) program as it is today and there was no expansion of the hostel program which this Government has brought in. In fact, in our seven years in government to 1990 we will have doubled the number of hostel beds in this country from 22,000 to more than 44,000. There is a complete lack of understanding of aged care by the Opposition parties. In the three years from 1988-89 to 1990-91 there will be an extra 199 nursing home beds and 1,809 new hostel beds in Queensland. The figures for Australia as a whole will be 1,409 new nursing home beds and 12,296 hostel beds, making a total of 13,705 residential aged care places.

The honourable member for Fairfax complained about problems associated with waiting lists. We have brought another element into residential care under the aged care system and that is geriatric assessment teams. In States where these teams have been operating for some time we have found that waiting lists for nursing homes are dropping because there have been considerable numbers-in some cases of the order of 40 per cent-of inappropriate admissions of people to nursing homes. Those people did not need to go there. People do not want to go to nursing homes unless they have to. Most older people prefer to stay independent in their own homes for as long as possible. The honourable member for Tangney nods his head. Being a compassionate man, he recognises the quality of life and independence that a person has in a hostel or in the comfort and familiarity of the surroundings of his or her own home. That is what the HACC program is all about. In particular, it is what the hostel program is all about. It is improving the quality of life and care in nursing homes and hostels as well as giving people the opportunity for individuality. Queensland has been slow to develop these geriatric assessment processes in recent years, but funding which is being provided in this Budget will increase Queensland coverage in the non-metropolitan areas to almost 100 per cent-I am sure the honourable member for Fairfax will be happy about that-and to about 60 per cent in Brisbane in the next year. I think that the honourable member will find considerable changes in the need for nursing home accommodation. I am sure that a number of hostel places will go to the non-metropolitan areas of Queensland, with the large numbers of ageing people in that State.

The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) raised a matter that was not raised by Opposition members-the home and community care program. It is worth noting the rapid expansion in the HACC program which is giving people a greatly increased quality of life. It is also increasing greatly the efficiency and quality of the expenditure of Government dollars. Expenditure on this program has more than doubled since it was introduced in 1985.

I wish to mention very quickly the matters raised by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I apologise that I cannot respond to the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), because I am only acting on behalf of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and I feel it is more appropriate that I respond to the areas of my own portfolio. The honourable member for Mayo pointed to fundamental differences in philosophy between the two sides of the House in many areas of housing policy. There are fundamental differences in philosophy in many regards but the big fundamental difference is in performance. The honourable member talked about disasters in housing. No disaster in the housing industry can equal that which occurred in 1982-83 when there were only 105,000 starts. He talked about deep troughs, but nowhere and at no time in the period of this Government has the number of starts dropped anywhere near as low as 105,000. We are looking at constant years of 120,000 to 130,000 new starts. That is the reality. The industry is strong and this Government is committed to home ownership. The 1986 census shows that home ownership in Australia was higher than it was in the 1981 census despite the very big growth in the number of households over that period. Opposition members do not seem to understand the relationship between an ageing population and the number of houses that we need. They do not understand the relationship between more single parent families and single person households and the requirement for more housing. There is far more finance available now than there was even in March 1986. That is one of the reasons why the housing industry is doing better.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill 1988, which is before the House, on the face of it is essentially a technical piece of legislation which was part of the package announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May statement and supported by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in a statement at the same time. It related to the manner in which appeals from the Department of Social Security by beneficiaries, pensioners or would be pensioners or beneficiaries within the community should be handled. The basis of the legislation is to give the power to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) which it previously did not have to make determinative decisions. Previously the capacity of the Tribunal was limited to reviewing the decisions made by the Secretary to the Department of Social Security and making a recommendation on that basis. The SSAT as it is called has in fact been in existence since 1975. Its aim was then, as it still is now, to provide an informal setting for consideration of reviews of decisions made by the Secretary to the Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: Since that time, the SSAT has had no legislative foundation and consequently no power to decide cases. The Tribunal currently reviews some 12,000 cases a year throughout the Commonwealth. At present a person may appeal to the Secretary if he does not like the decision of an officer in a branch office of the Department. The decision may or may not be overturned. The matter may also be appealed to the SSAT. However, any decision made by it has not been binding on the Secretary who has in the past had the capacity to reject the SSAT's decision.

There have been significant variations in the veto rate. It is interesting to note that in 1978-79 it was 28 per cent; the rate fell dramatically to 6 per cent in 1979-80; it rose to 8 per cent in the following year and settled around 12 per cent for the next four years. Then for some unaccountable reason it rose steeply to 28 per cent in 1985-86. During the following six months the rejection in fact got even higher. It is now 35 to 38 per cent. It might be of interest to the House if the Minister for Social Security, perhaps in his summing up, could give some explanation as to why there has been this rapid increase in the manner in which cases have been dissented from over that period. In such cases the appellant is required to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if he believes that a further appeal is warranted. Under the laws that currently stand he can go further; he can take the matter to the Federal Court of Australia.

The Administrative Review Council in its report in 1984 suggested that the absence of determinative powers had exacerbated the problem of delay and the processing of appeals. The Council concluded that the conferring of a power of determination would enhance the SSAT's credibility and standing and ensure its independence from the Department. The Bill is, of course, based on the recommendation contained in that report. The Minister for Social Security also pointed out in his second reading speech that the measures when implemented should save approximately $2.8m in 1988-89 and $5.4m in the following year. It would appear that the basis of the savings will be that the administrative costs will be less due to streamlining of procedures. In the Minister's statement he predicted that the new process would simplify appeals and remove the delays currently present when the Department considers the SSAT recommendation. At this point I move my amendment to the motion for the second reading which states:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is concerned that while there is a need for an effective system of administrative review, this should not be at the expense of Ministerial responsibility for the quality of departmental decisions and the policies upon which they must be based.'.

The principal function of the social security review system is to promote high quality primary decision making. One could go a step further, I suggest, and say that it is a principal function of government, certainly of Ministers, to ensure this high quality decision making. As I said in my amendment to the motion for the second reading, it also follows that the quality of the decisions is to a large degree dependent upon the quality of the policies on which they are meant to be predicated. This can be achieved by influencing policy of administrative change within the Department or by trying to remove or to avoid unnecessary errors. It has been stated in the Legal Service Bulletin of December 1987 in an article by Terry Carney and Peter Hanks, who are no doubt known to the Minister, that on an international comparison Australia does not rate particularly well in achieving that objective. They claim:

The reason for such a poor performance lies in major structural defects associated with the review system. These defects arise out of the insulation of the administrative review rulings from the administration and policy processes of DSS . . . from the drafting and revision of Departmental Manuals, from Ministerial and legislative policy, and from the primary decision makers.

Perhaps the difficulty faced is that most of the decisions which tend to be the subject of appeal are made by clerks usually around the level of clerk class 5, which in public service terms is relatively low, and people perhaps feel that they have not been given a fair go in the context of the environment in which they made their application for benefits in the first place. But the deficiencies in those three areas which were noted by Carney and Hanks are really quite serious. Up to date it can be argued that the system of administrative review has largely failed to achieve any normative or preventative impact on social security decision making policy or legislation. Unless these structural weaknesses are addressed in some way the question must be asked whether the system will continue to fail to realise its primary goal. If it continues to have so little success in promoting better primary decision making, we surely must doubt its ability to survive in the longer term or to have any really useful objective. It has been said that several forces are combining to place the review system under threat. These include political and economic pressures to reduce government spending, the introduction within the Department of Social Security of computer systems for claims assessment and administration and the dominance of administrative culture with its emphasis on uniform treatment of cases, precise non-discretionary rules, and minimal expenditure on administration. These pressures confront the values of legal culture as distinct from administrative culture which underpins the review system because legal culture should emphasise the accuracy of decisions in individual cases through the impartial review of grievances, accompanied by a fair hearing.

The issue was taken a step forward by an article in the Social Security Law and Policy by Kirkwood. He took a view which I must admit is very close to may own. He questioned the fundamental need to have a dual process of review. In fact, one can say it is a triple process of review if one adds the Federal Court to it as well. He took the view:

In my view appeals against DSS decisions should go directly to a single specialist review tribunal external to the DSS. Both the Myers Inquiry in 1977 and the Administrative Review Council in 1981 came to the same conclusion.

It is for that reason that while the Opposition is not voting against this legislation we believe that it is appropriate in this context to simply add a word of caution to the growing tendency in recent years, which probably dates back to about 1975, for more emphasis to be put on the so-called quality of review and access to review rather than the fundamental question of the need for the review in the first place. That is why the second reading amendment, which I have moved, emphasised that the fundamental requirement is responsibility of Ministers to this Parliament. That is the basis of the Westminster system and, by extension, it is equally required that Ministers call on their officers at all levels to apply the letter of the regulations in the spirit by which those regulations were drafted in the first place.

In 1981, we had the proposals of the Administrative Review Council (ARC) which suggested that a social security division should be established within the AAT to hear social security appeals. Kirkwood claims-and I support his view-that that was an ill- conceived idea and it indicated that the AAT had shown itself to be too formal and inflexible a body to ever be able to adapt to the enormous pressure of work which would have flowed from the 1981 ARC proposal. In other words, he does not believe, and neither do I, that the AAT should necessarily be the frontline review tribunal for social security matters. I would be grateful if the Minister, in his summing up, would give some thought to the question of how one can adequately justify a two-tiered system of review when logic would dictate that we would be better to strengthen the SSAT procedures at the cost of AAT procedures. If the processes are to work well, we should put the resources at the first point of contact because one of the advantages of the SSAT approach is that it is meant to be closer to the work place.
