It is meant to be on a regional basis; it is meant to be on a co-ordinated State level, and so forth. It is to be made up principally of officers on secondment from the Department of Social Security. There will be only one lawyer on the panel, unlike the AAT which is heavily legally dominated, a matter with which I have great disagreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?
—My colleague, of course, is almost a gentleman of the cloth.
—Don't accuse me of that; the law is bad enough.

—But God is not the law, or vice versa. So the difficulty we have tended to face in the AAT context is to what extent it is really able and equipped to handle the complexities and human questions relating to social security matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time available to me I will merely go through some of the examples of the decisions which many people, including I might add the Department of Social Security, believe are faulty decisions which have been made by the AAT in that context. Nevertheless, the decision to have a two-tiered social security appeal structure in Australia has really been, in some respects, a backward step for the reasons I have mentioned. It has been suggested by writers on the subject, including Kirkwood, that there has been a fundamental lack of in-depth reasoning as to why it is necessary to build onto existing structures rather than to question the need for those structures in the first place.

It has been pointed out-and I think it should be emphasised-that this attitude towards building rather than questioning the foundations started back in the time of the Bland Administrative Review Committee. It claimed that the key body on social security appeals should be the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to make this area consistent with other areas of administrative law. But such a premise has acted as a dead weight on the process of establishing an appeal structure because it has inhibited the consideration of whether the issues in social security law, the nature of clientele of the Department of Social Security, and the numbers of potential appellants all point towards the establishment of a new social security appeals body with no involvement with the AAT at all. I say amen to that because that is the very basis of my contention that we are running a very real risk of using appeals mechanisms as an excuse for not getting the question right in the first place. Every effort should be made at the first level of appeal to make that an adequate, respected and integral part of the process so that those who feel that they have not had a fair hearing within the Department should have the right to appeal to the SSAT. But whether they should then have the capacity to appeal upon appeal upon appeal becomes almost an absurdity in an administrative concept.

So, the report of the Administrative Review Council in 1984 was very partial to review. One would almost suspect that the personnel on the Review Council see the sine qua non of their existence as being the need for evermore widening capacities and additional areas of appeal. The Review Council reported in 1984 that the absence of determinative powers had exacerbated the problems of delay in the processing of appeals within the Department. It concluded that conferring a power of determination would enhance the SSAT's credibility and standing and ensure its independence in the Department.

As I said earlier, the Bill we have before us is based fundamentally upon the recommendations of that report. But it does not ask this fundamental question: To what extent should we be reducing effectively the power of departmental heads and transferring that power into the hands of so-called supportive administrative review-type machinery? If we do that, where would it leave the departmental head? Where would it leave the officer in the Department who made the decision in the first place? Does he feel that he is truly accountable for the decisions he has to make, or does he feel that it does not really matter because he will probably lose 25 per cent of his decisions anyway? Appellants will all go to the SSAT and, if they do not like that, they will go off to the AAT and, if they still have any money, they will go off to the Federal Court of Australia on legal aid if they can get it. I really question the need for that level of duplication in the review process. If we cannot have a more effective system than that the quality of public administration in this nation will ultimately be the loser and, through that, the Australian people.

It has been claimed by the Council that one of the problems of the existing system was that the Secretary had the capacity to overrule the decisions of the SSAT. Under new arrangements he does not have that right to overrule; he has the same right as the appellant-no more and no less. If the Department does not like the decision of the SSAT, he has the right to appeal the same as the appellant has the right to appeal. I ask the House: Is that really right? If the line of responsibility through this Parliament to the Minister, to the permanent head, and down through the Department, is meaningful in terms of vertical responsibility, why should the Secretary, who is responsible to the Minister for the decisions and the processes within his Department, be in a position where he has to face effectively a quasi court-type status to argue the decision made by his officers on his behalf and, by extension, on behalf of the Minister? To me this is a very relevant point and one which I hope the Minister will throw some light on. Having had some experience of public administration myself in my many years as Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Accounts in this House it came before me time and again that one of the greatest weaknesses of the Australian public administration system is that the decision-making process and the responsibility for the decisions which are made are now being so effectively diluted-I am glad to see that the current Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) is now in the House-that in many cases nobody really takes the responsibility for anything. We pass it all off to get a new review process.

The right of appeal to the AAT, following unsuccessful hearings by the SSAT in the past, was introduced in 1980. It is interesting to note for the record the percentage of unfavourable decisions-that is, decisions unfavourable to the Department of Social Security-made by the SSAT. Do not forget that, under the old system, it had no power to make that determination; it had only an advisory power. The decisions were as follows: in 1978-79, 6 per cent; in 1980-81, 8 per cent; between 1981 and 1985, 12 per cent; in 1985-86, 28 per cent; in 1986-87, 36 per cent; and, goodness gracious, it has actually dropped to 30 per cent in 1987-88. About 25 per cent of appellants whose appeals are dismissed by the Department of Social Security following an SSAT hearing have made a further appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Just under half of those appeals were decided, either in whole or in part, in favour of the appellant, either because the Department of Social Security conceded the appeal before a hearing, or because the AAT upheld the appeal after a hearing. One must ask: What was the real cost, not just the cost of running the AAT, which is a very shorthand way of covering this particular problem? What was the actual cost in the time of officers of the Department of Social Security who could not perform their normal functions and who were required to appear before the SSAT and the AAT on numerous occasions to try to get appellants' claims adequately processed?

The percentage of Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearings made up of Department of Social Security appeals is also significant. In 1981-82 it was 53 per cent; in 1982-83 it was 64 per cent; in 1983-84 it was 44 per cent; in 1984-85 it was 31 per cent; in 1985-86 it was 30 per cent; in 1986-87 it was 23 per cent; and excluding taxation appeals, it was 25 per cent. So the point is quite clear. Social Security appeals before the AAT are a significant part of its normal activities. While the cost of running the AAT is not great-in 1988-89 is will be $7.783m; in 1987-88, the previous year, it was $6.510m-the point I make still stands. The actual costs to other departments on a horizontal basis to satisfy the requirements of the review process are obviously substantially greater than the actual cost of running the AAT itself.

In the 1986-87 Budget, the Government announced its intention to review the procedures of the AAT aimed at achieving greater cost effectiveness in administrative review. The terms of reference for the inquiry were to streamline procedures and reduce the number of contested hearings before the Tribunal, and to ensure that Tribunal proceedings are conducted with a minimum of formality. Honourable members may recall that when the Minister, in 1975, I believe, introduced the legislation he emphasised that appeals had to be informal gatherings, but reality over the years has shown that the Tribunal has become a quasi court. Various people who have gone to higher and better things in the legal profession have emphasised the need for it to take on a quasi legal process. While technically it was not meant to base its work on the principle of precedent, in fact, over the years, precedent has become an important element of it.

It is in this regard that the social security element often finds itself in a difficult position. If one is dealing with two people with similar alleged criteria, or similar problems or case histories in relation to the reasons why they did not get access to benefits, it is so much easier for an appeal process simply to say `We have these other cases', and for lawyers to trundle up to represent their clients in a legal type environment and to argue the merits of cases, rather than necessarily the details of cases which are meant to be before the Tribunal.

In February 1987 the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) announced a task force which was due to report `in time to allow any necessary legislative amendments to be introduced in the 1987 autumn sittings of Parliament'. It is now October 1988 and no report has been forthcoming, and an officer of the ARC has confirmed that the task force has been disbanded and no report will be written. Perhaps the Minister for Social Security who is at the table will care to tell the House what happened to this task force. Why was it disbanded? Why is there no report? These commitments were made in February 1987.

I now refer to one or two cases in the social security area. I will not mention any names, for obvious reasons. The Department of Social Security claimed that an applicant aged 74, who was a recent arrival from India, was permanently incapacitated at the time of arrival in Australia. This was confirmed by two other doctors. I think for the record one should ask why such a person was allowed to migrate to Australia in the first place. Nevertheless, on arrival in Australia, the applicant claimed that he had contracted asthma. The condition, however, had improved markedly since then. Notwithstanding the applicant's illness, he was offered two jobs within two months of his arrival. The AAT decided that in no way could the applicant's invalid pension be terminated as it would be unfair and irresponsible. From the outside looking in one has to be careful about one's judgments about such matters. While not disagreeing with the AAT that terminating the applicant's invalid pension would be unfair, the great concern must surely be just why a 74-year-old invalid-to use its expression-was allowed into the country in the first place. Surely, if the applicant came in under the family reunion program, one would expect some form of assurance of support to have been given to the Government by his family. Instead, an old man came into the country and went straight onto government welfare. The AAT, in handing down its decision, appeared not to have the slightest concern about such matters.

Another case involved the overpayment of the widow's pension by a mere $35,448.70. This applicant was a Hungarian migrant who applied for a widow's pension in March 1980. She stated that she had been separated from her husband since March 1966. She had custody of her son. She ceased work in March 1980. The widow's pension was approved in April of the same year. The Department of Social Security in June 1987 cancelled her pension because she was not a widow as defined by the Social Security Act. It was claimed that she had been living in a de facto relationship since July 1980. The overpayment arose out of the applicant's failure to disclose details of the de facto relationship and therefore she was required to repay the full amount. In the course of the hearing, the following pertinent information was tabled. For 10 years prior to July 1980, the applicant had shared a house with a close friend. She had met the alleged de facto eight months before moving in with him. The applicant looked for a house with the alleged de facto and his son. For mailing purposes the applicant was addressed as `Mrs X' the woman's name being the same as that of the de facto. The applicant claimed no sexual relationship with the man she lived with for seven years.

At the hearing's conclusion, the AAT decided that the applicant did not have to reimburse the Department of Social Security for any payments as she was indeed a widow and was not living in any form of de facto relationship. Goodness gracious! If ever there was a case where the Department was right and the AAT was wrong, on the basis of the evidence I have seen, this was such a case. One would have to question the judgment made in that case.

There have been many other cases of a similar nature over the years. The Bulletin on 10 June 1986 ran a number of examples of Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions which it claimed then were conservatively costing the taxpayer more than $1 billion a year. It talked about the case of an elderly couple; an 80-year-old man who shared a flat with a 70-year-old woman. They had lived together since 1965. From 1971 the Department of Social Security treated them as married when it came to their old age pensions. That seemed on the face of it a reasonable thing to do because the woman had signed a statement in 1970 that she and the gentleman had lived as man and wife for five years. In due course the case went forward and at its decision in October 1985 the Tribunal commented that:

Before such a relationship (that is a housekeeping relationship) is converted into a man and wife relationship, there must be some kind of spark to ignite the tinder of cohabitation to the fire of quasi-marriage relationship.

There are many cases such as this, and nobody in this House could ever seriously suggest that they are not complex-clearly they are. But I end my observations by simply making the point: would it not be better to have a more effective one-tier system of review rather than the existing two-tier system of review which, on the face of it, and on the evidence I have attempted to present tonight, is not only additionally expensive but also runs counter to the fundamental principles of our system of parliamentary government, namely that the responsibilities of decision making rest not only with the Minister but also with the officers of departments at all levels whose role it is to ensure that the Australian people get the best level of administration possible, as quickly as possible, and at minimum cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a brief response to the contribution of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), I welcome the attention the Opposition is giving to this matter at last. It is at least a thoughtful look at the processes, whether we agree or not. But it seems a bit rich coming from the Opposition at this stage. We are, after all, discussing this Government's proposals tonight as a result of its review of a program initiated by the Whitlam Labor Government in 1975. So the thought that has been put into all of this has come from our side of the House. In any event, it is as a result of the administrative and policy reform embarked on by this Government that we have got to this legislation at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill, as we have all been saying, establishes by legislation the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). The Social Security Appeals Tribunals have existed since 1975 as recommendatory bodies providing an informal and accessible mechanism for reviewing social security decisions. As I said, the tribunals were originally part of the welfare rights program of the Whitlam Government and were established by ministerial directive. Their main advantage to clients has been their accessibility and their informality. Their advantage to the social security system has been their ability to advise the Minister of anomalies in the legislation which have become apparent in attempts to determine appeals.

The disadvantage has been that their decisions have not been binding on the Department. Everyone of us knows of cases in our electorates where a constituent has had a good hearing at the SSAT, has had a favourable recommendation and then has been knocked back by the Department. The honourable member for Bradfield gave some of the statistics on the rejections. I will give figures as an example of only one year, in 1987-88 and of only one State, my State of New South Wales, even though up to 12,000 cases a year are dealt with by the SSAT. In New South Wales in that year, of unfavourable recommendations accepted by the Department, there were 99.19 per cent-pretty staggering. Of favourable SSAT recommendations accepted by the Department, there were 73.92 recommendations accepted, and 26.08 not accepted by the Department. So the total percentage of recommendations accepted by the Department was 87.44 per cent and the total of those not accepted was 12.56 per cent.

Those knockbacks from the Department can have catastrophic consequences for social security recipients. So can the delays in getting a decision. I would like to quote from what Julian Disney from the Australian Council of Social Service said some years ago. It describes the situation exactly:

When a person applies for social security the outcome is very often of crucial importance to his or her personal survival. The amount of money at stake in a particular case may appear insignificant from lofty and comfortable positions within Parliament, the bureaucracy and the legal system. But if payment to a social security claimant is denied or delayed, he or she (and perhaps a number of dependants) may be unable to afford even a subsistence level of food, clothing or accommodation, let alone the means by which to make life more bearable (such as a trip to the football or cinema) or to climb out of the vicious circle of poverty for example, by travelling in search of work).

So uncertainty and delays have been exacerbated by the lack of determinative powers at the SSAT level. This legislation gives the power of decision-making to the SSAT, which is the first tier of external review, yet the accessibility and informality will remain. That is the important thing. Real concerns have been expressed about whether the SSAT will become another inflexible, formal structure dominated by lawyers, legal procedures and technicalities. That will not be the case. Proposed sections 188, 193 and 194 of this legislation make that a certainty. It is important, too, that those who are appointed will be, as they have been in the past, understanding, able to listen, approachable and non-threatening, their extra powers giving them only more confidence and generating more trust from the clients.

The other important aspect of an efficient appeal system is that it can help the Government identify holes in policy, anomalies, injustices not intended by the legislation and the system. An example of the sort of case handled by the SSAT where an anomaly was shown is the instance of a woman who gave birth to a severely deformed child and the husband declined to recognise the child. He continued to live in the same house for the next 10 years but denied both the child and the mother any financial support. The mother was therefore forced to rely on the social security system. She obtained assistance for 10 years but was denied further assistance after amendments were made to the sole parent's pension entitlements. She was disqualified by the new amendments. She was made ineligible. Because the SSAT is independent of the Department and the Government, it can advise the Minister, give independent advice and bring about changes to the legislation. So the role of the SSAT is very important in helping the Government identify where the anomalies exist so as to adjust policy to suit the real needs of people.

The social security system should provide claimants with clear and enforceable rights and duties. Welfare rights as an area of activity has suffered a lack of priority and recognition by the community and the legal system. Few resources have been directed towards protecting rights in this area. The emphasis has been, perhaps, a bit skewed. I quote from an article which appeared in the Legal Service Bulletin in 1985, in which Tom Brennan said of the social security system:

That system's primary object currently appears to be to ensure that no claimant receives a payment to which she or he is not entitled. The objectives of the officers within that system appear to be to ensure that the integrity of the system, its procedures and policies are maintained.
So much for the perception! He continues:

Australians might expect an administrative system whose primary object was to ensure that every claimant obtained her or his full entitlement. Such a change of emphasis can be brought about only through political leadership from the government and through widespread community discussion.

Because of the community discussion in the welfare rights area, and because of the courage of this Government, that is now being brought about. In the past few years there have been many changes-great changes-in the social security system. They have come about as a result of the social security review established by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and conducted by Bettina Cass. That has meant a challenge for the Government. I will quote from a document issued by the Minister in June 1988 entitled Administrative and Policy Reform: Department of Social Security. I certainly hope that honourable members opposite are reading it. It states:

The challenge for Government, particularly at a time of significant pressures to limit all expenditure, has been to maintain these social security services to the public and strike an acceptable balance between the twin objectives of `care' and `accountability'.
The Strategy of Reform
Five broad strategies have been employed to meet this challenge:
to maintain and improve real levels of support to ensure the adequacy of social security payments;
to encourage entry or return to education, training and employment as the most effective route out of poverty;
to further assist low income families with children in order to tackle the problem of child poverty;
to ensure that social security programs are targeted to those most in need; and
to introduce administrative reforms for greater efficiency, effectiveness and integrity.

That is what this legislation is all about. Perhaps the strategy of greatest importance to the Government and of most potential for good in the community is our social justice strategy. The chairman of the Caucus social justice committee, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), has urged all of us to ask the following questions of any legislation or reports which come before us. The four principles he has asked us to look at underpin the social justice strategy of achieving greater fairness and equity in society. Will economic resources be distributed more equitably? Will civil, legal and industrial rights be strengthened and more equal? Will there be fairer and more equal access to essential services? Will there be more opportunities for the community, especially clientele, to be involved and participate? I say to the honourable member for Streeton, chairman of our Caucus social justice committee, that this legislation provides the answer `yes' to all those questions.

Because this legislation establishes the SSAT by legislation and provides for its decisions to be binding on the Department and the claimant, it thereby will directly enhance the equality of legal rights by providing an effective and accessible mechanism for social security claimants to secure their rights in those cases where it is claimed that the Department is in error. While enhancing equality the Bill has a number of provisions to guarantee the access of everyone to the SSAT. Some of these provisions are worth mentioning briefly. Proposed section 168a provides for payment of pension to continue pending appeal; 176 sets out the objective of providing a review mechanism which is fair, just, economical, informal and quick; 179 provides that appeals can be made by phone, and can be lodged at any office of the Department; 188 will prevent the development of adversarial procedures by requiring that the Department can only make submissions in writing, provides for hearings by telephone, and acknowledges the need for interpreters; and 193 and 194 require that hearings be private and informal. So much for the fears that this new legislative program will make the procedure too formal and too legalistic. Proposed section 203 provides for payment of an applicant's medical costs; and proposed section 205 gives a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from the SSAT. I commend this extremely important legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) in this debate and I am pleased that she has already ably outlined the way in which this legislation will impact on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). I will briefly refer to a few of the areas that she has covered which I believe are worthy of reiteration before looking at the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill from the perspective of the claimant in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) selectively quoted from some Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) decisions, and it needs to be pointed out that it is always difficult to assess the correctness of such decisions when they are isolated from the full facts. However, he may like to bear in mind that this legislation has the capacity to reduce the number of appeals to the AAT because those people who obtain a satisfactory decision from the SSAT in its amended form will not now have to fear a reversal of that decision by the Social Security Department and then subsequently have to follow their initial appeal with a secondary appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That ought to cut down the workload of the AAT and the cost to the Government.

This Bill will formalise access by social security claimants to an informal, quick and most importantly free mechanism of review which will have determinative powers which will be binding on the Department of Social Security. It will provide for a review to be conducted by the SSAT in the first instance and subsequent appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will remain available to the claimant in the event of dissatisfaction or disagreement with the SSAT's decision. Currently the SSAT has no legislative foundation, as a number of speakers have already indicated, and consequently has not had the power to decide cases in a substantive way. Its function to date has simply been to recommend to the Secretary to the Department that a decision under review be affirmed, varied or set aside. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has to be commended for introducing this legislation, which will make the SSAT a statutory tribunal with responsibility for the first level of external review.

The Social Security Review Tribunal's lack of determinative power has caused problems for a number of people in the system. As the Minister pointed out in his second reading speech, it has been the subject of comment by many observers, including the Administrative Review Council-the honourable member for Bradfield referred to this also-which concluded that conferring a power of determination would enhance its credibility and standing.

The need for this determinative power is illustrated by reference to the problems encountered by one of my constituents. I have no doubt that other members will have examples very similar to this one. The person concerned received a lump sum compensation payment last year. His dilemma began when his solicitor incorrectly advised him that he could use his lump sum to pay off his debts, including his mortgage, and then apply to Social Security for the invalid pension which would take effect immediately.

However, a discussion with the Department subsequently revealed that he would not be eligible to receive a pension for two years because of the size of the loss of earnings component of his compensation; that is, the Department, it appears correctly in this case, treated the whole of the lump sum as a loss of earnings and did not discount at all the medical, legal or other expenses which are allowed to be taken into account. As a consequence of this decision my constituent was totally reliant on his children for financial support with the day to day costs of living. He subsequently appealed to the Social Security Review Tribunal for reconsideration of his eligibility for invalid pension in the first instance and a proportion of his compensation which should be treated by the Department as loss of earnings.

Although the Tribunal acknowledged the difficulties confronting my constituent, it did not recommend that he be granted the invalid pension immediately, and I suspect that that probably was the correct decision. It did, however, recommend that the Department of Social Security should reduce the lump sum by 30 per cent to take account of past and future medical expenses, legal costs and so on. Thirty per cent of the sum involved works out at approximately $11,000.

Unfortunately for my constituent the Department chose to disagree with the Tribunal's assessment and opted instead to reduce the lump sum by only $4,000. This may not seem important in the overall scheme of things, but it was crucial to my constituent's welfare, given that it would mean that he would have to wait longer to qualify for the invalid pension than he would have had the Department accepted the decision of the review tribunal. For instance, the reduction of $4,000 has the effect of bringing his pension eligibility date forward by three months. Had the suggested amount of approximately $11,000 been agreed to, his eligibility date could have been brought forward by almost nine months, that is, he would have been in receipt of the invalid pension now instead of having to wait until January next year.

The Department's decision left only one avenue of appeal open to my constituent-the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Given the formal nature of the AAT hearings, he concluded that legal representation would be necessary in order to present his case to the maximum advantage. He applied for legal aid so to do but he was rejected. The Legal Aid Commission's reasons for refusal were as follows:
There is no reasonably arguable ground of appeal and the expense to the legal aid fund of conducting an appeal cannot therefore be justified.
The remarks accompanying the refusal read:
The proceedings are not likely to be determined in a manner in your favour.

I find this refusal itself to be mystifying, given the position of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal on at least one aspect of the matter. Unfortunately, my office was not advised of the refusal and I was therefore not able to request reconsideration of the decision or explore other avenues of assistance which may have been available at that time.

In any event, because legal aid was apparently not available my constituent did not proceed with an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which would have been the correct course, and has still not qualified for the invalid pension. Had the Social Security Review Tribunal had deliberative powers, the Department would not have been in a position to reject or ignore its ruling and my constituent would not still be dependent on the goodwill and charity of his family.

Furthermore my constituent and his family would not have had to suffer the stress which was undoubtedly involved in pursuing justice in the way that they have had to and his case would have been resolved more quickly as well as in a more satisfactory manner. The Minister has since recognised the difficulty of assessing legal and medical expenses on a case by case basis and changed the legislation to permit 50 per cent of compensation lump sums to be taken as a fairer measure of such costs. I commend him for that decision also.

However, because there is no room for retrospectivity in the legislation which has achieved this change, it is not possible for my constituent to take advantage of a policy which would have rendered him eligible for the invalid pension some months ago. That sounds like a very long and drawn out story and I think it probably is not as uncommon as it might appear.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is the video coming out.

—The video is coming out next week. It is also the story of somebody who does not have English as a native language and who had to have the services of an interpreter at the original Social Security Appeals Tribunal hearing. I am absolutely amazed, as I said, that legal aid was refused for an AAT hearing under the circumstances. It illustrates the importance at that early stage of one decent avenue of appeal which has the power to advise the Department what it should do. I sincerely feel that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has taken the correct decision in pursuing this line and that it will ensure greater equity for all people within the system who have claims to make and who believe that they have an objective to pursue which has not been met properly by the Department. It will cut down on the workload of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that the altered Tribunal be able to shorten the period during which the Department of Social Security must make its submission to the Tribunal in cases of financial hardship, as this case obviously was, because the person is placed in a very difficult predicament if the matter goes on over a very long time. It is also important for reasons of equity that an appellant is able to be represented at a hearing by any person he chooses. In other words, he can have one of his family there or a friend or a member of Parliament or somebody he believes will represent him properly.

The other aspect that is worthy of mention is that notices of appeal will continue to be received either orally or in writing and that the receipt of an oral request will be acknowledged in writing so that there is no chance of the oral request being lost in the system.

Legal costs will not be met or awarded. I understand that in relation to the Tribunal, but legal costs will not be required in most circumstances because, very importantly, the Tribunal will retain the informal element that it has had to date. I think that informal element does encourage most claimants to go to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal feeling reasonably confident that they will not be intimidated and will have a fair hearing. By the same token, the Tribunal will not be bound by rules of evidence or notions of judicial procedure as the Minister indicated, and hearings will be conducted in private unless the member presiding at the hearing has decided otherwise. It is very important that this should happen because it has been pointed out-I am not sure whether the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) mentioned it-that there have been cases where the AAT puts forward all the information and the person's privacy, which has been so scrupulously maintained during the Social Security Appeals Tribunal hearings, is lost.

I would like to commend the Minister on the Bill and to commend it to the House. I believe it is an excellent piece of legislation and one that is long overdue. I congratulate him and the Government for bringing it forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the contributions of the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) and the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen). I think they illustrated clearly the purpose and function of this legislation. I point out to the House and to those listening that this legislation is part of the Government's systematic pursuit of a fair go for all Australians. It is another step in fulfilling this Government's commitment to social justice, which has already been demonstrated by the one million new jobs that have been created; the removal of the tax lurks for the privileged; universal health cover; better education; better housing; the alleviation of child poverty; and our commitment to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Social justice underpins this Government's whole policy setting agenda. It ensures that the benefits of a growing economy are distributed equitably, at the same time improving equality of opportunity and, as in the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill 1988, ensuring that the rights of people, especially the underprivileged, are enhanced.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Phillip pointed out, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) elucidated four key elements of a just and equitable society. I will repeat them for the benefit of the House: equity in the distribution of economic resources; equality of civil, legal and industrial rights: fair and equal access to essential services such as housing, health and education; and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision making. The strategy which is outlined in this legislation is part of the reform of the Department of Social Security (DSS), and the Government has employed a strategy which has five broad principles. They are clearly outlined in the document referred to by the honourable member for Phillip, the statement by the Minister entitled `Administrative and Policy Reform: Department of Social Security 1983-88'. The five key points of that strategy are to maintain and improve real levels of support; to ensure the adequacy of social security payments; to encourage entry or return to education, training and employment as the most effective route out of poverty; to further assist low income families with children in order to tackle the problem of child poverty; to ensure that social security programs are targeted to those most in need; and to introduce administrative reforms for greater efficiency, effectiveness and integrity. That is exactly what this legislation does.

Before I go on to outline the important aspects of the legislation as I see it, I would like briefly to comment on the contribution from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). Indeed, I found his contribution most interesting, but I think there was a fundamental flaw, a misunderstanding of the purpose of the proposed tribunal and its functions and what it would mean to the public sector. Far from meaning, as the honourable member for Bradfield suggested, that public sector employees would be less accountable to the Department of Social Security, I would have thought that scrutiny by an external tribunal such as is being proposed by this legislation, with the final determination being made by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) and not subject to the final will of the Department or its officers, would make Social Security staff more and not less accountable. In addition the structure imposes the threat of external review and will put pressure on DSS to ensure that its decisions are administratively and legally correct and in accordance with the Government's policy directions. In addition, the honourable member said he believed that there would be a prevalence of claims to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). Like the honourable member for Cowan, I reject that view. I believe that one could reasonably expect that the number of appeals to the AAT would be significantly diminished as a result of this review and the role and the mechanisms of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill is part of moves to develop a more rational and, importantly, understandable system of decision making in social security. It will assist social security claimants to secure their legal entitlements to pensions, benefits and allowances. Social security claimants will now have access to an appeal system which will provide a quick, cost efficient, just and authoritative decision making mechanism. While the Bill gives the Tribunal more extensive powers, it is also designed to ensure that appeal procedures remain informal and accessible. One of the key aspects and one of the most laudable aspects of the SSAT is its informality. Appellants do not require legal representation, it is more informal, there are no rules of evidence, it is far more accessible, and they will get a quicker result than in the courts. I believe that that has a great deal to be said for it. It is far more efficient to do it in this way, with the final determination being with the Tribunal, than having to go back to the Department, as the honourable member for Bradfield wants.

The Bill will indeed make appeals a lot shorter. I would expect that on non-medical and non-assets appeals the turnaround will be within six weeks of lodgment. That would lead to about a 60 per cent reduction in the time between the lodgment of normal appeals and the outcome. It will also be shorter because the Department of Social Security will no longer have to consider the recommendations of the Tribunal. The present absence of the determination power by the Tribunal has been one of the major deficiencies of the current system and has led to delays in processing and finalising appeals. The Tribunal will be able to meet reasonable medical and travel costs for appellants.

The Tribunal is very important in the context of my electorate-perhaps more so than most areas of Australia. The demography and the geography of the place make that so. I shall go through for a moment the types of concerns that are experienced in the Northern Territory and explain the dependence upon the Department of Social Security and the payments made by the Department. As of 7 October 1988 the number of people on unemployment, sickness and special benefits in the Northern Territory was 9,671. As of 2 September 1988 the number of people on invalid, age and supporting parent pensions was 9,183. As of July 1988 the number of families receiving family allowance was 21,549. As of 16 September 1988 the number in receipt of family allowance supplement was 940. I think that that illustrates the importance of the social security system to the population of the Northern Territory.

Other figures which demonstrate the system's importance not only to the whole community but also to a particular group within the community are the unemployment benefit figures. In the Northern Territory Aboriginal recipients comprise 20 per cent of all of those in receipt of the unemployment benefit. In some communities the figure is a great deal higher. In Nhulunbuy it is about 78 per cent; in Katherine it is about 35 per cent; in Tennant Creek it is about 38 per cent; in Darwin it is 12 per cent; and in Alice Springs it is 20 per cent. These people, by and large, are not only dependent upon unemployment benefit payments but also in almost every case are dependent in another way upon the social security system. It is important, therefore, that they are treated in an equitable and fair way and in a way which meets their demands in terms of service delivery.

The area covered by the Northern Territory Social Security Appeals Tribunals includes the whole of the Northern Territory and the Kimberleys region down to Broome. That is a tremendous slice of Australia. The sort of job which the Tribunal does is one for which I have a great deal of admiration. On the figures provided by the Department, in 1987-88, of the total number of recommendations made by the Appeals Tribunal in the Northern Territory, 96.67 per cent were accepted by the Department. I believe that that demonstrates the way in which the Department and the Social Security Appeals Tribunal have been working in northern Australia. I commend both the Department and the Tribunal for that.

In terms of looking at the problems which confront the delivery of social security in northern Australia and the welfare of the northern Australian population, some things need to be pointed out. For the benefit of those people who are unaware of the types of problems that are confronted by the Department of Social Security-and, indeed, by other government departments in administering to clients throughout northern Australia-a number of things need to be taken into account, not the least of which is the weather patterns during the year. On some occasions during the year some communities are completely inaccessible, at other times of the year, in terms of demography, there is a great deal of movement in and around the Northern Territory and, indeed, the north of Western Australia, South Australia, and also western Queensland, as a result of Aboriginal people moving because of ceremonial and familial obligations. This requires a flexible approach to the administration of social security, which, I am happy to say, has been taken up by the Department and the Minister.

In terms of the delivery of service by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, in the past it has often been the case that it has been most cost effective to have a stockpile of cases to justify the costs of travel from one place to another. Indeed, another problem which confronts the administration of the social security system in northern Australia is the question of invalid pensioners. It is often very difficult, because of the nature of the area, to get specialist medical opinion. I would like the House to appreciate that if a person lives, say, at Borroloola, which is on the eastern side of the Northern Territory on the Gulf of Carpentaria, and needs specialist attention, that person's closest town is Darwin. In some cases travel may also be required to other States, perhaps to Adelaide or Brisbane. It is important to recognise that these difficulties confront not only the clients who are the recipients of the social welfare system in the Northern Territory and northern Australia generally, but also the administration undertaken by the Department.

There are also specific cultural and demographic factors which I have already mentioned which are peculiar to the north and which often result in appeals that are very peculiar to the region. Cases which have come before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in the past highlight the problems of service delivery to an area which is characterised, as I have said, by isolation and a population mix which includes a high migrant population. I believe that the number of different ethnic groups totals about 95, with 26 per cent of the population being Aboriginals. A large itinerant work force moves to the area mostly in the dry season to take advantage of the very nice climate which we experience and, indeed, also to take advantage of the job opportunities that have been provided in the mining sector and other resource-based industries.

A number of policy issues were raised in the 1986-87 annual report of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. I would like to mention them to the House this evening. They also reflect the nature of the delivery of social security in northern Australia and the problems which the Department has confronted in the administration of its service. Firstly, there is the question of Aboriginal law versus European law in the case of an Aboriginal person having two under-age wives. Secondly, there is the question of family allowance payments for children residing overseas. I refer, for example, to mixed marriages, such as those in which spouses come from the Philippines and Malaysia. Thirdly, there is the question of what constitutes `special circumstances' in the last lodgment of unemployment benefit income forms-the SU19B-especially in remote areas. They are significant problems. I would like to mention a number of specific cases. The first is the situation of a polygamous Aboriginal marriage in which the second wife was in receipt of the unemployment benefit. This woman was not able to get supporting benefits. The woman had automatically been placed on the unemployment benefit and was in hospital waiting to give birth to another child. As she could not then fulfil the work test, she was taken off the unemployment benefit. The recommendation of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal was to provide the woman with special benefits-a most appropriate course of action.

A second example is that the Top End of Australia experiences a huge wave of itinerants, as I have already mentioned, who travel north in the dry season looking for work. It is now a matter of policy that when a person who fits into this category registers for benefits, he is issued with a work effort certificate which has to be signed by two prospective employers every two weeks. In remote communities, one person often acts as an agent to certify the eligibility criteria of everyone living in that area. In a case in which a recipient has been judged to have been overpaid, the legal issue has arisen as to who is responsible: is it the recipient or the person who signs on behalf of the recipient?

Another case that I mention is that of an Aboriginal man who has three under-age wives and several children. This man was employed under the community development employment program, a very important and most worthwhile program which this Government has increased quite significantly. I must say that it was introduced by Dame Margaret Guilfoyle under the Fraser Administration. After successfully appealing to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the family is now in receipt of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, as it should have been in the first instance.

The northern area Social Security Appeals Tribunal is the only Tribunal which advocates, because of the large Aboriginal population, which often has English as a second language and quite diverse cultural expectations, a radical approach to the way in which it deals with clients. I am happy to say that the Department has taken up that challenge. Indeed, as I have mentioned in the House previously, the Department has introduced a very positive program. It has developed and introduced into the administration of social security in northern Australia the North Australian Development Unit. I would like to remind the House of the functions of that Unit to demonstrate the way in which the Minister has fulfilled his responsibilities in providing fair and equitable service for all of his Department's clients, wherever they might be, whatever their race, and whatever their background.

The North Australian Development Unit is based in Darwin and has as its primary purpose the development of policies and strategies to improve the applicability and delivery of departmental programs and services to people living in northern Australia. The Unit's activities will not be limited to the Northern Territory, but will also span the Pilbara and the Kimberleys in Western Australia and north-western and north Queensland. In that way it reflects most of the area that is already covered by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal based in Darwin.

The Unit has three main areas of responsibility: the development of ideas relating to the provision and improvement of departmental services in remote areas; the development of policy on matters specifically related to Aboriginal clients; and the development of policy on matters relating to other groups of clients more commonly found in remote Australia-isolated outback communities and itinerants. I think that that is an important admission by the Department-that it needs to pay special attention to the very great needs of these people.

The North Australian Development Unit will need to address a number of policy issues, one of which I have already mentioned-that is, appropriate policy relating to the findings of the Australian Law Reform Commission in the area of Aboriginal traditional law and culture. Specific issues include, as I have already said, polygamous marriages, changes in child custody, under-age marriages, and others. There is also the question of the definition of unemployment. There is a need to clarify the application of the work test under section 116 of the Act to client groups within the northern area. These matters have already been recognised by the Department. They have also been thrown up by the Appeals Tribunal mechanism. As I say, the Minister is to be commended for recognising his responsibilities in this area.

Some of the advantages in establishing the Unit will be the achievement of one consolidated view and a consistent approach to remote area issues, thus gaining outcomes and approaches across the three administrations-that is, in the north-west of Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland-which have often been at variance with one another. The Unit will provide greater opportunities to assemble departmental experts in a concentrated way to achieve solutions to remote area problems quickly, and will provide better targeting or prioritising of departmental service delivery activities in remote areas. In addition, there will be better long term planning to achieve solutions to current problems facing the Department in the delivery of services to remote areas, and, lastly, development opportunities provided for staff to work in remote localities and later to apply this knowledge to other operations within the Department.

In the choice of staff that the Department has operating in these areas, I would like to say that they are carrying out their functions extremely well. They have a high level of acceptance within the community. As I have said previously, they are to be applauded for their application to their tasks and the way in which they have genuinely tried to overcome the particular problems that confront social security clients in northern Australia.

Finally, I refer the House to the cost savings that this particular measure will bring about. I am sure the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) would applaud this, knowing his interest in public administration and his concern for the public purse. I understand cost savings which this will involve are about $5.4m. I believe that shows the Minister has adopted a very cost-effective and a cost-efficient approach to the administration of his portfolio. The Government has taken a number of significant steps towards a policy at administrative level to address the special needs of people throughout the social security system in Australia, of which this legislation is a fundamental part. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members who have contributed to the debate, particularly from my side of the House, the members for Phillip (Ms McHugh), Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) and the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). I think everyone who contributed to the debate referred to certain cases, certain situations, particularly the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who pointed to an extremely important area of Aboriginal custom and tradition and the difficulties of applying this Act to the real life situation of Aboriginal people in those remote areas of Australia. I assure the honourable member that the Northern Development Unit to which he referred is specifically being established to try to reverse the process, as it were, of the initiative in terms of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Very often we draft our policy and our approach to legislation in Canberra and then consider the implications for people around Australia. In this case, we are trying to look at some of the issues, some of the policy questions, within that remote area context, particularly focusing on the needs of Aboriginal people, so that we can begin to frame at least the policy questions and perhaps policy initiatives from that situation. I have certainly got great expectations of the unit. It is really only now being formally established, with staff being appointed, but in the next 12 months I am expecting to see a significant output.

The honourable member for Cowan referred to one of those very difficult cases that are not unknown in other parts of Australia. I appreciate very much the comments she made. I think we see the value but also the limitations of the appeals processes when we take cases such as the one referred to. It is important that we get it right in these areas, and I think that the changes to which the honourable member referred are somewhat fairer than the situation that existed earlier.

Of course, in social security one is always trying to apply the general rule and the law to a great myriad of individual circumstances, and it is extremely difficult to legislate in social security in such a way as to take account of all the circumstances that one needs to consider. Very often we find that we need the discretion that itself creates problems. The balance between good law and legislation and the need to preserve some discretion is one of the very difficult tensions in social security.

I very much appreciated the contribution from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and I acknowledge his expertise in this area, although I will have to disagree to some extent with his judgment. I have to say that although the honourable member for Bradfield likes to plead amnesia from time to time, the fact is that the previous Government left this country in a terrible mess and that was reflected perhaps more in the area of social security than anywhere else. When one fails to achieve proper management of an economy and one realises the levels of dependency of people of work-force age who were the legacy of the Fraser-Howard Government in 1982-83, that does put enormous pressure on any administrative system. In 1983 the Department of Social Security was struggling to cope with the massive numbers of people who had come into that system, particularly people on various kinds of benefits, principally unemployment benefits. That situation is perfectly understandable but it resulted in an administrative situation in which many of the proper controls and checks and balances within the social security system were simply relaxed and there was no really fair, effective and efficient administration.

A number of people have referred to this leaflet that was put out with the Budget kit on administrative and policy reform, 1983-1988. Any study of the outline of change would recognise that this Government has given the highest possible priority to administrative reform within the Department of Social Security. There has been a great deal of policy change but along with policy change there has also been very significant administrative reform. We have sought not only to review policy through the social security review but also to bring our legislation into line with policy with some major reforms of areas of the social security system in terms of the legislation.

I would have to say that the sheer rate of change in our period in government has itself represented something of a challenge to the regional officers in the Department of Social Security. I want to put on record how impressed I have been with the work that has been done by the Social Security Department in managing this rate of change, which has been necessary to achieve a more efficient and a fairer social security system. In the hundreds of offices around the country, I am always impressed with the quality of commitment of members of staff. They may be, as the honourable member for Bradfield suggested, mere class 5s, sometimes making important decisions, but nevertheless, they are highly committed to the task of being public servants responsible to administer legislation fairly and ensure that we have a system which runs with some integrity.

Perhaps some of the increase referred to by the honourable member for Bradfield in the number of appeals rejected by the Department-although I do not believe it has been as dramatic as he suggested-reflects in a sense the difficulty which the appeals tribunals themselves have had in getting on top of the change. We are talking about less than 15 per cent of appeals being overturned by the Department, not the much higher figure mentioned by the honourable member. Nevertheless, I would be the first to concede that there have been a greater number of rejections by the Department and I think that reflects in some respects the rate of change that has occurred in legislation, policy and tighter administration in the past two or three years.

The most important issue that was raised by the honourable member was the question to two-tier appeals. Perhaps the reasons for that go back to the fact that that was what was recommended by the Administrative Review Council (ARC). I gave a great deal of thought to the question of decision making powers for the Social Security Appeals Tribunal as was recommended at that time. The reason we did not move quickly there-and I think this is very much the point that the honourable member for Bradfield raised in his scathing criticism of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT)-was our concern about excessive legalism. We wanted to improve the administration of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal before taking that step to ensure that it was operating in a fully responsible way. We moved to appoint the principal members in various States and to take up most of the other recommendations of the ARC, leaving aside that particular question.

The people currently associated with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal are convinced that, as a result of getting decision making powers, there will not need to be excessive formality. By the same token, one recognises that there are various degrees of complexity of decisions that have to be made on questions of law. Of course we are talking about a situation whereby the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, as the honourable member for Bradfield rightly said, was dealing with a very large number of cases each year-something of the order of 12,000-whereas the Administrative Appeals Tribunal heard a relatively small number of social security cases.

There is no doubt that at the AAT level one is talking about a much greater expense per appeal. Within the context of our budgetary policy we are concerned about that particular issue, though I would not put too much weight on it. My prime concern in terms of structure is to ensure that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal continues to operate in a way that is sympathetic to the situation of the client and that it is not run in a legalistic way or as a court of law. I am concerned that it should be run so that people can meet and in a considered way can consider the circumstances that are in front of them, over and against the law. I am not at all convinced that that circumstance would apply in the context of the AAT as it is currently constituted-and I recognise that that is not what the honourable member for Bradfield was arguing-but I am convinced that at least for the time being it is important to provide for the possibility of appeal in cases where there is contention on the part of either the client or the Department and where there is a difficult or complex legal issue which needs to be resolved.

Those were the principal issues raised by the honourable member. I regard this legislation as significant. It is perhaps the first significant element in the task of rewriting our social security legislation. The honourable member will know that that is the challenge we are taking on as we move towards the end of the period of the social security review. While I cannot guarantee that all our legislation in the next few months will contribute significantly to that objective, I think this piece of legislation has a great deal of clarity. It not only sorts out the position of appeals tribunal but also clarifies the whole review system of the Department, the powers of the Secretary, the requirement of guidelines to be tabled and so on. The whole range of issues that are relevant in the review process are sorted out in a very clear way and it is a fine piece of legislation.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Howe) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 September, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas Airways Ltd is a prisoner of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) factions-it is a hostage of the left wing, and I am pleased that we have two members of the Left here at the table tonight-and it is a victim of the Government's policy paralysis. If that were not all true we would not have the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill in the House tonight. I begin by saying that the Opposition has no problems whatsoever with this Bill and does not oppose it. But the Bill is unnecessary. If the Government did what it should be doing and what everybody knows it should be doing there would be no need for the Commonwealth Government to provide a loan guarantee for Qantas Airways. Qantas would in fact be a listed public company and it would be borrowing money like every other company. Gerry, if you want to tell us about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission then I am happy to listen to you. But if you want to participate in this debate, you should go and see the Whip, put your name on the speakers list, and come in here and talk.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think we have had a number of gratuitous comments. The honourable member should refer to other members by their proper titles and he should address himself to the Bill rather than irrelevancies.
—There have been gratuitous comments from both sides of the House. The honourable member for Richmond will address the Chair.

—I am more than happy to acknowledge that the Minister, in taking what I thought was a frivolous point of order, has in fact learnt that one should refer to people by their appropriate names in this House, which is a lesson that I might have taught him at some stage. As for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), I think he had better consult with his left wing colleague and see how they are going to handle the emerging leadership challenge within the Australian Labor Party when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) returns.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. There is a particular Bill before the House. It might be in the interests of everybody if the honourable member, even though he admits that it is not necessary, gets on with whatever he has to say about the Bill.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Richmond will resume.
—How much time have you to fill in?
—Actually, I have quite a lot to say tonight. That is why the Opposition is moving an amendment. It will allow us to address some of the inadequacies of this Government. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

(1) regrets that Qantas has been prevented from selling shares to Qantas employees and the Australian people to provide a capital increase to facilitate expansion of the airline to cope with increasing passengers and freight; and
(2) notes that the Australian Taxation Office has issued a statement on debt defeasance, a procedure adopted by Qantas to finance the acquisition of new aircraft'.

We will now debate some of the more inadequate aspects of this Government's performance. As I said, this Bill is totally unnecessary because if Qantas were in fact a publicly listed company it would not need a Government guarantee to borrow the money that it needs. The Opposition laments the situation that the Government is cluttering this House with legislation which could be made redundant if it had the courage of its convictions to go on and do what is necessary. But, of course, we have this policy paralysis arising from the national convention. The Australian Labor Party (ALP) has set up a committee to see what it could do about Qantas.

We really come down to the crux of the matter that Qantas is in fact a good airline. It is doing a great job for Australia. This current Labor Government is not a good government and it is not doing a good job for Australia. It is not doing the right thing by Qantas. I find it amazing that any government would have the temerity to set up a committee at a Labor Party convention and put on the back burner an urgent and pressing economic decision, that is, what the future is for our national carrier. The members on the government benches have suddenly gone very quiet because they know that that is in fact the problem. They are not game to address what is a major problem in our country simply because they cannot achieve agreement within their own factions. As I said, Qantas has become a prisoner of the factions and a hostage of the left wing.

The reason we want to debate the need for Qantas to cease becoming wholly owned by the Commonwealth Government and for shares to be sold to its employees and to the Australian public is that air traffic into Australia is growing dramatically. Qantas, if it is to maintain its share of that growing air traffic-it is in the interests of all Australians for it to do so-must expand. At the present time we have about 2.25 million tourists coming to Australia each year. Qantas has about 43 per cent of that traffic. By the year 2000 a conservative estimate is that we will have about 5 million tourists coming to this country. It will probably be considerably more.

If Qantas is to maintain its market share and its earnings for Australia it will need to grow, and to grow it will need to spend a lot of money. In this House yesterday, I mentioned that Qantas was looking to spend $5 billion. I was corrected by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). I welcome his correction. He said I was wrong. It is not $5 billion; it is $6 billion. This simply adds emphasis to the point that I will make later tonight. Someone has to address the question of where the money is coming from and what the financing proposals will be.

Qantas currently runs a fleet of about 34 aircraft. It has 25 Boeing 747 and 9 Boeing 767 aircraft. But by 1992, which is only four years away, Qantas wants a fleet of 52 aircraft-37 Boeing 747 and 15 Boeing 767 aircraft. They are very expensive. This Bill that we are debating here tonight is a Bill for the purchase of a relatively few Boeing 767s. The amount of money that this Bill deals with is $250m. It is a lot of money; aircraft are very expensive. To take the Qantas fleet from 34 to 52 will take a lot more than $250 million. It will take of the order of $6 billion. The problem is that Qantas does not have sufficient capital to justify borrowing that amount of money because this is what this Bill does: it is a loan guarantee Bill and Qantas is borrowing. It could continue to borrow. What would happen is that its interest repayments would become a greater proportion of its obligation. We could go back to the situation in which the annual interest payments for Qantas exceeded its paid up capital. That is not a desirable situation. That was the situation that existed not so long ago. In prudent commercial terms it should not move in that direction.

Qantas itself acknowledges that it needs between $400m and $600m in order to put it on a reasonable commercial basis. The Government knows that it cannot afford to put that amount of money into Qantas. It also knows the cost that the Australian community will bear if Qantas does not maintain its relative size in the international market and maintain its market share. We only have to look at what is happening to the United States carriers and other carriers around the world. There is aggregation and they are growing.

The growth in air traffic in our region, into Australia, because of the growth in our tourist industry is significant. There is a need for Qantas to maintain that market share in our national interest. It is in our national interest for Qantas to grow. That is why this Government is culpable for not addressing the Qantas problem. The Government is made doubly culpable not because it cannot address the mechanism but because it is not game to address it as a result of dissension within its factions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the micro-reforms?

—As my effective colleague the shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), has pointed out-he is well aware of the significance of Qantas and technology to this country-there is a need for this problem to be addressed. It really comes down to how we are going to pay for it. This Government, obviously because it is too hard to come to some sort of compromise or deal within the factions, is going to keep borrowing money. It is commercially not a very good idea. Qantas knows it is not a very good idea. Of course, what the Government really should be doing is floating shares in Qantas right now. As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was about to interject, I will explain to him why now is a very good time to act. Qantas is trading very well at the moment. Tourism is very buoyant and profitability is there. It would be possible to sell shares in Qantas at a premium at present and reduce the cost into the future of raising the capital which would put Qantas on a far better financial base. It would reduce its gearing and reduce the obligations of the Commonwealth Government. It would allow the airline to expand, the way other airlines are expanding, and it would provide a greater earnings capacity for Australia. Qantas has the capacity to become one of the great international companies of Australia. It is a company which is capable of earning vast quantities of foreign exchange. Everybody in this chamber knows that we need a lot of foreign exchange because I do not think the Treasurer's predictions for the balance of payments will come off. They seem to be way off at present. We will have a continuing problem into the foreseeable future. Every opportunity that we can get to earn foreign exchange should be grasped with both hands. We certainly cannot afford to push it off simply because it is a bit awkward for the ALP. This country is bigger than the ALP. This country is about all the people who live here. If it is going to cause a bit of heartache for a few of the factional bosses within the ALP that is tough.
—Ideological loonies.

—Ideological loonies is right. What is more important to this country in the long term-the success of Qantas or a bit of factional peace within the ALP? I know what the average Australian thinks. He wants our airline to grow and to prosper and he wants to gain the benefits that come from that. He would not be worried if the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) or the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) had to knock a few heads together. They are there to get the job done, to govern in the interests of Australia, not the ALP factions.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP cannot really come to grips with this issue without tearing itself apart. It has problems, as we know. The Treasurer will return to the country very soon and the Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), will probably greet him at the airport and tell him about all the questions that he could not answer and ask what he should have said. They will then probably jointly go to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and say, `We both have the same opinion as to your future'. I read about that in the newspaper today. I think it is a very good idea, too. I think the Prime Minister should retire. The terminal decay which has set in in the Labor Party could then run riot.

Another issue is raised by this Bill which I think members of this House will be interested to hear about, and I am sure that the public also will be interested to hear about it. It highlights the inadequacy of the second reading speech that the Minister made when he introduced this Bill because it does not cover this issue at all. There is something fundamentally wrong with a government that is not prepared to talk in detail about the financing arrangements of a company that it owns 100 per cent. I do not mind Qantas doing what it is doing, provided it is legal and above board; but I think it is shameful that the Government is not prepared to talk about it. The issue I want to talk about is the second aspect of my amendment; that is, debt defeasance. Let me read briefly from an article that appeared in a newspaper not so long ago. It was a very interesting article. I think it raises at least questions as to why the Minister, in introducing this Bill, did not explain fully what the financing arrangements were. From reading the second reading speech of the Minister, one would think that it was about a straightforward loan guarantee Bill whereby Qantas will borrow some money, take it across to the Boeing aircraft company and get the aircraft. That is what one would think from reading the speech. But, of course, it is a long way from that. Let me explain how this works by quoting from the article written by Tom Ballantyne. The article states:
The aircraft purchase began simply, with Qantas ordering four new 767-300 extended-range passenger jets from the huge Boeing aircraft company in Seattle.
That is in the United States of America. The article continues:
The places are to be delivered in September, October, November and December. They will enter service with Qantas named after the cities of Whyalla, Bendigo, Kalgoorlie and Maitland.

But before the aircraft touch down in Australia, Qantas will sell the planes to Japan, using Sydney lease-management company Babcock and Brown, which has previously handled similar deals for the airline.
They are dealing in Japan with an affiliate company, Namura Babcock and Brown . . . which will set up separate lease companies for each of the four new aircraft.
