On paper, NBB pays Qantas for the planes by raising 80 per cent of the money from Barclays Bank in Japan. The remaining 20 per cent comes in as equity capital from Japanese investors.
The jets with the flying kangaroo on the tail are now officially Japanese, and thus qualify the new owners for tax benefits and depreciation under Japanese tax laws.
According to Qantas director Mr Max Haworth, the Japanese will then share the profit with Qantas.

The NBB will then in effect sell the aircraft back to Qantas, but not directly. The Japanese will issue Qantas with a lease and an option to buy the planes on hire purchase through Barclays International Leasing in the Dutch Antilles, a small island group in the Caribbean.
Qantas will then buy the planes back through Barclays.
To this chain of entities we add the Barclays branch in the Cayman Islands, also in the Caribbean. The article continues:
Qantas pays the bank a fee to defease-
which means to do away with-
the rental obligations and part of the purchase option (. . . an accounting technique which cancels repayments on the loan principal).
The planes, bought back on hire purchase, will then become Australian again, qualifying Qantas for tax benefits and depreciation under Australian tax rules.

It is a very complex financing arrangement. There is no reference to it whatsoever in the Bill. I do not have any problem with Qantas doing so, provided it is legal. In fact, if every other airline in the world is doing it, Qantas has to do it to compete. Let us face it, we are out there in the world economy. We are competing, as the Treasurer constantly tells us, and we cannot afford to tie one hand behind the back of Qantas if it has to compete with United Airlines, Continental Airlines, Japan Airlines, Lufthansa or any other international airline that probably uses the same fairly sophisticated financing techniques. I am told that the Australian Taxation Office believes that there are many 747s flying around the world courtesy of tax arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit like Bill Hayden.
—No, Bill is not flying courtesy of tax arrangements.
—No, but courtesy of the taxpayers.

—Courtesy of the taxpayers. He just has his snout in the trough. Let me get back to the fundamental issue of debt defeasance, which I think the Minister should address. Why is the Government not prepared to make a statement about debt defeasance when it brings in a loan guarantee Bill? The Government knows exactly what the financing arrangements for Qantas are but it makes no reference to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw the attention of the Minister to a tax ruling headed `Income Tax Debt Defeasance Liability Assumption'. The date of the ruling was 15 September 1988 and the time of effect was immediate. I expect the Minister, when he sums up this debate, to make a comment about the financing arrangements of Qantas in terms of this tax ruling. If this Government is to provide loan guarantees for this financing arrangement, the Parliament deserves to know exactly how the financing of these aircraft will be undertaken and what relationship it has, if any, to this tax ruling issued recently by the Australian Commissioner of Taxation.

In conclusion, it is deplorable and lamentable that this Government is not prepared to address the real issues. Instead, the Minister comes into this chamber with a superficial second reading speech that talks briefly about scheduling increases and bringing forward the delivery of aircraft when the Bill is about appropriating about $250m and involves a very complex financing arrangement. If the Government wants the Parliament to vote on this legislation it ought to tell the Parliament what is involved in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the contribution of the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), we seem to have travelled all round the world. I suppose that is fairly appropriate, given the context of the legislation that we are debating tonight. I would like to bring the attention of the House back to the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill, but I would also like to make some comments on the points that the shadow Minister raised because I have also seen the newspaper article entitled `You own the airline, Japanese own the Jumbos', written by Tom Ballantyne, which the shadow Minister read into Hansard in the course of his delivery tonight. I will make some comments about that a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill actually authorises the Treasurer (Mr Keating), on behalf of the Commonwealth, to guarantee borrowings raised by Qantas Airways Ltd to finance the purchase of three Boeing 767-300 extended range aircraft. As has been pointed out, they will be delivered in October, November and December of this year. They will provide Qantas with greater flexibility in meeting the requirements of the rapidly growing inbound tourist market. They will be used primarily on the Tasman and Japanese routes, two of Qantas's and Australia's important markets. That, I think, raises an interesting issue about the tourist industry in this country and the source of our tourists. If honourable members take the opportunity to look in Qantas's annual report of 1986-87 and at its interim results of 1987-88 they will find the statistics thrown up quite interesting. For example, in January to July 1987 the number of tourists coming into this country was estimated at 106,200. In 1988 for the same period that number has jumped to 188,300, a 77 per cent increase. That is on the Japanese route. On the New Zealand, or Tasman, route 230,100 came in that six-month period, January to July 1987, but that number increased to 286,300 in the same period in 1988, which represents a 24 per cent increase. It is a fact that New Zealand is the largest single source of inbound tourists to Australia. They account for something like 17 per cent of all international arrivals. The Japanese on the other hand at present account for something like 13 per cent of the total arrivals, but this particular segment of Australia's tourist market is growing at the highest rate.

The Bureau of Tourism Research has projected that by 1990 the number of tourists coming from New Zealand on the Tasman route will increase to 446,000, which is about 16 per cent of the total number of tourists coming into this country. For the Japanese tourists that number will increase to 465,000, which represents about 17 per cent of our total intake. Other Asian countries will also provide a considerable number of tourists to Australia and that number is growing at the rate of 26 per cent per annum. They are interesting statistics because they reinforce Qantas's position in deciding to buy these sorts of aircraft and to place them on the Tasman route and the Japanese route.

It is also important, in view of the contribution made by the honourable member for Richmond, to talk about the success of Qantas. Again, if honourable members look at some of the statistics that are available they will find it very interesting to reflect upon what has happened to Australia's national carrier since the Hawke Government has been responsible in a direct sense for Qantas and to compare those statistics with the position, in an operating sense, under the former Government. If honourable members look at the past seven years of operations, which is quite a reasonable measure by anyone's standard, they will see that in 1982 Qantas made a loss of approximately $220m. In 1983 it made a loss of $47m. However, in 1984, with a change of government, amazingly it made a profit of $58m. It went from a loss of $47m in 1983 to a profit of $58m in 1984. In 1985 the profit was $62m. In 1986 it fell back to $44m, nevertheless it was still a profit. In 1987 it was $104m, and in 1988 it is projected to be $150m on the interim results that have been put forward. That profit between 1987 and 1988 represents a 47 per cent increase in profit margins on its operations.

We heard the honourable member for Richmond say that this is an airline that is in desperate need of a cash injection, that is in desperate need of being put out into the public domain, that is desperately searching for an identity. He said that it is an operation that could become one of the greatest airlines of the world if only it were given a free hand by the Government. In response to those comments, for Qantas to be taken from a $20m loss in operations in 1982 to a $150m profit in prospect in 1988-89 to me does not sound as though it is doing all that badly. We also have to take into consideration the comments made by the honourable member for Richmond about the need for Qantas to continue its growth, to aggregate and to do all the sorts of things that he said carriers in the US were doing where aggregation has taken place. Following deregulation, which some people saw as being the panacea for introducing lower fares, more regular services, and all the rest of it, certainly in the initial phases more airline companies operated-many of them fly-by-nighters-but they have now gone out of business or they have been swallowed up by the larger carriers. So US Air, Continental, et cetera, are buying out smaller airline operations and expanding their networks.

The honourable member for Richmond made quite a bit of that and suggested that that is what Qantas should do. He suggested that it should get bigger and become a major airline in this region. I remind the honourable member that that is exactly what Qantas is endeavouring to do. It is, as all honourable members would know, the preferred tenderer in a 25 per cent purchase of Air New Zealand. As I understand it, the Government of New Zealand is presently deliberating upon that very fact: should Qantas, an Australian airline, be permitted to purchase 25 per cent of Air New Zealand? The honourable member for Richmond says that Qantas was starved for cash, starved for capital, and there is a need to turn it out into the public sector where people, either within the company or the general public, can purchase shares.

I suppose that the honourable member for Richmond in moving the amendment which states that `the House . . . regrets that Qantas has been prevented from selling shares to Qantas employees and the Australian people' probably has in mind some of the schemes which presently operate in the United States where companies in trouble sell shares to their own employees and operate a very complex relationship with those employees. When certain profit levels are reached dividends have to be paid to their employees. There is nothing wrong with that. It sounds like a pretty good sort of a scheme. But there is also in some cases in the United States-and I am thinking particularly of some of the steel mills in that country-a second part of the agreement which says that once the employees purchase those shares and the shares reach a certain profit level in the company, the company is obligated to buy those shares back.

One company in the United States of which I am aware, Wierton Steel in Pittsburgh, has reached the magic profit margin. Half of it has to be spent on providing dividends to the shareholders, being the employees, and the other half has gone out because the shareholders, the employees, have decided they want to cash out their shares. So the whole of the profit is gone and the steel company, which needs to upgrade its facilities, has absolutely nothing. How does it compete? The honourable member for Richmond should take that into consideration when he decides to move an amendment of this nature.

I would also like to refer to some comments the honourable member for Richmond made when talking about a newspaper article written by Tom Ballantyne. The honourable member asked the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) when summing up this debate to investigate the methodology by which the aircraft were purchased by Qantas. He detailed-in fact he read into the Hansard-the article.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's all he said. He read the newspaper article. It was a pretty long speech.
—It was all he had to say. It was a pretty poor speech. However, he did read the article well into the Hansard.
—I'd give him two out of 10 for the speech.

—I would give him 2 1/2. Some questions have been raised about the use of tax havens in that arrangement. The Cayman Islands is one and the Dutch Antilles is another. Questions have been raised about the methodology of leasing, about who owns the jets in the first instance and about whether there is some legal or moral question of taxation liabilities. Let me say to the honourable member for Richmond that this issue is presently being reviewed by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its review of international profit shifting. One would hope that some light will be shed on it when the report is finally tabled in this Parliament later this year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that the Australian Taxation Office has handed down a ruling on the tax issues associated with the leasing and purchasing arrangement, complex as it is, associated with the purchase of these aircraft. Every manoeuvre that has been employed has been legal under the taxation regimes of both Japan and Australia-totally, unequivocally legal. There has been no problem with any of those operations. The fact that banks in tax havens may have been used, I believe, is worthy of some consideration. Nevertheless, there is nothing illegal about what has happened. There is a benefit to Australia in getting aircraft at a much reduced cost. Obviously, any organisation would attempt to do so. As I have indicated, the question of that tax ruling is one that will be pursued. As I have also indicated, the question of tax havens and their use in this instance is worthy of pursuit and that is being done through the Committee I am involved with.

I suggest to those people involved in this debate tonight that it is most important that Qantas be supported in its endeavours to provide opportunities for further income to come to this country because of the number of seats it can sell on its aircraft. We have seen examples of that. The company plans to operate 154 extra round trips this summer to accommodate the anticipated higher demand, basically through the use of these aircraft. It is also going to lease other aircraft. Qantas, our premier flag carrier, our international airline, has to be supported in those endeavours.

The new schedules will take effect in November, which reflects an increase each week of about 6,700 seats, or an equivalent of 17 jumbo jets compared with last summer's schedules. Qantas would not be doing it if the demand was not there. Rather than coming in here and suggesting that there is a debate on privatisation that is impeding Qantas, one has only to look at the reports I have quoted and the financial figures I have cited and at the increase in traffic. Again I refer honourable members to the annual report of 1986-87 and the table which appears on page 2. The number of kilometres flown in 1987 was 92,291,000 compared to 1986, when it was only 76,546,000-an increase of 20.6 per cent. In 1987 over 3 million passengers were carried compared to only 2.5m in 1986, a 16.8 per cent increase.

Those statistics are here for everyone to see. Qantas is operating effectively. It is operating efficiently. Considerations about capital injection are necessary to enable Qantas to reduce its debt to equity ratio, but those issues are under consideration by the Government. This is a Bill worthy of support. It is simple. It is not complicated, as was suggested by the honourable member for Richmond. It does not beg the question about problems associated with who owns it and who provides the capital and so on. As I have indicated, more than adequate evidence is there to suggest that the company is operating extremely well, thank you very much.

The issues of the taxation rulings and the purchasing arrangements have benefited Australia. In a pure legal sense they have been proven to be totally legal and totally above board. I reject the amendment that has been moved. I am sure that the honourable member for Richmond was not really serious when he chose to put it forward-nor does he expect it to get up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendment. In doing so, I draw a couple of matters to the attention of the House. I doubt whether there would be any honourable member who would not have used Qantas Airways Ltd in some respect in the last few years. They would have found its services, particularly its in-flight services, very competitive and of a very high standard compared with those of the rest of the international carriers. There is some considerable difference these days in the quality of service provided.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I must immediately diverge to the realities of life and pick up the last annual report of Qantas-a wholly owned government enterprise. Looking at its accounts, I immediately see a company that is vastly under-capitalised. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) would recognise that. Anybody in the chamber would recognise that. This operation has fixed assets-outlined in its balance sheet; these are the latest accounts, to the end of 1987-of a total value of $2 billion on an authorised and paid up capital of $149m. Any clown could tell you that that is not on. It is just not a rating value. Any member of the Labor Party backbench could tell you that. They cannot tell us we should privatise Qantas because that goes against the socialism at the heart of the Labor Party. The Government starves a major competitor in an industry which requires millions of dollars every year to be able to compete. The Government does not seem to be able to understand where the money comes from. It owns all the shares and it expects the company to pay taxation and a dividend. As I said, Qantas has an authorised paid up capital of $149m and total assets of $2 billion.

I quote from its balance sheet. It says that loan drawings raised $237m through a Euro commercial paper program to assist in the finance of aircraft. Increased creditors and deferred revenue towards sales contributed a further $79m. Funds outflowed included payments of $125m-I am rounding the figures-as deposit and progress payments on additional aircraft and related equipment and $108m paid on other fixed assets, equipment and investments. Loan repayments during the year required $62m. The Government required a dividend of $14.9m. Increases in current assets totalled $506m, including cash at bank, in hand and on deposit.

We are not talking about a peanut show. We are talking in very large figures-against a paid up capital that the Government owns of $149m. It is a total disgrace. No wonder the Chairman of Qantas, Jim Leslie, says that Qantas needs an immediate injection of $300m for starters. I am not surprised. The Government is drawing from it a dividend of $14.9m. The tax payment for the year is $50m. I find it quite extraordinary.

It is no wonder that this company is forced to lease its aircraft. These lease arrangements are of a sophisticated nature. They involve offshore registration and offshore funding, all of which have high taxation significance. The Commissioner of Taxation says, `Do not worry about the law. It is what you think the law means, what the intention is'. This company, which is wholly owned by the Government, is using the most significant and highly sophisticated tax mechanisms in the book. There is nothing wrong with that. What it is doing is completely right, but members of the Government say that Mr Boucher is right. If Boucher is right, Qantas is wrong. They cannot have it both ways. The Government owns Qantas 100 per cent. If Boucher is wrong and Qantas is right, Boucher should be told what his position is. He is not an interpreter of the law. Parliament writes the law, and it is not for Boucher to interpret it. Members of the Government should make up their minds on these taxation matters.

Qantas is being forced into these arrangements because the Government will not contribute the capital necessary to fund the airline's ongoing operations. That is apparent in the balance sheet itself. Before I look at that, I draw attention to an article in the Economist of 30 July 1988 which refers to the projected growth of world airline traffic between 1988 and 2005. It forecasts that the growth in America will be roughly static; in Western Europe it will probably decline marginally; in the area of Asia and the Pacific it will increase by approximately 50 per cent; and in the area of Japan it will increase by approximately 50 per cent. There will be a small decline in the Middle East; a 25 per cent increase in Latin America; a small decrease in Africa; and a small decrease in Canada. This shows the enormous growth that will occur in the areas in which Qantas predominantly has its routes. In order to handle this, Qantas must be in a position to finance its operations adequately. It will be operating in the fastest growing area and, as the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) knows better than I, he being a veteran traveller and experienced airline man, this company will require an enormous increase in capacity to be able to cope with the projected demands of world changes in the next 20 years.

The balance sheet for 1987 shows a paid-up capital of $149m and total assets amounting to $2 billion, but there are large off-balance sheet figures involved in leasing arrangements, probably something of the order of the assets outstanding. So there is probably $2 billion shown in the off-balance sheet statements. What does the Government think it is running? A two-up school?

Today's issue of the Commonwealth Bank annual report indicates a similar position. In the past 12 months the asset position of the Commonwealth Bank has not changed. Every other bank in Australia had a significant increase in its asset position. Qantas, starved of capital, is required to pay a dividend, required to pay taxation, and so uses the most sophisticated financial measures in relation to its leasing and offshore taxation arrangements. This is forced upon it by the actions of the Government.

What would the Opposition do in relation to this matter? In view of the very large outstanding commitments of Qantas, the projection of the Economist of a 50 per cent increase in traffic over the next 20 years and the shortage of capital, the Opposition would simply offer the existing public company a substantial expansion of its capital base. We would take it up from $149m to at least $500m, as a starting point. Those shares would be offered first to Qantas employees. When I recently travelled on Qantas I asked the stewards what they thought of having access to ownership of shares in their airline. I did not find one member of the staff flying that night who was not keen to be in it-and one of those stewards was a member of the Australian Labor Party. He could not understand why his lot were not on side with the idea. He was not a bad steward either. He seemed a bit misled in some areas but he certainly knew the value of Qantas. As a consequence of that, I have no doubt that the staff would be involved. The balance of shares would be offered to the public at a market rating appropriate to the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —With safeguards.
—With appropriate safeguards concerning foreign ownership.
—How many would the pensioners buy?

—Pensioners who could save a few bob would buy every one they could lay their hands on and they would do a better job than those who walk around the nation with price watch schemes. At the end of all this Qantas would have a $500m capital base listed on the stock exchange, would be paying dividends which would be higher than those paid at the moment, because it would not have to pay so much interest-and it would be paying a higher rate of taxation for the same reasons-and because of the employee incentive to increase productivity of the airline to meet the competition there would be a far greater spirit. People who own equity in a company have a surprising degree of commitment to the performance of that company. Even Western Australian members would probably reach a little further in doing things if they were financially involved.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence of that there would be a massive increase in the profitability of the company, with a resultant relief to some of the company's capital debts. It might well be that $500m is nowhere near the capital base necessary to meet the demand by the year 2000, in view of the projected increases in demand in Japan and the Asian and Pacific areas. But it would be a modest beginning which would involve Qantas employees and other Australian investors in setting up a more substantial base for the company which would then bring about greater profitability and greater presentation.

I shall briefly allude to another recent innovation. The Government is now allowing Qantas to enter into a deal with Air New Zealand. It is really an extension of the old British nationalisation system. Here is a company which is undercapitalised, at $149m, ordering aeroplanes for the future-and using sophisticated offshore tax arrangements to do so-and all of a sudden it is moving to buy 25 per cent of Air New Zealand. What is the reason for this? Taxpayers' money is being committed to a deal that is not wanted. It is clear that Qantas does not want it; that was clearly stated by its chairman. The Air New Zealand people appear not to want it because they are doing a great bagging job on the deal in the background. The Government is proposing to put up taxpayers' money-more borrowed money, not its money. It is going to borrow some more money to get into it. If it is successful, do not think Air New Zealand is mug enough to say, `That's good enough; we won't call up more money from you guys as major contributors'. That is the first thing it will do. The first thing Qantas is going to have to do is put up the brass to buy planes for Air New Zealand. What is it going to be able to do, with the capital base here, but borrow more money offshore to fund planes for Air New Zealand?

What do we hear from the Government? Not a peep. It all helps with this good old game of owning things in the public sector. It does not have to justify things to the lefties in the Australian Labor Party or that lot who want to continue public ownership. Those people know that if they were to give up the ghost and allow these things to be privatised, then the real control would slip from the trade union movement. The losers would be the trade union movement. They are the ones who are most concerned about it. It is not the personnel of Qantas who want privatisation, it is not the management of Qantas who want privatisation, and it is not the board membership, in the main, who want privatisation, as the Chairman has said. That case falls totally to the ground. I return, if I may, to the case put before us tonight in which we are approving--

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't done too well so far.

—I have done a damn sight better than the honourable member in relation to arguing the case of privatisation. I have not seen anything in what he has put forward about how Qantas is going to survive to the year 2000-not a word. It will not survive if the Labor Party here continues to force Qantas to borrow funds offshore in leasing arrangements which are straight tax dodges. It is a complete farce in every respect and a case of double standards in relation to the taxation agreements that it goes on about with Boucher.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in conclusion that no government enterprise in the future will be able to withstand the call from its employees to be freed and to be able to prosper. Any politician or political party that wants to stand out there and say `We are going to continue to run you as a government' will be swept aside. I say this because part of what Gorbachev is on about in Russia is the acknowledgment that the economic system will not function under a socialist scheme without personal incentive.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you know?

—I was there a couple of weeks ago and that is what is going on. The Minister ought to have a trip. They will give him one too. As a consequence, not only communist China but Russia is turning to personal incentive. That is what perestroika is all about-getting the system going, getting the economy going. If those countries can see it, how strange is it that the Australian Labor Party cannot see it in relation to its own enterprises?
—Is Aeroflot on the market?
—If Aeroflot is on the market at a reasonable price the Government ought to buy it because it has got a long way to go back to reasonable operations.
—Can you pick it up?

—I would not expect the honourable member to understand that. At price watch they are not in the game of making money. He would be far better on cornflakes than he would be on aeroplanes. The consequence of that, I would suggest, is that the whole emphasis of the Government as it relates to funding of public enterprises needs to be reviewed, needs to be understood. If it does not adequately fund publicly owned enterprises like Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank, Australian Airlines, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and many others, all of them within 10 years will be virtually out the window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1988, which I must say has hardly been touched on by members of the Opposition, relates to the authorising by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of borrowings and the guarantee of borrowings by Qantas. There are few-in fact I am bound to say there is no-one-on either side of the House who would disagree that there is a need for Qantas to increase its fleet of aircraft. Indeed, the growth that has occurred in the trans-Tasman route and between Australia and Japan has been so significant that it is necessary for these aircraft to be purchased.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not surprised that the debate turned around to one of privatisation. I suppose one of the things we learn in this place is that hindsight is a very valuable commodity. But if we look at the figures which relate to Qantas at the time when the Opposition held the purse strings and sat on the government benches in this place, it is very interesting to find that between 1976 and 1983, when we came to government, there was a very small injection of capital into Qantas-$25 million-by the former Government. During those seven years, at a time when Qantas was in a parlous state, the capital injection provided by the Opposition was only $25m, hardly enough for Qantas in any of those years to turn over a dividend. Indeed, in only one of those years did it do so. So did the Opposition in those seven lean years embark on the strategy that it now proposes, to privatise Qantas? Did it provide significant capital for Qantas, an airline which then was greatly in need of capital-I do not think anybody on either side of the House would suggest that is not the case now-either by injection from government sources or by taking the course which it now proposes?

What was the Opposition's attitude to domestic airlines in this country? Were the bastions of private enterprise, these great free marketeers, involved in deregulating the airlines of this country or were they involved in providing a straitjacket which I suppose is now, after initiatives by this Government, finally to be removed? Certainly, the rhetoric of members of the Opposition is very interesting to hear but, if we look at its performance and its record in government, we find that, far from privatising, deregulating and providing the capital that was necessary for Qantas, its approach was completely different.

I do not think any of us would disagree that the airline industry is a high-tech industry. Very expensive aeroplanes, expensive capital equipment and expensive computer facilities need to be bought. Because of the success of this Government's tourism policy and because of the massive increase in the number of people wanting to visit Australia, there is a massive increase in demand and there has been a massive increase in the profitability of Qantas. That is something for which this Government can take credit.

The Government is aware that Qantas is in need of capital injection. That is not anything we run away from or anything we have hidden from. Indeed, a number of papers produced by the Government have expounded that view. But what we need to realise is that this issue is being considered in a very broad context, just as this Government has taken a broad approach to a number of issues relating to the economy. We inherited an economy which was too dependent on rural and mineral commodities, an economy which was not adaptable and which could not respond to the influences of overseas changes and absorb the shocks that inevitably come from overseas. So the Government took the macro-economic focus and brought about a more mature, adaptable and flexible economy for the country by floating the dollar, deregulating our financial system, liberalising foreign investment and reforming the taxation system, and in a number of other ways we have produced that sort of economy. In the same way, we took an approach to government business enterprises which would make them more efficient and allow them in a number of ways to compete more readily. At the same time we were looking very closely at many of those government business enterprises.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: International Airline Services-Lithgow-Chicken Meat Industry-Lt-Col. Gawler-Tax File Number

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve months ago in this House I raised a matter of public importance concerning the capacity of international airlines to handle inbound traffic to Australia. Honourable members who are present tonight may remember that debate, because I expressed my concern that in many ports outside Australia a total of about 45,000 people were waiting for seats on flights into Australia. I remember the response of the Government at that time and, indeed, the response of the national airline, Qantas Airways Ltd, to my accusations. In my files in my office-which I will keep forever-I have a telex from Qantas which is about 2 1/2 metres long, telling me how I had been misled, how I was not telling the truth, and how I was exaggerating the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise that issue again tonight. At the beginning of October this year, in the ports of Asia up to 45 people per flight were waiting for seats on flights into Australia. Those people were not Australians waiting to come home; they were international visitors who wanted to come here and spend their money, thus helping our foreign receipt earnings. Once again we have not learnt the lesson.

The debate that preceded the adjournment tonight was very interesting because it was at the crux of what I am talking about. We do not seem to have a capacity to judge markets, to get our instrumentalities to adapt to market demands. Once again we are facing an absolutely farcical situation. International visitors who want to come to Australia cannot get seats on flights into the country. My question is: When will we ever learn? This is not the first time that I have tried to promote in this place the concept of opening up the skies of Australia so that the tourist industry can reach its true capacity. It seems to me to be absolutely farcical that, when we have a government that is doing its very best-and I concede that point-to promote Australia as an international tourist destination, we do not seem to have the capacity to promote the infrastructure to make sure that we can handle the business.

The most farcical situation that we have seen has occurred in Brisbane. I refer to World Expo 88. Five years ago there were projections of the numbers of international visitors who were expected to come to Australia to visit Expo. Who took any notice of those projections from organisations such as the Boeing International Corporation? The answer is that nobody took any notice. Throughout the staging of Expo we have found that people could not get seats on flights into Brisbane or, indeed, into Australia when they wanted to come.

The real condemnation of government instrumentalities is that, finally, Australia's national carrier, about five months ago, recognised what the real demands were going to be. I congratulate Qantas for introducing a new schedule for the port of Brisbane to cope with Expo. The new schedule came into operation on 1 October-29 days before Expo will end. That is the problem that we have. While we talk about the tremendous contribution that tourism is making to our foreign account situation-it is quite true that it is our second biggest hard currency earner at the moment-we do not seem to have the capacity to provide the wherewithal to bring it all about.

The really sad condemnation of this Government is that it has had notice of this situation for the last five years. I congratulate it for its overseas promotional efforts. I condemn it for its failure to provide infrastructure to meet the demand, which will not go away. Two million international visitors will come into Australia this year. By the year 2000 we will have five million. In an earlier debate in this place today we spoke about leasing three Boeing 767s. What do they carry? They carry 220 passengers each. And we have to more than double the size of the international tourism market into Australia. We do not know what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the finest sporting achievements by one of my constituents was the recent courageous effort by Graham `Spike' Cheney to win a silver medal at the Seoul Olympics in boxing. There could be no overstatement of the bravery and straight-out guts of this young man who, at only 19, has taken on some of the toughest and hardest hitting sportsmen in the world today. Given this fact, it is not surprising that the people of Lithgow are bursting with pride and admiration for his efforts. In fact, Lithgow is a very proud community. It is a very close-knit community. The people of Lithgow stick together. Sporting clubs from other nearby towns and cities in the electorate think twice when they have to play a Lithgow side at Lithgow because they know the home crowd will be big and will be vocal in support of its side. That is just the sort of place that Lithgow is. So one can imagine the justifiable reaction of the people of Lithgow to a number of insipid and patronising articles in the Sydney media about the home of Spike Cheney.

SPEECH.PARA: The strongest reaction has been against a bit of a `colour' piece that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 30 September. Apparently the paper had sent someone to Lithgow to `get the local feeling' on the night of the semi-final bout. Unfortunately one night in Lithgow was apparently not enough to get an accurate portrait of the place, its people and its character. This article must rate as one of the most condescending bits of fiction in the name of journalism that I have ever read. An editorial more correctly expressing the mood and feelings of the people of Lithgow appeared in the Lithgow Mercury the next day criticising the Sydney media. I would like to quote directly from the editorial, because there is no way I could better word my criticism of the Sydney Morning Herald report. I quote:

The report was more like an episode of Dad and Dave. A few quotes: ``They had gathered at the Lithgow's spiritual heart, the Landowne (sic) Hotel, to cheer one of their own''. Even Barry Rushworth wouldn't describe the Lansdowne ``the Spiritual Heart''. ``They were all there-his football mates, town bikes, his drinking companions''-Bikies? Football mates? A teetotaller's drinking mates?-``none of them could really pronounce Seoul. . .'' We must have forgotten to mention that we've all been on correspondence lessons since the old bush school burnt down. ``These were people who don't display emotion easily''. . . the reporter clearly wasn't there at closing time.
. . . and this classic. . .
. . . ``they grouped around an ancient radio cassette. . .''
Wonder what Sky Channel thinks of that?
. . . or this one. . .
``Faces creased with the hard lives of a miner rested upon shoulders of their mates and concentrated on the small grey radio''.
. . . and to finish up. . .

``. . . cheers swamped the small pub where most of Lithgow had gathered''. That must be why there was no one at Lithgow's other eight pubs or four clubs on Thursday and children at home were howling for their mums and dads.
We hesitate to imagine what they'll write if they turn up for Spike's welcome home next week . . . that's if the stage into town is still running.

While the Sydney media have tried to poke fun at the City of Greater Lithgow, not recognising even that it is even a city, the people of Lithgow have been working very hard toward the more serious task of promoting the city. Yes, the city has had its problems with the closure of mines and economic hardship that this produces, but civic leaders and the population as a whole have been making a tremendous effort to promote the positive aspects of the city. Very few Sydney people would associate Lithgow with other important business enterprises, such as the Small Arms Factory, which is currently producing a new generation of small weapons for the Army, or to the textile industry which provides valuable employment, particularly to women in Lithgow. And of course how many city people would be aware of Lithgow's other Olympic success story? Berlei-Hestia, which has a factory in Lithgow, was the official supplier of the undergarments worn by our female Olympic athletes. Lithgow also has a burgeoning tourist industry, with the Zig Zag railway attracting thousands of visitors each year. The Greater Lithgow Development Task Force, funded under the Country Centres Project, is looking at still further ways of diversifying the economy and making the most of the human and natural resources of the area.

But still, media sources from east of the Blue Mountains continue in their efforts to portray Lithgow as a depressed and depressing mining community-not the vibrant commercial and social centre that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in this debate, I was mentioning the problem we appear to have in providing the infrastructure to meet the demands of international tourists who want to come to Australia. I specifically mentioned the difficulty that is being experienced already in this high tourist season of international visitors trying to obtain seats on international flights into Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge the Government not to repeat the mistake it made 12 months ago by not loosening up the system quickly enough to be able to provide the additional services to handle that additional traffic flow. I also mentioned that this year there will be in excess of 2 million international visitors into Australia and I flag the fact that on all estimates in 1990 that amount will almost double. By the turn of the century there will be more than 5 million international visitors coming into Australia.

That really brings home the difficulties being faced in providing that infrastructure. What really worries me with the situation that has evolved with this Government is a lack of cooperation between Federal Government departments in trying to coordinate those efforts to provide the necessary infrastructure. It is true that more than eight years ago the Boeing International Corporation provided a report on the estimates of international arrivals into Australia. The recommendations made by the Boeing International Corporation have proved to be very conservative indeed, and in fact an underestimate occurred. But the real nub of the situation is that when these reports have been received from companies such as Boeing, which know the business, no notice has been taken of those estimates whatsoever. The result is that in 1988, when Australia is flavour of the month, we have great difficulty in being able to provide the ground facilities. There would not be one member of this House who would deny the fact that we have on our hands a number of disasters. I suppose the biggest disaster we are facing with the international visitors' arrival is the situation at Sydney Airport. At the moment Sydney international terminal is a disgrace and there is a general recognition that something must be done and it must be done quickly. The sad thing that has evolved in the case of Sydney, in the case of the new international terminal for Brisbane, and in the case of Melbourne to a degree, and I suppose even the debacle that has ended up as the international terminal in Perth, is that the Government in its wisdom has handed over the whole situation of our airports to a quango. The Federal Airports Corporation has been set up and we have seen disaster after disaster and a complete lack of capacity by that organisation to adapt to a real situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you are pork-barrelling in Queensland.

—We are not pork-barrelling in Queensland. Let me remind the honourable member that the port of Cairns is now a bigger international airport than Perth. The reason for that is that prior to 1983 the Government, in its infinite wisdom, allowed the Cairns Port Authority to set up that airport unencumbered from Federal Government intervention. That airport went out and got the business. I am glad the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) has raised the issue because this is what I am all about: that we do not have the capacity to provide the infrastructure. What we really should be doing, rather than handing over the situation to quangos, is getting into the marketplace and letting the people who really understand the situation go about the business of providing that infrastructure and providing it at no cost to the taxpayers of Australia-indeed, providing the infrastructure at a profit. That can be done. It has been proved that it can be done-not only in the United States of America but also in Britain at present and in ports such as Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Bangkok and Singapore. But, for some strange reason, we are not prepared to say to private enterprise, `You can provide this service better than we can; go ahead and let us relieve Australian taxpayers of the unbelievable cost of providing this infrastructure'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one of the things that the new Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) should be doing as a matter of priority is going about seeing how we can in fact relieve the Australian taxpayer of this incredible cost. If he looks at this matter wisely and well, he will see that the only option that we have is to let it out to private enterprise. Let us make a profit on the whole thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to tell of the considerable hardship being suffered by two of my constituents and their families at the hands of the Queensland State Government as a direct result of the operation of one of its many boards, or quangos as they have come to be known. What has happened to these people and the State Government's handling of their complaint is grossly unfair and utterly disgusting.

SPEECH.PARA: Both of my constituents, Mr Garth McDonald and Mr Fred Williams are the owners of chicken farms worth in excess of $600,000 each. Well over a million dollars worth of shedding and equipment has been made absolutely worthless by the Chicken Meat Industry Committee (CMIC), a State Government quango and, through its inaction, by the State Government itself. Because of what appears to be deliberate State Government policy, not only can these farms not be used for their intended purpose, but they cannot be used for any other purpose or, for that matter, even sold.

This is a story of gross harassment and abuse of power. It is an actual life account of the effect on ordinary hard-working Queensland men and women, of the tangled web of bureaucracy which has manifested itself in the form of boards and committees. It shows how they choke the life out of enterprise in what is supposedly a free enterprise State with a free enterprise Government.

It is of particular interest to note that Mr McDonald, until recently, has been a staunch supporter and I believe member of the National Party. In fact, I remember during the last Federal election seeing Mr McDonald outside a polling booth handing out how to vote cards for the Nationals. I can assure the House and National Party members that he now regrets every single vote and ounce of effort which he has given to that Party.

In 1984 both men had their contracts with Inghams Enterprises Pty Ltd, a major chicken meat processor, terminated. In the case of Mr Williams, this occurred because he was supposedly growing for another processor simultaneously with Inghams. This was undoubtedly the case, but he did so with the permission of Inghams. In the case of Mr McDonald, it was because he attempted to sell his farm as a going concern-that is, with the contract. This is something which was apparently quite normal practice in the industry, but for reasons best known to itself, Inghams terminated the contract on that basis. Neither person was given the six months' notice which is required under the contract. In short, I believe that they were mistreated.

This is where the Chicken Meat Industry Committee comes into the picture. Both Mr Williams and Mr McDonald referred their case to the CMIC in the hope that some justice would be done. Under section 15d of the Act which establishes this quango, it is stated that one of the board's functions is to `mediate in disputes between processors and growers'. The Committee found that, despite the apparent lack of logic or justice in the termination of the contracts, all was well and the contracts were terminated properly.

It is relevant to note the composition of the Committee, which is specified in clause 6 of the Act. There is a Chairman, who is appointed by the State Minister for Primary Industries, three representatives of processors, appointed by the State Minister and three representatives of growers, appointed by the State Minister. This composition has all the hallmarks of a National Party State Government quango. The really telling sign is the fact that everyone, absolutely every member of the board, is appointed by the Minister. There is plenty of scope to reward loyal members or supporters of the Party for their years of dedication, except of course Mr McDonald and Mr Williams.

The other important thing about the structure is that, although three representatives from both the growers and processors may on the surface appear fair, the fact is that growers cannot exist under the Act without being contracted to processors. The Act effectively prevents by way of its definition of the term `grower' any person in Queensland from growing more than 1,000 chickens at a time without being contracted to a processor.

I understand that at the time of the appeal by Mr Williams and Mr McDonald, one of the processors was Inghams and two of the growers held contracts with Inghams, the very company that caused the dispute by terminating the contracts.

This State Government kangaroo court delivered anything but justice to my constituents. Almost needless to say, their appeal was rejected. This is despite being supported by way of a petition signed by two-thirds of growers in the Brisbane area. Despite repeated requests for justice, the State Government has ignored them. They now own chicken farms which cannot be sold because they have contracts attached to them. They cannot be used for any purpose because the local shire council has determined that industrial activity at the sites would be incompatible with the character of the areas. They are prevented from growing more than 1,000 chickens by an Act which is designed to preserve monopolies written by a government which has the gall to call itself free enterprise.

Approximately eight sheds for Ingham growers have been established in my electorate since the time that their contracts were terminated. Yet these farms, with the capacity for more than 100,000 chickens, are idle because of the abuse by a large company aided by a State government that does not care about the welfare of small business. I call on the Queensland State Government to review this present foul situation urgently and amend its shonky Act so that it can never happen again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the history column of today's Canberra Times a little snippet appeared which, I suspect, was largely overlooked by most people in Canberra but which, I am pleased to say, was picked up by a member of my staff. That column pointed out that on this day 150 years ago, in 1838, Lieutenant-Colonel George Gawler arrived in Adelaide and on 17 October was sworn in as Governor of South Australia. As one who now resides in the city of Gawler in South Australia and as one who chose to move there because it is far and away the largest centre and most rapidly growing area in my electorate, I was interested to have this snippet brought to my attention. I was interested to discover that Governor Gawler was born in 1795 and died in 1869 and what we celebrate today occurred 150 years ago, just two years after the birth of South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Gawler was trained at the military college at Great Marlow in England, and achieved the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. He arrived in South Australia just when Governor Hindmarsh was having desperate disputes with the then resident commissioner of the South Australian Colonisation Society. To his horror Governor Gawler discovered that he was very quickly immersed in all the difficulties of that young colony. In fact, in 1838 there were 5,000 residents in South Australia still clinging to the city of Adelaide, unable to feed themselves and reluctant to move from the city because no land survey had been completed. I am grateful to the Parliamentary Library for providing me with some information on Governor Gawler and I would like to read a paragraph of that information. The information indicates that Governor Gawler, having arrived in South Australia, discovered the following:

The settlement had to be fed from outside, and most of its revenue was spent on food. Gawler had to start relief works near Adelaide for the poorer settlers; he spent the whole of his private means and drew bills on the London authorities for #270,000. By the end of 1840 the colony's financial position was desperate and the British Government, dishonouring his drafts, recalled Gawler. The news was brought to him by his successor, Captain (later Sir) George Grey in May 1841-a blow to his pride from which he never recovered-and he returned to England in 1842.

His work was long misjudged, largely because Grey's dispatches made the worst of his actions without suggesting the difficulties under which he had laboured. Actually, Gawler had done well for South Australia. He had appointed Charles Sturt Surveyor-General and encouraged in every way the completion of surveys. He had erected public buildings, organised a police force, and promoted the development of religious and social life . . . During his term 6,000 colonists were settled on the land.

Too little has been made of this man's impact on the history of South Australia. The city in which I now reside bears his name. The city of Gawler has become a satellite city for Adelaide, but it valiantly defends its character as South Australia's oldest country town. As honourable members would expect in view of its age, Gawler is a town which is dominated by bluestone buildings and the remnants of what was once a great foundry. Through it runs the picturesque River Light.

I point out that in 1986 the city of Gawler was host to the world three-day horse riding event and in fact horse activities have dominated the now rural tranquility of that part of South Australia. It is the gateway to the Barossa Valley and it will best be remembered by recent visitors from this Parliament, who were members of a committee on which I served, for the experience of one committeeman. He was travelling past the Gawler raceway and he saw another of our members running around the raceway in a manner reminiscent of the sort of shuffle that characterises Cliff Young. He was not surprised therefore to find that that member was the honourable member for Corangamite, Mr Stewart McArthur, in whose constituency Cliff Young resides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the re-election of the Cain Government in Victoria, the Western Australian Government will be next up for re-election. If ever there was any doubt about that, one has only to look at the front page of today's West Australian, which is headlined `Liberals wavering on tax file number'.
—Dowding is growing in the job.
—He is growing in the job, as the Minister intervenes. To know who is pushing this charge, we look half-way down the report and we see:

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia's Opposition spokesman on individual rights, Mr Hassell . . .
Those of us with a bit of a memory will remember that Mr Hassell was a senior Minister in the Court Government that brought in section 54b, that oppressive legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember it well.

—The Minister remembers it. That legislation meant that no more than three people could meet in the streets of Perth without a police permit. Mr Hassell, an ex-Minister in that Government which brought in that oppressive legislation, now has the role of Opposition spokesman on individual rights. There are many glittering virtues he might have to be a member of the Liberal Party, but the one he really has to have is front. Mr Hassell has more front than St George's Terrace. This born-again civil libertarian is now saying that we have to get rid of the tax file number. The article went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hassell said privacy was not the basic issue.
`The basic issue is power-Government power over the people-the taking away of our most basic rights as a free people'.

Those of us with a memory will always remember that Mr Hassell was the Minister for Police at the time of the infamous Noonkanbah dispute, where he used section 54b and the gestapo tactics of that day to break up legitimate picket lines. Here we have this born-again civil libertarian trying to do away with the tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is looking after his tax dodger mates.
—The Minister says he is looking after his mates.
—Labor is the great party of mates.
—Why don't you go back to your dolls' house? The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The tax file number system is expected to return $2.2 billion in revenue over 10 years by cracking down on tax fraud and welfare cheats.

That is something the Liberal Party, especially in Western Australia, would know all about. What we are seeing here is the Western Australian Liberal Party, for grubby political purposes, trying to put pressure on the Federal Liberal Party in Canberra to reject the legislation on the tax file number, notwithstanding the fact that this Government has gone out of its way to consult all groups and has deferred its privacy legislation so that the Opposition can have a good look at it and make sure it is up to its high standards.

Apart from doing all that, we now hear from the Western Australian Liberals that they want to junk the file number. If the Liberal Party in the Senate were to do that, taxpayers would miss out on $2.2 billion worth of tax cuts. The reason for bringing in the tax file number is to increase the efficiency of the Australian Taxation Office to make sure that it can match all the information it currently gets, to bring it up to 1988, and so that the computing power and facilities this Government has given to the Tax Office to make it more efficient can be used in the most efficient way. Yet for the most grubby political purposes, the Western Australian Liberal Party wants the Federal Liberal Party to do away with the number.

I also have a copy of a media release put out by the Western Australian Liberal State President, Mr Simpson, who is calling on the Federal Liberal Party not only to scrap the tax file number but also to oppose the tax on gold-that is, the company tax. Half-way down the statement Mr Simpson said that he has decided `to ask all Western Australian Federal Liberal MPs to continue to do all in their power to ensure no income tax is imposed on the goldmining industry'. He cannot even get that right. The fact is that it is company tax, not gold tax or income tax, as Mr Simpson said in the release. In Western Australia now, with an election not far away, we are seeing the Liberal Party doing exactly what it does best: trying to scuttle decent legislation in this House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any purchasers been, or are now, in arrears in payments to the Australian Wheat Board; if so, which countries and what has been, or is the extent of their arrears.
(2) What has been done to cope with these debts through rescheduling or other means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Payments for wheat sold on credit by the Australian Wheat Board from time to time become overdue. The extent and frequency of these late payments varies according to the market; with Egypt for example, it is not unusual for payments to be from 30 to 60 days late. However, the payment obligations in respect of all credit sales have always been met except in the case of Egypt where an agreement was reached in May 1987 under the auspices of the Paris Club to reschedule some $3909 million of wheat debts. These debts aside, overdue or late payments to the AWB (25 August 1988) amount to $A9 million and US$8.8 million, all relating to wheat sales to Egypt.

(2) Together with other creditor countries, Australia participated in a Paris Club meeting in May 1987 to provide debt relief to Egypt for official and officially insured debts. At that meeting it was agreed that debts relating to contracts entered into before 31 October 1986 and falling due before 30 June 1988 should be rescheduled. Participants agreed that there should be a 5 year grace period for the rescheduled credits, with repayments of 10 equal and semi annual instalments commencing on 31 March 1993. The AWB's credit sales to Egypt are covered by payments insurance through the national interest provisions of the Austrade Act. Claim payments were made to the AWB under its insurance policy with Austrade EFIC in March and June 1988.

The Paris Club agreement requires that Egypt sign a bilateral agreement with each participating creditor nation to implement the multilateral undertakings agreed to at the Paris Club. In Australia's case this agreement was signed in Cairo on 29 June 1988.
The bilateral agreement is considered to be a satisfactory outcome for Australia as arrangements for the payment of interest have a commercial basis which should recover refinancing costs.
